IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will address the evolving drug overdose epidemic by elucidating the complexities of polysubstance use among the general adult population and identifying the associated risk profiles. The findings will be particularly relevant for determining critical windows of changing risk or resilience to drug use across the life span. We will evaluate the predictive value of community and societal factors to inform future prevention, treatment, and public health initiatives to improve individuals’ health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clinician burnout—particularly in ICUs—has persisted, despite widespread recognition of this problem. This study will yield valuable information about a crucial missing piece of the puzzle: how organizational factors contribute to burnout in ICU clinicians and adverse, preventable outcomes in patients with acute respiratory failure. By generating novel evidence about the factors that promote organizational resilience in ICUs, the study will lead to improvements in quality of care for patients with acute respiratory failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Today’s biomedical researchers represent the backbone of innovation that improves public health nationwide. However, they have little resemblance to the America’s increasingly diverse populations which contributes to disparities in health access and outcomes. The proposed project to establish a G-RISE site at Delaware State University (DSU) will promote diversity of the new workforce in biomedical research. Being a Historically Black University, DSU is well positioned to significantly contribute towards this goal as its Neuroscience PhD program graduates are 60% among minorities underrepresented in the biomedical research workforce.

PROJECT_TITLE: G-RISE at Delaware State University: Diversifying neuroscience through predoctoral training at an HBCU
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Training and Workforce Development Study Section - D[TWD-D]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The goal of this proposal is to investigate the molecular mechanisms regulating the development of protective CD8 T cell immunity in the respiratory tract during influenza infection. We plan to elucidate the molecular cues, signaling pathways, transcriptional regulation and metabolic control of the development, maintenance and function of anti-influenza tissue-resident memory T cells (TRM). We expect our study will help to design future interventions to promote TRM protective function and long-term maintenance in the lung, which ultimately will aid the design of future influenza therapeutics and/or vaccines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Aligned collagen fibers are the primarily source of strength in tendons, ligaments, and menisci; however these fibers do not regenerate after injury, nor in engineered replacements, creating a lack of repair options. There is a need to regenerate these collagen fibers to develop functional repairs and replacements for tissues throughout the body. Using a novel culture system, we will investigate how cells sense and response to mechanical cues in developing collagen fibers so to better engineer functional ligament replacements and to drive repair in the body after injury.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: OEF/OIF/OND Veterans face an unprecedented array of combat-related disabilities. Referred to as polytraumatic injuries, these impairments often include traumatic brain injury, PTSD, chronic pain, and depression. Veterans with polytraumatic injuries struggle with community reintegration and psychosocial functioning, leading to high rates of unemployment, poor health outcomes, and increased risk for substance abuse and suicide. To date, however, there has yet to be a systematic investigation of the role of nutrition in psychosocial recovery. Our work, therefore, aims to operationalize and develop a theoretically grounded, empirically validated outcome measure of “nutritional functioning”. Additionally, as integrative health modalities are increasingly popular among injured OEF/OIF/OND Veterans, we will conduct our research in Whole Health and Rehabilitation settings. A unique cohort requires innovative approaches, and our project will address the VHA’s overarching goal of improving psychological recovery in Veterans with polytrauma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Young people who have experienced traumatic events are much more likely than those who have not had such experiences to acquire HIV and to develop substance use problems, costing the US economy hundreds of billions of dollars. The goal of the proposed research is to refine and evaluate a virtual reality tool to enhance the trauma-informed assessment and prevention of substance use and sexual risk behaviors among young people who have experienced trauma and are at high risk for HIV acquisition. The significantly heightened capacity for mentorship of early stage patient-oriented researchers who will learn about the incorporation of virtual reality technologies with HIV and substance use risk reduction for trauma-exposed young people, along with the numerous other related training experiences gleaned from the candidate's research program in these areas, further enhances the public health importance of the proposed K24 renewal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative  Alcohol use disorder and binge eating disorders are debilitating illnesses that often co-occur and develop during late adolescence. College students are particularly at-risk for establishing problematic binge drinking and binge eating patterns that could manifest into full disorders. We seek to develop and test a transdiagnostic approach to target the underlying mechanisms maintaining problematic binge drinking and eating behaviors among students. Developing an evidence-based mobile phone-accessible and personalized intervention that could be scalable to reach thousands of students nationally can help to alleviate personal, familial, and societal costs resulting from binge drinking and binge eating in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One outstanding question in addiction biology concerns the mechanism by which neurological changes persist long past the cessation of drug taking. The persistent nature of epigenetic modifications may underlie their role in chronic psychiatric diseases, such as addiction and depression. This proposal aims to define the molecular mechanisms by which a key neuronal transcription factor, Nr4a1, leads to long-term change in gene expression that persist across cocaine abstinence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As the population ages, cataract lowers vision of millions of Americans every year, requiring costly surgery, and it leads to blindness for millions of others in the developing world where surgery is unaffordable. We have found evidence that cataracts arise from the combination of irreversible destabilizing modifications, reversible oxidative modifications (disulfide bonds), and an unusual “interface stealing” interaction between eye lens crystallin proteins, which together lead to aggregation of these proteins. We will study the biochemical mechanisms and the altered protein structures that underlie this aggregation process and apply this combined knowledge to design aggregation inhibitors that could prevent or delay cataract.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a need for an effective vaccine that blocks the transmission of malaria. We will design a vaccine by “focusing” the immune response towards the same target epitope of a potent monoclonal antibody against Pfs48/45, an antigen candidate which we recently solved the structure of. The vaccine will be tested in the context of a next-generation vaccine adjuvant we developed which spontaneously converts well-characterized protein antigens into large particles with significantly greater immunogenicity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Graft vs. host disease (GVHD) remains a major barrier for the successful application of hematopoietic stem cell transplant for a wide range of benign and hematologic malignancies. There is increasing evidence that the microbiome can impact GVHD outcomes, though current understanding of how specific microbial species contribute to GVHD pathogenesis remains largely correlative with limited mechanistic insights. The proposed research will aim to improve the understanding of how the microbiota and microbiota-specific T cell response impact the alloreactive response to open additional strategies aimed at treating GVHD.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative  During their development, cells that are initially non-specialized undergo differentiation, causing them to commit to particular identities and to endow them with the properties necessary to perform their unique functions. We propose to reveal the genetic and molecular processes that cause cells to lock onto particular differentiated, specialized identities and will investigate how cells can be provoked to switch to entirely different identities. The findings from these studies could lead to methods for creating replacement tissues and organs in regenerative medicine, will contribute to our understanding of malformed organs in birth defects, and may provide important information about particular cancers of the digestive tract.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Cold exposure and mitochondrial stress induce the integrated stress response (ISR) in brown adipose tissue (BAT), resulting in the activation of the activating transcription factor 4 (ATF4). This proposal will elucidate the role of the unfolded protein response (UPR) kinase PERK on ATF4 activation, and will determine whether ATF4 is required and sufficient for the systemic metabolic adaptations to cold exposure and mitochondrial stress, via the secretion of growth and differentiation factor 15 (GDF15), as a batokine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Beige fat cells can consume a large quantity of calories as heat and hold great promise for combating the epidemic of obesity and metabolic disorders. This project will explore a new pathway of beige adipocyte generation, its regulation by a gene called NFIL3, and its effect on whole body energy balance and glucose control. This study will suggest new ways to treat and/or prevent obesity, diabetes and other metabolic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The Brief Research in Interdisciplinary Neurosciences (BRAIN) program offers a rich summer research opportunity at the Vagelos College of Physicians and Surgeons at Columbia University for predoctoral candidates interested in research in the field of aging, particularly among neurologic disorders including neurodegenerative illnesses such as Alzheimer, Parkinson and Lou Gehrig diseases, as well as a broad array of related neuroscience disciplines. This program provides an ideal environment for students to pursue careers in research studying diseases often without cure or even effective treatments, and thus pose a significant public health burden. In addition to researching neurological diseases, students learn essential principles of research at a critical training period, providing skills to launch successful research careers.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Ten to 15% of American couples experience infertility and 50% of all infertility is attributable to male factor; however, little is known about predictors of male infertility or how male infertility and other male factors predict subsequent reproductive and perinatal outcomes. The proposed prospective study will identify modifiable risk factors for poor semen quality and examine how male factors influence reproductive and perinatal outcomes, yielding important public health information about male reproductive health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE This project aims to investigate the role of an innate immune protein, C1q in atherosclerosis / cardiovascular disease. C1q binds “bad cholesterol” and helps macrophage immune cells break it down to be removed from the body, which prevents dangerous plaque build-up. This project will focus on identifying the molecular mechanisms involved to identify novel therapeutic targets for treating atherosclerosis and improving public health.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative In a preclinical Rhesus macaque model of cancer survivorship, this application will to develop next generation therapies to preserve and restore the fertility of males who are at risk of infertility due to their medical treatments. We will test a combination of pharmacological- and tissue-based therapies to preserve and/or restore fertility in a monkey model and with testicular tissues from human patients. Progress in the proposed application will expand the menu of reproductive options available to patients who have frozen their testicular tissues prior to gonadotoxic therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study will provide an evidence for the contribution of inherited mutations in DNA damage repair (DDR) genes in lung cancer susceptibility and etiology. It has immediate translational and preventive implications as lung cancer patients with DDR abnormalities would benefit from targeted therapies, such as PARP inhibitors and the genetic testing offered to undiagnosed relatives (cascade testing) would identify high-risk individuals for earlier or more frequent low doze CT screening for early detection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on understanding a new mechanism of immune evasion by glioblastoma (GBM), the most common and incurable brain tumor in adults; and developing a novel therapeutic strategy based on this scientific rationale. Once such strategies have been tested, there is the potential for a significant advance in cancer therapy for patients with this devastating brain tumor. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to reducing illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Disorders associated with under- and over-eating cause many health problems and are costing the United States billions of dollars in medical care. Although hunger-sensing neurons in a part of the brain called the hypothalamus have been identified, we do not know which neurons in the brain regulate the timing of feeding and, in turn, influence activity levels. This proposal seeks to identify the dopamine neurons and their targets that link feeding and timing of circadian rhythms.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: WHITE RIVER JUNCTION VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) is a common and serious condition affecting many Veterans. There are effective treatments for PTSD, but additional treatments are needed in order to better serve Veterans suffering from PTSD. Transcranial magnetic stimulation is one such promising treatment. It involves use of powerful magnet to stimulate the specific brain regions in Veterans with PTSD. Transcranial magnetic stimulation has been shown effective in treating depression, but currently it is unclear if it is an effective treatment for PTSD. We propose to conduct a randomized clinical trial in 91 Veterans with PTSD comparing the effectiveness of transcranial magnetic stimulation treatment and sham transcranial magnetic stimulation in treating PTSD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative More than one-quarter of translated proteins enter the secretory pathway. Our research is designed to elucidate sorting mechanisms that guide a broad range of secretory proteins through the early stages of this pathway. Defects in biogenesis of secretory proteins have wide-ranging effects on human health and disease including atherosclerosis, blood clotting disorders, kidney disease and cystic fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Despite the overwhelming success of cochlear implants, there remains wide variability in performance related to both patient and treatment factors. This project will use electrocochleography to assess cochlear health together with tests of cognitive function to develop prediction tools for speech perception abilities in quiet and background noise among cochlear implant candidates. Predicting performance has direct relevance to patient counseling and shared decision making (between clinician and patient), design and recommendations for auditory rehabilitation after cochlear implantation, consideration for device mapping and troubleshooting, and patient stratification in future clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Latino youth face longstanding disparities in health care access and utilization, especially the 9 million youth in immigrant families who represent half of Latino youth in the US. This study will take advantage of a unique opportunity to examine the multiple levels of influence that contribute to these disparities through a follow-up study of 1000 Latino youth and their families in the California Health Interview Survey (CHIS). California has the largest Latino and immigrant populations in the country, and CHIS captures the many unique dimensions of family citizenship and documentation statuses, making them an ideal state and survey in which to study health care disparities for Latino youth and families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: About 35% of U.S. adults report eating more or eating high-calorie/fat/sugar foods in response to stress or other negative emotions—a behavior known as comfort eating that increases risk for weight gain and the development of type 2 diabetes. Prior comfort eating interventions have used similar techniques and a one- size-fits all approach, achieving mixed results; however, new information about when and why comfort eating first develops, the characteristics of people who do and do not have confidence in their ability to quit comfort eating, and which groups of people are most at risk for poor health related to comfort eating will enable a new generation of targeted, tailored, and innovative intervention and prevention approaches. The present project will draw upon a rich data from a large, diverse, national sample of 2,022 U.S. adults age 18 and older— including current comfort eaters, former comfort eaters, and never comfort eaters—to fill these crucial gaps in knowledge, paving the way forward for future research to more effectively curb comfort eating and its adverse health impacts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation is a common cause of morbidity and mortality during critical illness. Spontaneous drive to breathe varies in unpredictable ways during acute respiratory failure and could be protective or harmful depending on clinical context. This research will deepen understanding of mechanisms underlying respiratory drive heterogeneity and its relationship with clinical outcomes in mechanically ventilated patients with acute respiratory failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tuberculosis (TB), caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality in young children <5 yr. old, especially children with underlying HIV-infection (HIV+). The vulnerability of young HIV- exposed and unexposed children to develop TB following primary infection is not understood, and current diagnostic tools perform poorly. Our proposal will advance pediatric global health by: 1) identification of immunologic signatures reflecting successful containment of primary Mtb infection that can serve as correlates of protective immunity for novel vaccine trials; 2) development of novel blood-based assays that discriminate between young children with TB and those who have successfully contained their infection.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative This study will describe in-school menstruation-related experiences of American Indian girls in rural, reservation communities as well as the experiences, perceptions, and comfort level of middle and high school educators in responding to the menstrual experiences of their students. The results of this research will provide insights into the school-based menstruation experiences of American Indian female adolescents and the perceptions of educators in reservation-based middle and high schools about the impacts of menstruation on learning and educational outcomes in the school setting. The findings will lay the groundwork for tailoring interventions addressing educational disparities for AI adolescent girls.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our long-term goal is to develop a new therapy for glaucoma, a prevalent eye disease characterized by increased intraocular pressure, neurodegeneration of the retina, and vision loss. We are focusing on myocilin, an extracellular matrix protein involved in regulating eye pressure; mutations in myocilin lead to an early-onset, inherited form of glaucoma. We are studying disease-causing mutants to understand the molecular mechanisms of pathogenesis, which, in turn, is guiding our efforts develop a new therapeutic that treats the underlying cause of the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE By leveraging optical spectroscopy, nanofabrication, and machine learning, this proposal advocates the development of three innovative platforms for ultrasensitive molecular sensing and nano-imaging in diverse biological systems. We propose to develop highly sensitive and spectrally enriched Raman sensing approach for multiplexed molecular detection by realizing surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy in the strong coupling regime. We also seek to employ self-assembly principles to: engineer a highly sensitive nanoscale magnetometer for intracellular quantum sensing; and design a new class of Raman-active peptide-based nanoprobes for targeted cellular imaging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: HEALTH RELEVANCE Illegal use of psychostimulants such as cocaine presents a worldwide health problem with huge socioeconomic costs to societies; however, little is known about genetic risk factors for substance abuse. We will use the powerful Drosophila melanogaster genetic model to precisely map variants that affect cocaine preference and consumption, perform a systems genetic analysis to infer causal regulatory networks associated with these traits, and use germline gene editing to prove causality of the genetic associations with cocaine preference and gene regulatory networks. Since approximately 67% of Drosophila genes have a human counterpart, both general principles derived from these studies and individual network elements will be relevant to human substance abuse phenotypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE During cell division, each daughter cell should receive one copy of each replicated chromosome, a process that requires functional centromeres and when failed has broad medical implications including infertility, birth defects and tumor development. Importantly, centromeres are not determined by a specific DNA sequence, but rather depend on a DNA-protein complex. Our goals here are to understand how human centromeres function and the molecular mechanisms that prevent failure of normal chromosome delivery and the subsequent broad effects on genome instability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Continued opioid abuse and HIV infection contribute to exacerbated systemic and CNS inflammation. The proposed project aims to define molecular mechanisms of opiate and HIV-induced microglia activation and neuronal damage utilizing 3D spheroid cultures utilizing iPSC-derived primary human neuronal cells. These in vitro model systems will be leveraged to identify host pathways to prevent microgliosis and the resulting neuroinflammation, which are critical to preventing the neuropathogenesis of HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Building upon a rich, interdisciplinary research environment with numerous NIA-funded investigators, this training grant seeks to support predoctoral trainees in the Brown University School of Public Health with a focus on aging health and health services for dementia care. The objective of this training program is to meet the growing demand for investigators conducting research on the biological, psychological and social forces that shape the manner in which older Americans, particularly older adults living with dementia, utilize health services and how those services affect their health and well-being.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative This project will establish a preliminary evidence base regarding the feasibility and acceptance of using privacy- preserving financial activity data as an objective behavioral marker in BD. Specifically, the project will: i) identify and address relevant privacy concerns; ii) develop a cross-platform prototype to collect financial activity and symptom data; and iii) develop and evaluate privacy-preserving machine learning models to detect early-warning signs in BD from financial activity data. Given the strong association between BD and financial instability, this project will provide crucial insights regarding potential assessment and intervention methods to support financial stability and overall wellbeing in BD, including for those living in remote and rural areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This study will investigate the association between sedentary behaviors (SB), brain health, and the risk of developing Alzheimer’s disease and all-cause dementia. Using a comprehensive set of both objective and self- report measures of SB from the UK Biobank, this study will form an essential foundation for developing effective behavioral interventions and prevention therapies for those at increased risk for developing Alzheimer’s disease.

PHR: Project Narrative Decreased lung function through inhaled Cadmium as an environmental pollutant, and particulate matter is known to cause small airway diseases; however, the mechanism remains unclear. This project will investigate how cadmium toxicity is responsible for persistent inflammation and airway remodeling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: We propose to examine whether a ketogenic compared to a standard diet in children with newly diagnosed diabetes would extend the honeymoon period – a transient improvement in insulin production that occurs shortly after diagnosis and greatly improves diabetes control and disease burden. Despite major pharmacological and technological advances, diabetes control remains poor in most children with diabetes, while conversely tighter diabetes control has been associated with weight gain, placing millions at risk for complications. A ketogenic diet could have benefits on insulin production, diabetes control and body weight, would be directly translatable, inexpensive and relatively free of major side-effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The integration of longitudinal cohort studies such as those funded by the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Insti- tute (NHLBI) has provided cardiovascular researchers an important opportunity to address emerging questions that would not have been answered by a single cohort, but at the same time substantially increases the complex- ity of data structures and demands novel analysis approaches. We develop a suite of novel Bayesian machine learning methods to address challenges posed by complex longitudinal data with censored survival outcomes, including missing exposure data, causal inference with time-varying confounding and sequential unmeasured confounding. Our work is uniquely relevant to the mission of NHLBI and is aligned within the institute's strate- gic vision, and will provide a key apparatus for advancing the understanding of emerging cardiovascular health questions via enhanced use of integrated data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Olfactory deficits are prevalent in the preclinical and early stages of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and are predictive of the conversion form mild cognitive impairment (MCI) to AD dementia. Experiments described in this proposal are designed to answer two fundamental questions regarding AD-related neurodegeneration: 1) Are olfactory deficits a direct consequence of neurodegeneration in the olfactory network, and its connectivity to hippocampus and the default mode network? and 2) If so, what are the mechanistic relationships behind early olfactory deficits, which precede memory, as well as other cognitive impairments in AD?

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: CHARLES R. DREW UNIVERSITY OF MED & SCI
PHR: Narrative Although substance use disorders are a health disparity that occurs more commonly in minority and low-income populations, underrepresented minority researchers and researchers from disadvantaged backgrounds are less like to go into research in this field and less likely to receive funding from NIDA. The Summer Substance Abuse Disorders Research Training (SummerSART) at Charles R. Drew University (CDU) and UCLA builds on the highly successful SART grant that, in turn, built on 15 years of DIDARP/MIDARP program (PI: Friedman) in which 159 mostly minority students received a meaningful research experience in substance use disorder fields along with training and mentorship. This grant proposes to provide research opportunities and courses for skill development and mentorship to undergraduates over the summer with the goal of training the next generation of substance use disorder researchers.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Transposons comprise approximately half of the human genome.  The piRNA pathway has a conserved  function in transposon silencing and genome maintenance during germline development, and mutations  in this pathway have recently been linked to male infertility, and insertions of these mobile  elements cause disease. This application addresses how the piRNA pathway responds to viral infection of the germline,  distinguishes between host genes and transposon, and responds to stress.  These fundamental  biological processes directly impact human health and development, and the proposed studies thus  support the mission of the NIH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Transcription factors and signaling molecules are key modulators of cartilage development, with alterations in either resulting in skeletal anomalies. We have identified a factor that is required for cartilage formation, presumably through its ability to regulate the expression of components of both of these groups. Results from this study will determine whether and how this factor controls transcription factors and signaling molecules during cartilage development, which may impact our therapeutic approach to correct skeletal defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative In ERASE HIV we have assembled a team of world leaders in HIV virology, immunology, advocacy, in vivo animal models, and drug development with the goal to define: (i) the key mechanisms regulating CD8+ T-cell- mediated antiviral functions, including cytotoxic T lymphocyte (CTL) activity and the recently described transcriptional silencing (i.e., pro-latency) effect, and (ii) the best way to manipulate these mechanisms by in vivo immune-based strategies to trigger the most effective CD8+ T-cells, NK cells, and ADCC responses to de- stabilize HIV persistence. This collaborative effort is uniquely poised to address the critical questions outlined in the proposal and to inform novel therapeutic strategies that can be translated in clinical trials to achieve viral remission and/or eradication in people living with HIV.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rapid, easy, and valid biomarkers of carotenoid, fruit, and vegetable intake are needed to monitor the association between infants and toddlers’ dietary intakes and health outcomes. The purpose of this project is to determine if a rapid, non-invasive measure of skin carotenoids can provide a valid estimate of carotenoid and fruit and vegetable intake in diverse American infants and toddlers, and if children’s carotenoid intake is associated with their visual function. Simple and valid measures to estimate infant and toddler fruit, vegetable and carotenoid intake will promote our understanding of children’s nutrition and health, and will help organizations to monitor children’s dietary intakes as needed to promote healthier dietary patterns.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will address a gap in knowledge regarding how the structural organization of synapses is robustly established during development yet flexibly modified during learning to sustain behaviors. Synapses, which are specialized junctions between excitable cells, govern information flow through neural circuits, and where/how they form affects neural circuit architecture, information processing and animal behaviors. Because these mechanisms are conserved throughout evolution, the findings emerging from the completion of the proposed work will result in broad conceptual insights that will inform our understanding of how these processes could go awry in disease, including neurodegeneration and neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The mechanisms that regulate skeletal muscle topography to perfectly align muscle morphology with the overall body plan remain poorly understood. We are investigating the integrated actions of short-range navigational signals, morphogenetic gene regulatory networks, and contact-dependent cell recognition programs that direct muscle morphogenesis and regulate muscle topography. The foundational work proposed in this study will be a necessary first step toward understanding how multiple regulatory modules cooperate to direct myogenesis in more complex systems and how dysregulation of these regulatory modules contribute to human disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study of the largest 20th Century pandemic, the Spanish flu of 1918, aims to investigate who was at risk of dying in New York and Philadelphia, which were among the cities with the highest fatality rate. Key questions are how death rates varied across neighborhoods and over time, based on such factors as their age, racial, ethnic, and class composition, and how these neighborhood inequalities affected individual residents. The 1918 pandemic in several ways was a precursor to the COVID-19 pandemic, and the study of how inequality was affected in 1918 will provide concepts and measurement approaches that can be applied in the current case and other future pandemics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease impacts 6.5 million Americans and is projected to affect more than 12 million by 2060, if there are no significant advances in prevention and treatment. To address these needs, we must study non- neuronal, but increasingly important, drivers of Alzheimer’s, such as vascular and aging influences. This project will utilize in vitro models to understand these dysfunctions and will contribute significantly to our understanding of Alzheimer’s disease, increasing the scientific potential to design specific therapeutics to reduce illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE / RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Acute lung Injury (ALI), a common cause of respiratory failure in critically ill patients such as those with sepsis and COVID-19, affects ~200,000 Americans each year with 10-15% of intensive care admissions and is associated with a mortality rate of ~ 25-40% in reported cases. All current therapies for ALI and its more severe form Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) rely on supportive care to improve clinical outcome and no effective drugs have been developed. The proposed studies are designed to understand how BiP/GRP78 and Mortalin/GRP75, two important proteins present in endoplasmic reticulum and mitochondrion respectively, collaborate in causing ALI/ARDS and have the potential for the development of an efficacious and superior therapeutic strategy that relies on combined inhibition of BiP/GRP78 and Mortalin/GRP75 to control ALI/ARDS in sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because chitin synthases (CHSs) are highly promising and clinically unexploited targets of antifungal therapeutics, and existing CHS inhibitors exhibit in vivo antifungal activities against pathogens that cause endemic invasive fungal infections in humans. The proposed project will provide an atomic-level understanding of the catalysis and inhibition of CHSs from pathogenic fungi. Since such knowledge is critical for the future development of clinically useful CHS-targeting antifungal antibiotics, the proposed research is an important step towards combating fungal infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This Phase 2 STTR proposal will develop CF10, the first DNA-based fluoropyrimidine (FP) polymer, as a new treatment for metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC). The best available treatments for mCRC use 5-fluorouracil (5-FU)-based regimens and were optimized over decades, but result in <15% 5 year survival with <50% of mCRC patients treated with chemotherapy surviving 1 year. Through Phase 1 STTR support, we demonstrated improved anti-cancer activity for CF10 in rodent colon cancer models and an improved toxicity profile relative to 5-FU. To advance CF10 into clinical trials we will test for improved survival relative to current therapy in a rodent model of pre-treated mCRC. We also develop a lipid nanoparticle (LNP) formulation to improve CF10 pharmacokinetics. Safety Pharmacology testing of CF10 with LNP formulation will be performed in rodents and non-human primates (NHPs). Our studies will provide a foundation for regulatory approval to initiate clinical studies. Ultimately, CF10, will improve long-term survival for patients with mCRC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative This is a multidisciplinary, highly collaborative consortium that combines next-generation sequencing with state-of-the-art behavioral screening in a unique, genetically diverse, nonhuman animal model. The goals of this consortium are to identify gene variants that are associated with oxycodone use, the effects of oxycodone on analgesia and pain using genome-wide association studies (GWAS), and the sensitivity to FDA-approved treatments in behaviorally characterized heterogeneous stock rats, and to maintain a data/tissue repository (Oxycodone BioBank) accessible to all researchers to study the cellular and molecular mechanisms of oxycodone addiction. Results from these studies have the potential to have a sustained and powerful impact on the field of addiction because they will identify novel druggable targets, provide a comprehensive analysis of oxycodone addiction-like behaviors in males and females, and maintain a unique data/tissue repository that will facilitate follow-up and replication studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research is significant because it will provide a critical step forward in the development of a humanized glial mouse model of NeuroAIDS that can mirror human disease. Natural progression of brain infection and disease in relation to peripheral HIV infection makes this mouse model most relevant for the studies of viral reservoir assessments, neuropathology, and therapeutic development including eradication strategies. These mice are important tools to study the role of substances of abuse on viral reservoirs and HAND.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Damage to our genome, including DNA double-strand breaks programmed in developing lymphocytes, must be recognized and efficiently repaired to avoid oncogenic aberrations, such as chromosomal translocations. The DNA break response includes extensive revisions of regional chromatin; however, the impact of spatial architecture surrounding damage sites on their subsequent repair remains unknown. This project will define how the three-dimensional conformation of our genome can aid or impede the holding together of broken chromosome ends until they are repaired, thus impacting their potential to produce cancer-causing alterations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic pain is a major healthcare problem with annual cost of above $600 billion in the United States; generalizability of available evidence for treatment of chronic pain (mostly from traditional explanatory randomized controlled trial data) is problematic as these trials exclude up to 90% of patients: leaving out real- world patients with serious medical and psychological comorbidities. We will perform a pragmatic randomized comparative effectiveness trial using our point-of-care randomization. We will then use the data from this trial to build a model predicting the response to anti-convulsants and anti-depressants to develop a platform for precision health: predicting how to choose the best medication for each patient with chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) has prominent autoimmune and fibrotic features but their interplay is not well- understand. Herein, we characterize the role of Interferon Regulatory Factor 7 (IRF7) as a key link between these two components which could represent a significant step forward in understanding the molecular basis of systemic sclerosis. This additional insight into the disease mechanism can open the door for the development of more effective treatment options in this potentially devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To break the cycle of persistent community gun violence that primarily affects low-income, Black, and Latinx neighborhoods, this proposal aims to challenge long-standing structural racism, manifest through redlining and mass incarceration, and the social context that permits and normalizes trauma after exposure to gun violence. TRUE HAVEN: TRUsted rEsidents and Housing Assistance to decrease Violence Exposure in New Haven is a multi-level, multi-component, strengths-based, community-driven intervention focused on reducing gun violence by (1) improving housing stability through providing financial assistance coupled with comprehensive financial education and (2) fostering greater support for mental health by training a trusted network of community members in trauma-informed counseling. We will test the effectiveness of TRUE HAVEN within specified neighborhoods using a step wedge design, while also identifying intervention facilitators and barriers and project long-term outcomes using a simulation model, yielding a roadmap for how cities can effectively and systematically tackle structural racism to reduce gun violence and improve community health and well-being.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Regulatory genes that control embryonic development are shared among diverse species because changes in their basic functions are highly deleterious. Surprisingly, we found that the genes controlling a fundamental feature of the insect body plan – segmentation – have changed during insect evolution, with genes gained, lost or changed in function. We explore the evolutionary and molecular mechanisms underlying these changes, which have allowed for seamless re-wiring of regulatory interactions, and develop tools to examine a cohort of segmentation genes in new insect model systems that use different genes for early patterning than the established model Drosophila melanogaster.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Eating disorders are common in adolescents, increase the risk of substance use, have the highest mortality rate of any psychiatric illness and are not responsive to current pharmacotherapy. The overall goal of this K23 proposal is to evaluate neuroimaging as a pharmacodynamic biomarker of opioid antagonism in adolescents with eating disorders through practical application of training in neuroimaging, pediatric randomized clinical trials and exposure-response modeling. At the completion of this proposal, Dr. Stephani Stancil will be well- positioned for an independent career as an interdisciplinary translational scientist focused on pharmacodynamic biomarker development to support early-stage drug development in pediatric neuropsychopharmacology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Schools are the most common setting for mental health (MH) service delivery to children and adolescents; unfortunately, school health and MH professionals face a number of barriers to using validated MH screening tools, including lack of familiarity with and access to established measures, scoring and interpretation challenges, and limited time and resources to set up and administer MH assessment. These impediments contribute to the disturbing fact that two out of three youth with a diagnosable MH problem in the U.S. do not get the help they need, leading to heightened risk for chronic MH problems as well as school failure, family problems, and risky behaviors (e.g., substance use). The goal of this Direct to Phase II SBIR is to increase access to and use of established high quality MH and MH-related assessment measures in schools which, in turn, has the potential for broad-reaching public health impact for youth and families.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity is associated with ovulation failure and negatively impacts the function of ovarian blood vessels in women; however, the mechanisms by which obesity increases the risk of ovulation failure are not fully understood, and in particular, it is not known whether obesity impedes necessary changes in ovarian vascular function leading up to ovulation. This research will produce new understanding of how ovarian vascular function is regulated at the cellular and molecular levels and how obesity impacts these processes required for ovulation. This knowledge will support the design of novel infertility treatments that can benefit millions of women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Telomeres are specialized structures located at the ends of chromosomes that fulfill an essential role in maintaining the structural and genetic integrity of the genome. Telomeres do this by controlling the number of times each cell can divide. Once a cell becomes damaged or acquires a potentially harmful mutation, telomeres signal to other proteins that elicit a permanent cessation of cell division. This prevents the development of cancer. However, mutations can bypass this arrest in cell division and re-initiate cellular division. These cells must also re-activate a mechanism that ensures that telomeres once again maintain the structural integrity of chromosomes but are no longer capable of blocking cell division. This is achieved by activating one of two different telomere maintenance mechanisms. One of these mechanisms is known as alternative lengthening of telomeres, or simply ALT. Cancers that rely on ALT tend to be among the most aggressive and patients often have a poor prognosis. Therefore, understanding the molecular basis for the activation and maintenance of the ALT pathway and identifying the key regulators of ALT is critically important for improving the detection and treatment of this devastating disease. We have identified an essential mediator of ALT telomere maintenance named HIRA. We show that deletion of HIRA or attenuating its function is capable of killing cancer cells that rely on ALT. Developing a greater understanding of the molecular function of HIRA and evaluating its potential as a cancer therapy target is the focus of our study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Osteoporosis is a prevalent disease characterized by low bone mineral density, bone fragility, and fractures. Mice lacking the potassium ion channel Girk3 have elevated bone mass and reduced circulating cytokines in adulthood, making Girk3 a novel target for bone remodeling. This research will determine the physiological and cellular mechanisms by which Girk3 regulates cytokine production and bone mass and test whether Girk3 deletion prevents ovariectomy-induced osteoporosis in a cytokine-dependent manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Project narrative: This project will test for differences in emotion dynamics (e.g., within-day negative affect variability and emotion differentiation) across NIAAA recovery (e.g., cessation of heavy drinking and remission from DSM-5 AUD) phases examine associations between amotion dynamics and alcohol consumption between and within NIAAA recovery phases. Study findings have the potential to provide critical information that can serve to identify optimal timing of intervention and re-intervention during different recovery periods, prepare patients for affective changes that may occur during AUD recovery, and inform longitudinal studies that examine trajectories of relapse and recovery in the long-term.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative The goal of this project is to understand the molecular mechanisms and physiological roles of store-operated calcium channels for Ca2+ signaling in neurons and astrocytes, and examine implications for brain pathologies including inflammation-induced depression and neuropathic pain. Findings from these studies will provide new mechanistic insights into Ca2+ signaling pathways controlling neuronal and astrocyte function, and could in the long run, yield a new therapeutic target for brain diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative CDC34 and SCF/CRL E3 ligases function together to control myriad cellular processes such as cell cycle progression, a process essential to life that when dysregulated is a defining feature of cancer cells. CRL E3 ligases are also hijacked by PROTAC molecules which harbor therapeutic potential by inducing degradation of proteins of interest that contribute to human disorders. Successful completion of the proposed studies will reveal the molecular mechanisms by which Cdc34 and SCF/CRL E3s function together as essential regulators of key cellular processes and will provide a platform for development of novel cancer therapeutics.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative We have discovered that distinct PIWI-interacting RNA (piRNA) transcription complexes drive expression of male- and female-specific germline piRNAs. The goal of this proposal is to understand the mechanisms by which sex-specific piRNAs are expressed and regulate endogenous germline genes. We will characterize the distinct male and female piRNA transcription complexes and elucidate the impact that sex-specific piRNAs have on animal fertility, thus providing insights into therapeutic opportunities for human infertility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Scarring is the end result of injury in adult human skin and results in an enormous financial and medical burden for our society, yet no molecular therapies exist that can prevent scarring or its sequelae. While dermal adipose tissue has been proposed to contribute to wound healing via adipocytes transitioning into wound fibroblasts, the role and drivers of adipocyte-to-fibroblast transition in scarring remain poorly understood. Therefore, we propose to explore the biomolecular and tissue mechanical drivers of wound adipocyte-to-fibroblast transition, in order to inform potential novel targets to minimize scarring and promote regenerative wound healing.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Personalizing stroke gait rehabilitation hinges on our understanding of how neural constrains limit an individual’s ability to coordinate many muscles and joints to achieve relatively few task level goals, such moving the whole-body stably, efficiently, and quickly. This project will characterize interindividual and inter-limb differences in whole-body dynamics and joint-level strategies for achieving desired whole body dynamics during treatment. Identifying characteristic relationships between joint and whole-body dynamics may explain diverse treatment responses and provide novel metrics to characterize stroke gait rehabilitation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multiple lines of evidence suggest the involvement of brain and peripheral innate and adaptive immunity in Alzheimer’s disease (AD); however, the mechanisms remain unknown. The proposed studies will perform multi-tissue (brain, meninges, choroid plexus and peripheral blood) single cell multiomics and spatial transcriptomics profiling of immune cells in AD and control cases. To gain additional mechanistic insights into the interaction among the adaptive and innate immunity, we will perform parallel studies in AD mouse models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Severe neonatal jaundice can be fatal and is a leading cause of death among newborns in many developing countries. The blood tests needed to detect severe jaundice are expensive and invasive, but non-invasive options have low accuracy in dark-skinned newborns. We propose to develop and clinically test the ability of a novel, non-invasive mobile phone-integrated device to provide accurate, point-of-care detection of jaundice in dark-skinned newborns.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research aims to reduce mental health disparities in the Latinx community by enlisting  promotoras, who are trusted community voices, to collaborate in designing and later to deliver a culturally  specific intervention to improve mental health services use. We will measure the impact of this intervention at  the community, interpersonal, and individual levels. Ultimately, our goal is to create a sustainable and scalable  model and culturally specific materials to decrease disparities in mental health services use within the Latinx  community as well as to create a template for conducting similar outreach in other underserved communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project narrative: The current proposal takes a critical direction by aiming to reveal the brain- wide principles underlying the development of mnemonic and executive functions of the mammalian brain. This development is conceived as the result of age- and experience- dependent maturation of network computations within the MEC and the mPFC and of neuronal ensemble coordination between these areas and the hippocampus (e.g., memory-guided decision making). The results of these studies promise to indicate new targets for preventive and therapeutic interventions in early-onset neuropsychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Racial disparities in maternal health in Georgia are stark and in need of systematic review, analysis, and intervention. This study will combine a statewide assessment of racial disparities in adverse maternal health outcomes with an evaluation of Georgia’s Medicaid Inter-pregnancy Care Program and a randomized trial of a comprehensive postpartum care system in an urban safety-net hospital. By studying the complex array of individual, health care system, community, and societal level factors that culminate in women’s lack of access we will fill critical gaps in knowledge regarding policy and health system approaches for reducing disparities in maternal morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is a metabolic disorder with a high prevalence in the USA and is found to be tightly associated with the cellular toxic effects caused by excess input of lipids in the liver. The proposed studies will investigate the knowledge gap of the fate of the cell digestion-derived lipids, and how it relates to NAFLD progression. Identification of the transport and distribution of this part of lipids and the related molecular mechanisms will deepen the understanding to NAFLD pathology and promote strategy designs for NAFLD interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE A protein called -catenin regulates many cell functions related to cell replication, growth and death through interaction with a vast network of many other proteins. Attempts to disrupt -catenin activity therapeutically have failed to date because previous attempts could not selectively inhibit its cancerous activity while maintaining its normal, required functions. The interaction of -catenin with a protein called BCL9 is often the cause of breast and other cancers, and represents an ideal therapeutic target. We have developed a peptide to selectively block the interaction between -catenin and BCL9, which we now propose to advance through animal testing to bring to testing in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Mutations in MYH9 that encodes for Nonmuscle Myosin IIA (NM2A), an actin associated motor protein, have been associated with kidney disease in humans, but the mechanisms by which MYH9 mutations cause kidney disease is unclear. Previous work focused on podocyte actin cytoskeleton in the Glomerulus. Our recent work established a novel function for Myh9&10 proteins in cargo transport in the thick ascending limb (TAL) epithelium, and loss of this function in mice resulted in rapidly progressing kidney disease. We propose to investigate the role of Myh9&10 in the TAL cargo transport system in the kidney. We will also test if combined loss of Myh9 protein in podocyte as well as tubular epithelium will lead to exacerbated disease due to synergistic functional loss in both cell types. Our work will directly address the loss of distinct functions of Myh9 in two different cell types within the kidney, reasonably modeling a severe form of MYH9-RD with complete loss of function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on identifying shared experiences, opinions, advice, (mis)information, and persistent delivery features of those messages in tobacco product culture on social media, a key socio-ecological feature of the environment of adolescent and young adult (AYA) tobacco use. With this information, there is potential for significant improvement in responsiveness of research and practice to current AYA needs and authenticity of social media interventions for AYA. The project is relevant to NIDA’s mission because it will advance science on the social ecological environment and social mechanisms of nicotine addiction among adolescents and young adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Soluble urokinase activating receptor (suPAR) has been implicated as one of the significant risk and pathogenic factors for the onset and progression of chronic kidney diseases regardless of the etiologies. In this grant application, we focus on the role of the proteolytic fragment of suPAR, D2D3, in simultaneously injuring two organs, the kidney and the pancreas. The ability to study molecular mechanisms of injury to two organs and organ-specific cell types (glomerular podocytes and β-cells of the pancreas), is a critical step in developing novel, mechanism-specific therapeutics for both, chronic kidney diseases and insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This project will assemble the largest ever cohorts of persons with and without HIV infection who will be classified according to the presence of moderate-to-severe hepatic steatosis based on the application of artificial intelligence methods to clinically obtained noncontrast abdominal computed tomography (CT) scans. The proposed research will contribute to fundamental knowledge on the factors associated with hepatic steatosis and risk of liver complications associated with steatosis among persons with HIV and assess how these differ from those without HIV infection. The results of these studies will inform interventions to prevent or mitigate the development of hepatic steatosis among persons with HIV, which will help to lower the risk of liver complications and prolong survival in this population.

PHR: Narrative In the central nervous system, the activation of NMDA (N-methyl-D glutamate) receptors produces electrical currents that are essential for brain functions such as cognition, learning, and memory. Excess electrical currents cause cellular loss in stroke, brain and spinal cord injuries, and age-related diseases such as Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s. In this project we will study how the internal parts of the receptor move during activation and how prospective drugs or clinically identified mutations alter these motions, to gain the basic knowledge that will enable the design of more effective therapeutic approaches for the many neurological conditions involving NMDA receptors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tuberculous lymphadenitis (TBL), the most frequent extrapulmonary form of TB, is a serious health problem in Tunisia and throughout the developing world. Here, we propose to integrate single cell RNA-sequencing (scRNA-seq) and spatial-seq to analyze the cellular and molecular architecture of granulomas in TBL to understand host defense mechanisms to control the infection. As such, our studies of the specific immune biosignatures in TBL will expand our understanding of its immunopathogenesis, leading to improved diagnostic and therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Transcription factors (TFs) mediate long range chromatin interactions to regulate specific gene expression; disruption of this process could lead to human diseases. The proposed research aims to develop a novel method for robust mapping of TF-mediated chromatin interactions which will help study the mechanisms of transcription regulation in physiological functions and pathological diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Post-stroke cognitive impairment (PSCI) is a major sequela of stroke in both young and old stroke patients, with no FDA approved treatment. In this application, we propose to identify DKK3 as novel therapeutic target for the treatment of cognitive impairment induced by ischemic stroke. The proposed studies may reveal previously unappreciated mechanisms underlying PSCI and provide a novel therapeutic approach to improve cognitive outcomes following stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Maternal obesity and consumption of high calorie diets continue to be public health concerns as the perinatal environment provides support that is critical to the proper development and health of offspring. Preliminary data suggests that maternal high fat (HF) diet during development is associated with changes in meal patterning suggesting impaired post-ingestive feedback along the gut-brain axis that may be a result of with microbiota dysbiosis. The current proposal will investigate how perinatal HF diet and dysbiosis alters gut-brain axis development and vagally- mediated controls of feeding in HF offspring and leads to increased susceptibility to obesity and other metabolic disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative  Pediatric healthcare inequities in the United States remain persistent and pervasive; patient-provider communication and the frequent mismatch between a family’s skills and resources and the healthcare system’s demands (such as health literacy and system navigation) are important drivers of these inequities, yet few interventions exist to address them. This project will test the effectiveness of the Family Bridge Program, a novel intervention combining principles of effective patient navigation and communication coaching into a brief and targeted inpatient program, on family-centered outcomes including system navigation ability, hospital-to- home transition, comprehension, and observed communication quality. If found effective, the Family Bridge Program would provide a scalable model for addressing inequities in healthcare experiences and outcomes for families of low-income children of color, including those with limited English proficiency.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Family violence imposes substantial and long-lasting burdens on children, particularly those in heavily policed and incarcerated communities. But little is known about how objective and subjective experiences of institutional contact in such communities may affect family violence incidence, disclosure, help-seeking, or consequences. The proposed project will advance the study of children’s exposure to family violence in the contemporary United States by collecting primary qualitative and survey data and applying inductive and latent variable methods for formative analysis. psychometric validation, and hypothesis testing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Myogenic direct reprogramming from non-muscle somatic cells has become an important strategy to produce abundant, patient-specific, and disease-specific human myogenic cells, but applications of these cells are hampered by low reprogramming efficiency and their immature nature. In this project, we will develop a high- throughput screening platform with a simple, low-cost, and physiologically relevant readout to effectively discover efficient myogenic reprogramming technologies. Successful accomplishment of this project will result in new technologies to generate directly reprogrammed human myogenic cells exhibiting more similarities to true myogenic cells for therapeutic applications and disease modeling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative The p53 tumor suppressor is a DNA damage/stress response protein that functions as a transcription factor to regulate a large repertoire of genes that prevent proliferation of damaged cells via initiation of cell cycle arrest and senescent programs or via apoptosis and other mechanisms of cell death. We have defined a pan-tissue p53 transcriptional signature that includes seven genes, three of which have been implicated in human cancers and have unique properties as a cell surface receptor that induces apoptosis (Eda2r), as a potential novel p53 inhibitor (Gtse1), and as an error prone DNA polymerase (Polκ). In this proposal, we will directly evaluate the functional contributions of these genes to p53-dependent cellular outcomes and tumor suppression in vivo, and comprehensively evaluate the p53 transcriptional response at single cell resolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Synthetic chemistry provides access to molecules important to human health through the assembly of chemical building blocks into drugs and molecular probes. This proposal outlines a program designed to provide new iridium-catalyzed methods for the synthesis of alkylboronic esters by direct sp3 C-H borylation. A central feature of this program is the application of catalyst- controlled selectivity to upgrade abundant chemical feedstocks into valuable, complex products including unnatural amino acid derivatives, linker molecules, and cyclic boronic esters.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study examines the precise timing, nature, and modifiable determinants of spontaneous change in cigarette smoking during pregnancy to identify novel mechanisms that disrupt addictive processes. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is expected to develop in vivo MR to assess tendon matrix structural and metabolic properties. This work will use both NMR studies of tissue explants and MRI studies in phantoms, tissue explants, and humans, to establish MR chemical shift imaging markers of tissue damage and metabolism. We will also establish relationships between acute bouts of tendon loading and chemical shift signatures of cell metabolic response. We aim to optimize MRI acquisition and analysis methods and establish a robust in vivo approach for characterizing matrix structural and functional differences between healthy tendon and tendinopathy.

PHR: Project Narrative The identification of distinct cell-types throughout the basal ganglia has been essential in advancing our understanding of network function and improving neurological therapies. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Deformability and non-adherence are the most intrinsic biorheological properties of red blood cells (RBCs), as they play a critical role in modulating RBC perfusion through the microvasculature. OcclusionChip is a novel standardized in vitro microfluidic assay to measure microvascular occlusion mediated by red blood cells in a wide range of clinical conditions. The goal of this project is to establish the manufacturability, analytical validation, and clinical utility of the OcclusionChip in providing comprehensive functional characterization of red cell biorheological properties and assessment of patient-specific response to emerging targeted and curative therapies in sickle cell disease.

PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): Ozone is a ubiquitous urban air pollutant that causes significant cardiopulmonary morbidity in healthy and  susceptible individuals, including children and the elderly. Our studies are focused on elucidating the role of  estrogen receptor signaling in macrophage inflammatory responses to ozone which are known to be  important in tissue injury and disease pathogenesis. Results may lead to the development of novel  strategies for mitigating disease burden and will better inform regulatory guidelines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE This training grant renewal application requests continued support for our training program in Alzheimer's disease and related dementia (ADRD-TP). The foundation of this training program is an outstanding group of preceptors who have exceptional combination of expertise that permits and promotes the multidisciplinary training of versatile ADRD researchers. The Program is composed of four integrated themes of research training: (1) Biological Mechanisms (2) Drug Discovery and Development (3) Clinical (4) Biophysics, Bioinformatics and Computational Science. In addition, the program includes collaborative training with the pharmaceutical industry in drug development and clinical trials in ADRD. This program encourages trainees to integrate and cross information, in a way that stimulates complex problem solving, required for finding a cure for ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study seeks to demonstrate that the omentin/TSG-6 axis plays a role in normalizing the pro- inflammatory omental microenvironment and preventing ovarian cancer development. This new understanding will enable us to delineate the immune modulator role of omentin in high-grade serous ovarian cancer (HGSC) pathogenesis, and to further develop omentin as low-toxicity chemopreventive and therapeutic agent for HGSC patients, ultimately improving their survival rates. Other prevention strategies that can upregulate omentin, such as weight loss and exercise programs, can also be developed to help prevent cancer metastasis and recurrence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opioid use disorder (OUD) affects millions of people, while existing medications are not readily accessible and suffer from low patient compliance. IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The retina, an outgrowth of the brain, is implicated in the development of Alzheimer's disease (AD). Although there is mounting evidence of a link between AD and age-related macular degeneration (AMD), the underlying molecular mechanisms that account for the similarities of these two neurodegenerative diseases are not yet well understood. This study aims to perform comparative single-cell data analysis to identify shared cell types and common cellular pathways between AD and AMD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narratives The brain consists of structures and neural circuits that are nonlinearly organized in nature. Electrophysiological mapping of complete structures or circuits is critical to understand their functional organization, synaptic connectivity, and signal processing. This project explores a new modality that allows the nonlinear implantation of flexible neural probes to conformally cover designated structures or circuits at minimal surgical lesions and thus enables mapping nonlinear brain trajectories at unprecedented spatial resolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: 8. Project Narrative To develop and deliver novel therapies such as antibody therapeutics, cell therapies and vaccines, scientists need to be able to study how large numbers of individual cells perform over time. CellChorus has developed an artificial intelligence-powered platform that evaluates the performance of thousands of individual cells over time. This project will support scaling the platform from the company’s lab to an instrument that can be placed in any laboratory or therapeutic manufacturing facility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The brain processes information through the collective activity of large networks of neurons that integrate incoming stimuli and respond by sending precisely timed electrical impulses towards their neighbors. Here we propose to develop a novel computational microscopy method designed to capture the signals emitted from fluorescent voltage-sensing reporter proteins across large volumes of mammalian brain tissue and thus measure electrical neuronal activity from thousands of individual neurons. This unprecedented recording capacity will enable precision studies of how neuronal network activity works on a fundamental level and will allow insights into how it is altered in pathological disorders of the human brain. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Accurate chromosome segregation critically depends on the effective attachment between kinetochores of the chromosomes and microtubules of the mitotic spindle. Defective kinetochore-microtubule attachments lead to chromosome mis-segregation and aneuploidy. Our work will examine new mechanisms that control kinetochore- microtubule attachments to prevent chromosome mis-segregation. Our long-term goal is to understand how defects in these mechanisms lead to the biogenesis and progression of cancer generated by aneupoidy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative We have assembled a multi-institutional collaborative center with the aim of creating a cellular taxonomy of molecularly defined cell types in the developing human, Rhesus macaque, and marmoset brain. Our project employs technologies for automated single nucleus and spatially-resolved RNA-sequencing and single cell transposase accessible chromatin sequencing to create spatial gene expression and epigenomic developmental expression maps for human and NHP brain. We will sample 30 brain regions at four key epochs of development and register our cellular data onto MRI-based Common Coordinate Frameworks to create a unique resource that will serve as a blueprint for studies of human brain function and selective vulnerability of cell types to disease and will provide foundational data for the development of primate and in vitro models.
