IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project presents a mentoring and training strategy in the development of novel antimicrobials with novel rRNA discriminating recognition oligomers. Antimicrobial resistance occurs when microorganisms (often infectious bacteria, viruses, and certain parasites) are no longer sensitive to drugs that were previously used to treat them; this is of global concern because it hampers our ability to control infectious disease and increases the costs of health care. In order to combat this world-wide problem, innovative strategies for antibiotic drug design must be implemented. The proposed research describes such a mentoring and training plan using novel antimicrobial compounds that evade common resistance pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overarching goal of the proposed project is to understand the molecular mechanism of Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD) by leveraging the publicly available single-cell data from human brain tissues. We will apply the novel machine learning methods for gene regulatory network construction proposed in our parent R01 to single-cell data from healthy individuals and patients with ADRD. Results from these analyses will augment the power of the statistical analysis in our funded R01 study; and collectively facilitate the development of new strategies to prevent, delay, and treat ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The primary objective of this proposal is to evaluate the combined effects of delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and cannabidiol (CBD) in alleviating pain and opioid craving among individuals living with both opioid use disorder (OUD) and chronic pain. Results will offer insights into the potential of THC/CBD combinations as a novel treatment for this vulnerable population. Additionally, our approach to developing new therapies for this population aligns with national health priorities, timely informing patients, healthcare professionals, and policy stakeholders about the risks and benefits of cannabinoid-based medicines during the opioid crisis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: This supplement to our R01AG076949 will harmonize and jointly analyze our single nuclei and spatial multiome datasets obtained from neurotypical subjects from adolescence into the 90s and Alzheimer’s Disease brains, with BRAIN Initiative-generated datasets from human brain tissue. We will integrate multiome data from different brain regions involved in AD neuropsychiatric symptoms, including hippocampus, amygdala and prefrontal cortex, to implement analyses on gene regulatory networks that are common to neurons and glial cells across brain regions, and identify those that synergistically regulate functional brain circuits involved in cognitive, emotional, and behavioral changes in AD. This project will provide information on the regulome, the interaction between regulatory components that control the state of expression of genes and their isoforms, their subcellular location, tissue state, development, and pathology, and deliver a developmental and adult cell atlas of cell type diversity, that will be shared via an NIH supported database.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To find vaccines and cures for HIV, scientists who work with non-human primates need to have opportunities to collaborate and learn from other scientists who study HIV in humans. We propose to hold four annual scientific meetings to promote collaboration among HIV researchers conducting both types of research. At the conferences, scientists early in their careers will hear about novel research, learn career development skills, and network with scientists and mentors to accelerate scientific discoveries to cure HIV and to develop HIV vaccines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will evaluate a novel intervention that integrates family- and community-level factors to mitigate the harms of Adverse Childhood Experiences (ACEs) exposure and prevent future ACEs while preventing substance use and overdose. We will test (1) whether this intervention increases referrals and linkages to community resources, increases positive family functioning, and reduces youth and parent substance use and ACEs; and (2) if the integrated intervention produces systems-level change vis-à-vis alignment of services and resources. Our findings will provide insight about the best ways to help disproportionately affected communities prevent substance use, overdose, and ACEs.

PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-CE-22-009 Rigorous Evaluation of Community-Level Substance Use and Overdose Prevention Frameworks that Incorporate ACEs-Related Prevention Strategies

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This project is relevant to public health, and specifically occupational health and safety, because it addresses all three core functions in public health: collection and analysis of data, building partnerships to promote the goal of tracking and using the data to prevent occupational injuries and illnesses. A variety of strategies will be used to ensure that surveillance data are of high quality, that stakeholders and the public are aware and have access to the data, and that the data drive prevention activities.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This year, VHA is implementing a new suicidal ideation (SI screening) and evaluation process, VA Risk-ID. However, prior research has shown that Veterans often do not disclose SI at healthcare visits just prior to suicide, and that Veterans frequently feel uncomfortable disclosing SI during screening. The purpose of this project is to is to develop a greater understanding of the impacts of VA Risk-ID screening processes, primarily from the Veterans’ perspective. Up to 2,000 Veterans nationally will complete surveys that assess their satisfaction with screening, patient-care team interactions, and perceived barriers to care and SI disclosure. Up to approximately 40 Veterans and 40 clinical staff members from primary care and mental health settings will participate in qualitative interviews. We will also examine if perceptions of screening and care team actions at the time of screening are related to subsequent engagement of Veterans in mental health treatment. This project will lay groundwork for the development of new approaches and interventions to improve SI screening.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: The loss of stable housing has a devastating effect on Veterans' health and well-being. Through the Supportive Services for Veteran Families (SSVF) program, Veterans and their families who are experiencing homelessness or who are at risk of becoming homeless can receive of financial support and other services from private non-profit organizations and consumer cooperative grantees with the goal of stabilizing their housing. The impact on Veteran housing, healthcare cost, and health outcomes as well as Veteran satisfaction with the SSVF program is not known. Through this project, we will generate important information about the SSVF program. We will use nationwide data to describe the geographic variation in SSVF services and expenditures throughout the country. We will measure the impact of SSVF on Veteran housing status, healthcare cost and utilization, and mortality. And finally, we will interview SSVF participants to better understand barriers and facilitators to SSVF use and Veteran satisfaction with the program.

PHR: Project Narrative GTPases are proteins that play a key role in the molecular signaling pathways involved in learning and memory, and are misregulated in Alzheimer’s Disease. Here, we propose to investigate the regulation of GTPases in living neurons, in real time. Results from our experiments will provide a greater understanding of the fundamental processes behind learning and memory in the brain, and could lead to the identification of novel therapeutic targets for Alzheimer’s Disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This project will investigate cardiac interoception as a possible biomarker of chronic pain that is maintained by telencephalic as opposed to peripheral mechanisms, where poorer interoceptive behavioral and neural performance would predict non-response to peripherally targeted treatments. Using EEG measures of the Heartbeat-Evoked Potential during interoceptive tasks, this project will establish the clinical relevance of interoception to chronic pain by comparing healthy adults, chronic low back pain patients pre-back surgery, and those who have not received pain relief from back surgery and have been diagnosed with Failed Back Surgery Syndrome and will receive a spinal cord stimulator for pain management. A cross-sectional design across the continuum of care for complex low back pain will enable identification of cardiac interoceptive processes that can predict non-response to peripheral pain treatment.

PHR: This study will focus on examining effects of stress on long-term mood and cognitive outcomes of late-life depression. It will also example the neural underpinnings of these changes using structural and functional brain imaging. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Virus-host interactions and microbial ecology Using E. coli as our model organism, we propose to explore how the DNA-loop extruding condensin motor complex, conserved from bacteria to humans, organizes the genome such that there are widespread contacts between all genomic loci, a finding that has implications for DNA rearrangements, evolution, and cancers. We also propose to understand why, when the bacteria associate in a group and swarm over a surface, they are protected against lethal levels of antibiotics by a subpopulation of dead bacteria. This research has implications for the enhanced drug efflux seen in chemotherapy-resistant cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Migraine is a painful, chronic neurological disorder that represents the second most disabling illness worldwide. This proposal investigates how two mechanisms that contribute to migraine pain, immune cell activation and calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) signaling, may be connected to understand how CGRP receptor antagonist migraine therapies work. The outcomes of these studies may not only reveal a mechanism underlying the therapeutic efficacy of CGRP antagonists but potentially novel targets and mechanisms to improve existing migraine therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to study the role of xenobiotic receptors and drug-metabolizing enzymes in drug-induced toxicological effects, the leading cause of treatment failure. We will develop and characterize novel compounds and determine their mechanisms and effects in preventing drug-induced toxicological effects and increasing intracellular drug accumulation. The results of our proposed studies will illustrate how drugs cause toxicological effects and will identify potential therapeutic approaches to prevent such toxicological effects and improve treatment efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Hepatitis C virus (HCV) infects at least 71 million people worldwide and is a major cause of liver cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma. The proposed research addresses this major public health problem by developing a vaccine to optimize the presentation of conserved broadly neutralizing antibody and T cell epitopes that will lead to long-lasting B and T cell-mediated immunity, the leading contributors to the control of acute HCV infection. A multi-disciplinary approach is proposed to address the challenges of the high variability of this virus, and, if successful, our work will lead to a rationally designed HCV vaccine candidate that will help prevent infection and associated pathologies of HCV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: We recently found that IL-4, a cytokine mostly associated with allergic disease is produced within lung tumor lesions and controls the development and the differentiation of myeloid cells in the bone marrow and lung lesions. In this grant, we will determine the mechanisms controlling IL-4 production in lung lesions and the downstream consequences of IL-4 signaling on bone marrow myelopoiesis and myeloid cell differentiation in lung tissues. We have also started a clinical trial to treat lung cancer patients with combined IL-4R receptor alpha and PD-1 antibody blockade providing a unique opportunity in this grant to measure the impact of IL-4 receptor signaling blockade on human circulating and lung tissue infiltrating myeloid cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We anticipate our work will offer in depth information about molecular mechanisms governing endometrial epithelium homeostasis. Our work will dramatically improve our understanding of endometrial carcinoma pathogenesis and lay the essential foundation for translational studies, such as identification of unique biomarkers and therapeutic targets based on stratification of endometrial carcinoma according to their cell of origin and causative genetic alterations. Our studies will also provide a solid basis for future studies of other critical issues of reproductive biology, such as infertility and endometriosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The past decade in neuroscience has focused on unveiling and characterizing the diversity of neuronal populations, but the developmental mechanisms by which this diversity is generated is relatively unknown. By studying the role of Satb1 levels in the generation of the diverse features of cortical somatostatin interneuron subtypes, this proposal seeks to uncover basic developmental mechanisms that are used to generate neuronal diversity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Many human diseases, such as cancer and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), are linked to mutations and dysfunction of Erythropoietin-producing hepatoma (Eph) receptors. Both the activation mechanism and how mutants contribute to Eph receptor dysregulation are unknown. Here, we will precisely characterize the mechanistic details of Eph receptor function to provide a novel framework for therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This research seeks to develop and test the efficacy and implementation of a multi- level, culturally-tailored self-management, nurse-guided intervention comprising of domiciliary self-monitoring of blood pressure, medication reminders and health education information on hypertension, stroke and unhealthy lifestyles delivered via mobile phones for 12 months among recent Ghanaian stroke survivors encountered at 10 hospitals across all the cadres of healthcare. Specifically, this study will test efficacy of a culturally-refined, and potentially scalable intervention aimed at addressing hypertension, the premier modifiable risk for stroke & other key variables in an under- resourced system in Ghana burdened by suboptimal care & outcomes. A secondary objective is to develop an implementation strategy for routine integration and policy adoption of mHealth as a component of a self-management strategy for post-stroke management of hypertension and other cardiovascular risk factors associated with unhealthy lifestyles in resource-limited settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many alcohol-related health problems (e.g., cirrhosis of the liver) disproportionately affect Latinx Americans, and evidence that Latina women may be disproportionately affected by some alcohol-related health problems (e.g., brain damage) as compared to Latinos is growing, underscoring the public health significance of examining alcohol use among Latinas. To this end, the research proposed in this K01 application will first examine national data to assess patterns of alcohol use and misuse that are the most reflective of the current U.S. Latina population, and next use a sequential mixed methods approach to identify and assess salient and important drinking-related gender role expectations that are endorsed by Latina women. This project seeks to triangulate across distinct and complementary research methods to comprehensively address major gaps in the literature on alcohol use among U.S. Latinas, in an effort to benefit future prevention and treatment programs designed to reduce alcohol-related health disparities in an increasingly at-risk group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is one of the leading causes of cancer related death in part due to its highly metastatic potential. Given the contribution of epigenetic processes to metastatic potential, this proposal seeks to tackle the need for effective therapeutic strategies to treat TNBC by interrogating the pathways linking prometastatic tyrosine kinase signaling and the chromatin landscape.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human papilloma virus (HPV) has been established as a causative agent of cervical cancer, which disproportionally affects women with HIV in resource-limited countries. While HPV-based screen-and-treat approaches are effective in decreasing cervical cancer, they can lead to overtreatment. By leveraging an ongoing cervical cancer prevention study in a disadvantaged community, we propose herein to study the relationship between HPV, lower genital tract commensal bacteria and fungi, and cervical cancer, as a means to improve cancer screening and follow up after treatment in HIV+ and HIV- women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: This project proposes to better understand racial/ethnic and geographic disparities of colorectal cancer outcomes through establishment of a colorectal cancer survivor cohort containing pre- and post-diagnosis built environment exposure histories. The survivor cohort will enable investigation of numerous relationships between race/ethnicity, pre- and post-diagnosis built environment factors, colorectal cancer prognostic indicators (microsatellite instability testing, subsite, grade, stage at diagnosis), and colorectal cancer survival. The existence and magnitudes of these relationships can motivate various actions, such as inclusion of built environment assessments within central cancer registries for enhanced cancer surveillance and motivation of municipal policies that impact built environments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Males and females experience both different outcomes and symptomatology following traumatic brain injury (TBI). It is currently unknown whether injury-induced changes in sex hormones underlie these differences. This study will yield novel mechanistic insight into how high or low estrogen at time of injury modulates initial injury severity and how hormonal dysfunction following TBI affects the development of sex-specific symptomatology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Diabetes affects a large number of people in the US, and increases the risk of chronic complications including cardiovascular disease, blindness, kidney failure, and non-traumatic extremity amputations. Obesity is even more common, and is associated with an increase in the risk of type 2 diabetes as well as cardiovascular disease and multiple additional morbidities. The University of Maryland Baltimore has established this institutional research training program to train the next generation of biomedical scientists to conduct innovative research to address the high degree of high unmet medical need due to diabetes and obesity.
PROJECT_TERMS: Diabetes Mellitus;Metabolic;Obesity
PROJECT_TITLE: Diabetes, Obesity, and Metabolic Complications

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Cancer therapies based on stimulating the patient's immune system represent an important treatment modality, but much remains to be discovered to overcome tumor-induced T cell dysfunction that often limits the long-term tumor control. Our effort has focused to devise the culture conditions that program not only CD4+ T cells but also CD8+ T cells to express unique effector features exhibited by Th1 (or Tc1) and stemness phenotype of Th17 (or Tc17) – in order to generate superior hybrid phenotype anti-tumor T cells. The studies proposed in this application will determine the underlying mechanisms, in terms of epigenetic and metabolic signature of these hybrid T cells, which lead to durable long-term tumor control upon adoptive transfer in pre- clinical mouse models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Proper control of gene expression is fundamentally important for the life and development of all organisms. In all eukaryotes, proteins that regulate transcription, a central step in gene expression, operate within the constraints of a chromatin environment that must be properly managed for gene expression to occur without error. This research program will uncover the functions of the Paf1 complex and other conserved proteins in regulating chromatin structure and transcription --- core cellular processes that, when deregulated, cause a multitude of human health conditions, including cancer and developmental defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: With the increasing public use of complementary and integrative health (CIH) modalities and  disciplines, rigorous research is essential so that CIH therapies can be accurately evaluated, and  members of the public adequately informed. To help meet the need to rigorously evaluate  promising CIH treatments for treating disease and improving health, CIH clinicians need  training in clinical and translational research methods, and conventionally trained researchers  need grounding in CIH therapies and philosophies. The T90/R90 BRIDG program partnership  between the University of Washington and the National University of Natural Medicine is preparing  the next generation of clinical investigators to design and carry out competitive,  rigorous programs of CIH research that are innovative, collaborative, and  multi-disciplinary, thereby generating new knowledge and contributing to improving health  care.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: NARRATIVE Recent work from our group has demonstrated that PRDM10, a member of the PRDM family of transcription factors, is essential in early embryogenesis leading to developmental arrest, and defects in the translation machinery. Given the expression of PRDM10 in the oocyte and its essential function as a maternal-effect gene, here we propose to investigate the function, at the mechanistic level, of PRDM10 at early stages of mammalian development. This work will greatly expand our knowledge on basic developmental processes and on the epigenetic, transcriptional and translational regulation of early embryogenesis, with future implications for reproductive biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The 60 million rural residents of the United States have a lower rate of new cases of cancer per year compared to urban residents but have a higher rate of cancer deaths per year, partly due to the greater difficulty in accessing high-quality cancer treatment in rural areas. As rural patients are less likely to receive care in urban cancer centers with cancer specialists who treat very large numbers of cancer patients, an effective strategy used by the University of Kentucky Markey Cancer Center has been to share their expertise and resources with smaller community hospitals across Kentucky to help improve their quality of care. We propose to study the Kentucky model in order to identify and characterize its core functions (i.e., what made it effective in improving quality of care in community hospitals), adapt it to a new rural setting, and determine its value to the hospitals and impact on cancer care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Increasing evidence from animal studies and humans suggests that exposures to environmental insults during fetal development can promote adverse health outcomes that persist transgenerationally by mechanisms that remain unknown. Mouse prenatal exposure to polybrominated biphenyls (PBBs), a flame retardant that people in rural Michigan were highly exposed to in the 1970s, leads to reproductive phenotypes in mouse descendants that mirror those observed in affected Michigan populations, and results in transgenerationally persistent newly accessible transcription factor (TF) footprints in the mouse sperm chromatin. The proposed project will assess the molecular makeup of transgenerationally persistent PBB-induced TF footprints in sperm, the genomic distribution of these sites in oocytes, and the fate of these epimutations from the gametes to the E6.5 postimplantation embryo, when the germline is specified.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Variation in epidermal pigmentation, one of the most striking features of modern humans, is critical for protection against the harmful effects of ultraviolet radiation and is altered in melanomas and many genetic diseases. The goal of this proposal is to identify genetic variants associated with skin pigmentation in a unique cohort of ethnically diverse Africans with varied skin tones. We will then determine how the sequence variations impact the expression of the associated genes, and identify the molecular and cellular mechanisms by which these genes modulate pigmentation within skin cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: Glutamate, the major excitatory neurotransmitter in the brain, acts at 8 metabotropic glutamate (mGlu) subtypes, expressed in a partially overlapping fashion in distinct brain circuits. Evidence indicates that specific mGlu receptor protomers can heterodimerize and exhibit dramatically different pharmacology when compared to their homomeric counterparts. Our preliminary evidence supports the presence of a heteromer of mGlu7 and mGlu8 in the hippocampus, and we will pursue electrophysiological, genetic, and pharmacological approaches to support this hypothesis, building toward more selective ligand modulation of mGlu receptor biology in the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  This proposal seeks to advance our understanding and treatment of coronary microvascular disease (CMD) through the development of new imaging methods and their use investigating underlying cellular and molecular disease mechanisms (in mouse models), and in the evaluation of pharmacological therapy (in mice and humans). Specifically, we will develop MRI methods to quantify the fatty acid composition of epicardial adipose tissue, use multiparametric MRI applied in a mouse model to elucidate the roles of the fatty acid composition and M1-polarized macrophages in CMD, and, in mice and humans, investigate a role of SGLT2 inhibition for the treatment of CMD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Peripheral nerve injuries (PNIs) account for approximately 3% of trauma cases in the clinic, which translates into an expenditure of approximately 150 billion dollars spent in annual care due to the increased morbidity and decrease in the patient’s quality of life caused by PNIs. An alternative to promote nerve regeneration across an injured nerve resulting in a gap are Acellular Nerve Allografts (ANAs), which are processed allogenic nerves that promote regeneration across short gaps (< 3 cm) but fail to promote regeneration across longer gaps (> 3 cm). The goal of this research is to identify and compare the subpopulations of cells inside short and long ANAs and autografts, identify the cells promoting the inflammatory microenvironment in long ANAs, and reduce inflammation in long ANAs to observe the effects of decreasing inflammation on axonal regeneration and to further develop therapies promoting nerve regeneration across long ANAs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  This proposed research is relevant to woman’s health and overall public health by implementing a specialized breast screening simulation system within radiology residency to study the interpretation and perception skills that occur over time. These findings will aid in developing tools that can avert or correct interpretation errors early in resident education to reduce missed cancers and unnecessary additional imaging and biopsies. Thus, this proposal is relevant to the NIH’s mission to improve the accuracy of breast cancer detection through training and education.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anti-thymocyte globulin (ATG), an immunotherapy, preserves β-cell function in type 1 diabetes (T1D). However, not all treated individuals boast a similar response, necessitating immune characterization of these clinical “responders”. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Caspases control whether cells live or die by apoptosis and are critical factors in neurodegener- ation and other diseases, making a full understanding of their roles and regulation pivotal in pharmaceutical development. Our work over the past two decades has focused on understand- ing caspase regulation at a structural level and has resulted in development of the most selec- tive and potent caspase-6 inhibitor to date. The overall goal of this research project is move one step beyond that success, identifying new exosites in caspases that engage just a subset of caspases substrates will allow us to develop an entirely new class of potential drugs: substrate- selective caspase-directed inhibitors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the importance of sleep for health and the prevalence of sleep disorders, the regulation of sleep remains poorly understood. We will use zebrafish to identify genetic and neuronal mechanisms that mediate homeostatic, circadian and light-dependent regulation of sleep, and to identify genes and mechanisms that underlie human sleep disorders. These studies will likely identify novel targets that may eventually lead to new therapies for sleep disorders.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: How healthcare organizations adapt in response to disruptive change has critical implications for patients. VA recently underwent two unprecedented disruptive changes that fundamentally altered the way in which care is delivered to Veterans. First, expanded community care access under the MISSION Act was implemented in June 2019, representing the biggest policy change in VA care delivery since the "Kizer revolution.” While VA healthcare systems were in the early phases of adapting to MISSION, the COVID-19 pandemic spread rapidly across the world, resulting in a sudden and prolonged ramp-down of elective outpatient care across the entire healthcare system. Our proposed research will leverage this rare combination of events to provide important insights into how large, complex health systems such as VA adapt to manage the health of a population in the face of disruptive forces, the relationship between these adaptation approaches and environmental and organizational characteristics, and their impact on specialty care access and the Veteran experience.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Social accountability interventions are designed to improve the performance of service providers via public monitoring and the use of feedback mechanisms to address deficiencies in service delivery, but little is known about their true impact on contraceptive use, especially in the context of Universal Health Coverage. This study aims to implement and evaluate two social accountability interventions: the community score card and the citizen report card. A three-armed cluster randomized controlled trial will assess the impact of each of these interventions on contraceptive use over a one-year follow-up period; implementation science research, including in-depth interviews with intervention facilitators and healthcare providers, will be used to assess the acceptability, replicability, and sustainability of social accountability interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall objective of the proposed research is to prospectively investigate the effects of two weight-maintaining diets (low glycemic, moderately CHO-restricted diet vs. fat-restricted diet) on reduction of hepatic lipid content, improvement in hepatic insulin sensitivity, and changes in the plasma metabolome in adolescents with NAFLD. We propose a 6 month, scientifically rigorous, RCT using a family-based design with two phases: a 12-week controlled feeding phase followed by a 12-week free-living phase. As such, results from this trial stand to address three key gaps in knowledge: 1) the role of diet composition in the depleting hepatic lipid content in pediatric NAFLD in the absence of weight loss; 2) the role of diet composition on hepatic insulin sensitivity and whether loss of hepatic lipid is associated with improvement in hepatic insulin sensitivity in pediatric NAFLD, and 3) the changes in metabolic pathways linked to diet-induced depletion of hepatic lipid using high resolution, untargeted metabolomics in pediatric NAFLD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative Research training is integral to the future of biomedical advancement and the needs of academic centers to provide an environment that integrates the vision of research to deepen our understanding of biology, stimulate interdisciplinary research teams, and reshape clinical research that in turn accelerates medical discovery and improves health. The present proposal will train medical doctors (MDs) and scientists (PhDs) to study the origins of disorders of glucose metabolism in children (illnesses such as obesity, pre-diabetes, diabetes) using basic or clinical science investigation and applying these to accelerate medical discoveries to improve children's health, prevent development and/or ameliorate severity of metabolic diseases. This approach will undoubtedly improve the health of the US population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: In this project, we will study molecular mechanisms that allow cells to change their shape in order to seek out and destroy pathogens and to take up nutrients and other materials from the extracellular environment. We will specifically investigate the roles of myosins, molecular motor proteins that move along actin filaments, in cell shape changes. In the long term, this work will help us better understand how myosin activity contributes to cell motility, immune response, cell growth, and differentiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stevens-Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis (SJS/TEN) are life threatening, immune-mediated and largely drug-induced diseases that have high acute morbidity and mortality and poorly defined long-term outcomes without defined evidence-based treatment strategies. We will perform the first double-blinded randomized controlled multicenter study to determine the benefit of cyclosporine or etanercept over supportive care for the treatment of SJS/TEN. We will fill critical research gaps necessary to prevent SJS/TEN and improve patient outcomes by: 1) Establishing the most effective management; 2) Identifying genetic and other biological markers to aid prevention, early diagnosis, risk stratification and treatment; and 3) Elucidating cellular and molecular signatures and specific antigens that define the mechanistic basis and population risk of SJS/TEN.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our project entitled `Modelling Longitudinal Reading Comprehension in Adolescence: Protective and Risk Factors' brings together multidisciplinary researchers to advance our understanding of reading comprehension in adolescents and how reading comprehension changes over time. Our overarching goals are to determine the structure of reading comprehension in 11th grade, clarify key predictors of reading comprehension within and across adolescence, and to identify protective and risk factors for good and poor reading comprehension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Non-coding RNA forms the cell’s machinery for protein synthesis and creates regulatory switches that turn genes on and off in response to stress or infection. To function properly, these RNAs must fold into particular three-dimensional shapes soon after they are synthesized. This research will use tools for imaging single molecules and for visualizing RNA structure within the cell to predict how RNA molecules promote healthy growth and why they sometimes cause disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic liver disease is a major global health problem that affects over 1 billion people worldwide and contributes up to 2 million deaths annually. Nearly all the deaths result from progression of liver fibrosis. In this proposal, we aim to characterize the cellular and molecular mechanism(s) underlying liver sinusoidal endothelial cell capillarization, which is a common event in liver fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Whereas some tumor-infiltrating T cells have the ability to directly recognize and kill cancer cells, the majority of infiltrating T cells are not reactive to tumor-expressed antigens, implying that these T cells may have unique functions that are not fully appreciated. Here, we demonstrate that "memory-phenotype" CD8+ T cells reactive to non-mutated endogenous antigens infiltrate mouse prostate tumors and express high levels of the inhibitory receptor PD-1, suggesting a critical role for these cells in the tumor context. This work will define the functional role of memory-phenotype CD8+ T cells in modulating tumor development and anti-tumor immunity, and define the molecular and cellular blueprints of how these cells are generated in the body, thereby revealing new ways to identify and manipulate these cells in human cancer patients.

PHR: Project Narrative Over 6 million people die each year as a result of sepsis. We show that mice lacking the long noncoding RNA, GAPLINC are resistant to LPS induced septic shock. GAPLINC is conserved in humans and mice and here we will determine how GAPLINC contributes to the body’s responses during gram negative induced sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The Hillman Academy at the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center will train 24 underrepresented minority and disadvantaged youth per year from Pittsburgh and surrounding areas by providing authentic cancer research experiences, didactic training from a tailored curriculum, and professional and academic development to prepare them for careers in cancer research and care. The Academy will also impact our local communities through outreach events facilitated by our long-standing community partners. The Hillman Academy will build from the strengths of our institution and past successes in working with emerging scientists from underserved backgrounds to broaden participation and expand diversity in the cancer workforce, which will produce more effective research and help decrease health disparities in cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: ZIKV is a mosquito-borne flavivirus of significant public health concern that has recently emerged in the Americas and has been linked to severe neonatal birth defects, including microcephaly and spontaneous abortion, and Guillain-Barre syndrome in adults. Our proposal seeks to understand how gestational age influences mechanisms of antibody-mediated ZIKV infection of the human placenta. Our studies will likely reveal therapeutic targets and provide insights for development a vaccine to protect against ZIKV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Colorectal adenoma is the precursor for the vast majority of colorectal cancers, the second leading cause of cancer death in the U.S. Gut microbes are pivotal in integrating colorectal cancer-associated lifestyle factors, including Western diet, obesity, physical activity, and aspirin use, with host physiology and metabolism; in turn disturbances in the gut microbiota have been linked to colorectal adenoma and cancer. Understanding the intricate relationship between lifestyle factors, the gut microbiota, and colorectal neoplasia will illuminate significant insights into the etiopathogenesis of colorectal cancer and launch novel research into cancer prevention through gut microbiota-targeted diagnostics and therapeutics.

PHR: Project Narrative: This proposal is founded on an innovative idea that normal human virome can play a beneficial role against cancer development in epithelial cells. The overarching aim of this proposal is to determine the underlying mechanism that governs the interplay of commensal papillomaviruses, epithelial tumors and the immune system. The outcomes of this research will create the path to the application of commensal virome for cancer therapy, which will benefit a large number of individuals in the United States and around the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Acute decompensated heart failure is a major cause of hospitalization and poor clinical outcomes in the U.S. population. Kidney function is a key determinant of management and prognosis in patients with acute decompensated heart failure, but current clinical measures of kidney function are inadequate for use in these patients. The goal of this proposal to identify novel kidney measures that may be used to guide therapy and determine prognosis in patients with acute decompensated heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative We propose a multi-scale framework for treatment allocation, treatment follow-up and treatment monitoring to provide precision medicine for brain tumor patients. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This proposal seeks to identify novel methods raised by identifying RRM2B alternative isoform as a genetic modifier, which rests firmly on information obtained directly from human patients to treat Huntington’s disease, a fatal neurological disorder affecting the lives of more than 100,000 people in the U.S, and advance mechanistic understanding of this debilitating, poorly understood condition. In addition to bringing us closer to a cure for HD, its completion will shed light on the fundamental causes of similar neurological disorders and pioneer innovative therapeutic strategies for other related incurable diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Having shown that calcium-activated chloride channels (CaCCs), which serve important physiological functions including modulation of neuronal signaling, are encoded by TMEM16A and TMEM16B of the TMEM16 family of “transmembrane proteins of unknown function,” we were surprised to find that TMEM16C assembles with the Slack sodium-activated potassium channel in dorsal root ganglion nociceptive neurons to modulate neuronal excitability and pain sensitivity, and TMEM16C function in the brain is important for homeostatic thermoregulation. It was also surprising to find that TMEM16F not only has the dual functions of calcium-activated cation channel and calcium-activated lipid scramblase but is also required for extracellular vesicle formation. This project aims to investigate the molecular and cell biological mechanisms underlying important functions of these TMEM16 family members in neuronal signaling, thermoregulation, and neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Huntington's disease (HD) is a devastating degenerative brain disease for which no disease-modifying treatments are available. The proposed research will broadly focus on understanding early mechanisms that contribute to pathogenesis in HD and develop therapeutic strategies. Broadly the goals of the grant will focus on protein quality control in the presence of mutant Huntingtin expression and how it impacts both DNA damage responses and cell type specific epigenomics and RNA biology in multiple systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The public health relevance of the proposed research is in explicating modifiable factors that contribute to neural vulnerabilities for obesity within developmental and environmental context. By elucidating which factors during childhood and adolescence are most critical to emerging neural vulnerabilities in young adulthood, the proposed study will directly inform the targets and timing of interventions to prevent and treat obesity. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to NIDDK's strategic focus on understanding modifiable factors that contribute to obesity risk and informing interventions to promote healthy weight.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative It is important to understand how specific transcript or protein isoforms contribute to the differentiation of cells to understand human development and disease. But, currently technical challenges exist to infer that information from the single cell RNA-seq data that is sparse and noisy. This project proposes to develop a novel method to infer differential exon usage for specific cell- types from smart-seq based single cell RNA-seq, and validate the method with data generated from alternative protocols.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epithelial-to-Mesenchymal Transition (EMT) is a cancer cell plasticity program linked to metastasis. Based on our novel data this proposal will explore the hypothesis that EMT requires the generation of specific modified ribosomes that translate EMT-driven mRNAs that fuels metastasis. We propose that EMT-specific ribosomes are manufactured by (i) activation of ribosome genes by a Pol I-Snail transcriptional complex and (ii) Snail promotes binding of METTL5 on de novo synthesized rRNA enabling rRNA specific m6A modifications before its incorporation into the ribosome. By forming a complex with METTL3 Snail also directs m6A modifications of selective mRNA enabling recruitment of the non-canonical DAP5/eIF3d/METTL3 translation complex to drive selective m6A marked mRNA translation in the mesenchymal state.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO MED SCIENCES
PHR: Pancreatic cancer presents with a dismal 3% five-year survival rate at stage IV metastatic disease, and the survival rates for breast cancer drops from 90% to 20% when the breast cancers establish distant metastases. Therefore, this proposal will characterize two new metastasis targeted therapeutics in preclinical mouse models and fresh breast and pancreatic cancer patient tissue. This study promises to shift paradigms and impact metastatic cancer cure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative (Relevance) Understanding gut microbiota kidney cross-talk during AKI/recovery is important to improve patient outcomes. The proposed studies in mice and humans will results in the identification of microbial communities and metabolic components involved in this cross-talk to set the stage for novel therapeutics. Focus on renal immunology and short-chain fatty acids/receptors will reveal novel mechanisms by which gut microbiota modulate AKI and recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Spliceosomes are cellular machines responsible for nuclear RNA splicing in eukaryotic cells. This proposal will answer outstanding questions about spliceosome function and its role in regulating gene expression. Since changes in splicing are implicated in a large number of human genetic diseases, our work could lead to new insights into disease pathology and treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma is a poorly understood cancer of immune cells, characterized by accumulation of T lymphocytes (a type of immune cell) in the skin. We suspect that bacterial exposure leads to disease progression and aim to explore the role of skin-associated bacteria in this malignancy. In an effort to gain a better understanding of the pathogenesis of this enigmatic cancer, we propose to survey the type of bacteria associated with the skin of patients, examine the proteins produced by these bacteria and use our novel mouse model of this disease to interrogate precisely how bacterial clinical isolates promote cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cleft lip with or without cleft palate (CL/P) represents the most common craniofacial birth defect and is a burden for the individual and society. We will investigate the cell behaviors, genetic pathways, and regulatory networks underlying facial prominence fusion to identify new genes for prenatal diagnostics and tissue repair of CL/P.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Re le v ance A major barrier in manufacturing insulin -producing islet-like clusters from stem cells is the inability to reproducibly and efficiently generate and sustain mature β cells in culture. Herein, we propose to engineer a physiomimetic pancreatic niche by combining a novel through-pore microwell perfusion plate and human pancreatic dECM produced using our detergent-free decellularization protocol. This platform will allow systematic evaluation of multiple biophysical and biochemical factors on the functional maturation and maintenance of islet-like clusters and will identify the optimal conditions for their reproducible biomanufacturing, which is critical for their application to therapeutic beta cell replacement in type-1 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Sensory afferent feedback plays a critical role in controlling movement, however, we still know very little about the central transmission pathways and how they intersect with spinal motor system. Studies in this proposal will dissect the functional organization of the sensorimotor circuitry in the spinal cord, in order to better understand the control systems that regulate movement and to develop new approaches for treating spinal motor disorders and spinal cord injury, as well as neuropathic pain and chronic itch.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Health care delivery for patients with cancer has become increasingly centralized in regional referral centers over time. This proposal will examine the ways in which centralized cancer care may be both helping and harming patients, particularly those who may be less likely to receive care at regional referral centers (e.g., racial/ethnic minorities, low-income individuals, and rural residents). The results not only will provide new insight into how recent shifts in cancer delivery may have widened disparities in cancer outcomes, but also will provide strategies to improve outcomes for millions of cancer patients through improvements in the regional organization of cancer care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Sights, smells and tastes associated with foods can be powerful drivers of food seeking behavior and consumption, even in the absence of hunger or physiologic need. We believe this phenomenon is a significant contributor to obesity, but the brain circuits and mechanisms underlying the phenomenon are poorly understood. This project uses cutting-edge neuroscience techniques to identify the neural circuits and mechanisms whereby sensory cues can drive consumption in the absence of hunger, and therefore, has the potential to identify new therapeutic targets for the treatment of obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Antibody-Secreting Cells (ASC), including Plasma Cells, are the cells responsible for the production of protective antibodies in response to infections and vaccinations. However, rogue ASC that produce undesired antibodies against human tissues are also responsible for myriad antibody-mediated diseases including autoimmune diseases, allergy and transplant rejection. In this project, we will study the different types of ASC that provide protection and induce disease to understand their nature and regulatory programs. The information gained will improve our ability to design safer and more effective treatments multiple antibody-mediated diseases and modulatory strategies to optimize protective vaccine responses.

PHR: Narrative Many studies have documented the presence of toxic chemicals in existing artificial turf fields and playgrounds. New materials are increasingly being used as alternatives in playing surfaces, but safety information is still lacking. Using a citizen science approach, we will characterize the chemicals in new materials and comprehensively evaluate the exposure of children to chemicals and heat under real-use conditions. The project campaign will communicate research findings among partnering organizations and communities at large.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE THIRD COAST CFAR OVERALL RESEARCH The Third Coast Center for AIDS Research has leveraged complementary strengths of Northwestern University, the University of Chicago, and partnering community organizations across Chicago to build a comprehensive infrastructure for multi-disciplinary, collaborative HIV research. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The design of small molecule drug candidates with well-defined three-dimensional properties has been directly correlated to their clinical success. This proposal describes a novel application of asymmetric ion pairing catalysis to the synthesis of compounds bearing carbon and silicon stereogenic centers that are largely inaccessible using existing methods. As the construction of complex small molecules is a limiting factor in drug discovery, the proposed research will assist scientists in the development of molecular tools and therapeutics to understand and treat human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to examine the magnitude of change in parents’ and children’s risk for cardiovascular disease (CVD) from before the COVID-19 pandemic to 18-24 months after pandemic onset (“post-pandemic time point”), and from the post-pandemic time point to a follow-up period 18 months later. The proposed project is uniquely positioned to examine important theoretical and practical public health questions, including: To what extent did the COVID-19 pandemic increase CVD risk among a sample of parents and their children?; which of the multiple stressors associated with this crisis (e.g., financial, mental health, social isolation, and family conflict) are most highly linked to increases in CVD risk in this sample?; and can universal prevention programming enhance parent and child resilience and mitigate crisis-related increases in CVD risk? This research will also inform future efforts to minimize the negative collateral health impacts of infectious disease epidemics – as well as other social, economic, and climate related crises – and will help program developers more precisely target salient mechanisms as well as families at highest risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The NLRP3 inflammasome is an important mediator of inflammation in a variety of metabolic and infectious diseases but the mechanisms of its activation remain unresolved. Mitochondrial association is an important feature of NLRP3 activation but how these bioenergetic organelles regulate NLRP3 activation is an intricate puzzle. This proposal will thoroughly dissect the role of mitochondrial structures and their associated proteins in NLRP3 inflammasome activation and identify how this key organelle controls NLRP3 crosstalk with the RNA virus-sensing RLR signalling pathway, thereby yielding critical mechanistic insights into how mitochondria regulate not only inflammasome activity but also other innate sensing pathways converging on the mitochondria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: HUGO W. MOSER RES INST KENNEDY KRIEGER
PHR: Movement abilities affect a child’s physical, social and emotional well-being, as well as their educational success—all of which can last a lifetime. We will use home-based video games and in-person tests to develop a detailed timeline of when different movement learning mechanisms mature and how this process is affected by damage to the brain. This will provide the comprehensive understanding required to generate tailored therapeutic training strategies targeted to age, developmental maturity, gender and disease state.

PROJECT_TITLE: Development of Mechanisms Underlying Human Motor Learning

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This research program will provide key insights into the types of contextual supports and psychological mechanisms that are needed to encourage persistence in biomedical science careers, especially for women, underrepresented minorities, and first-generation college students, across three unique university contexts. An understanding of how and why contextual supports are effective for promoting entry into biomedical careers will aid in the design of effective experiences and help decision-makers better allocate resources toward evidence-based strategies to recruit and retain women, minorities, and first-generation college students into STEM fields. By following participants throughout college and for more than 5 years after college graduation, this research will provide key insights into factors supporting sustained persistence in the biomedical careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This research project will help define new factors that contribute to variability in therapeutic warfarin dose requirements. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it has the potential to improve genotype-guided warfarin dosing algorithms and reduce adverse drug events associated with warfarin therapy. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH mission that pertains to reducing the burden of adverse drug reactions in cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Heart attacks and strokes remain the leading cause of death in the United States and despite current guidelines on aggressive cholesterol treatment and blood pressure management, some people continue to suffer cardiovascular problems leading to a poor quality of life and high cost of health care. The proposed study will investigate the effects of inflammation on bleeding inside of plaques, called intraplaque hemorrhage, one of the important plaque risk features that can cause heart attacks and strokes. The study will help us to better understand the problem with intraplaque hemorrhage and discover potential new treatments that can further reduce heart attacks and strokes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE An estimated 205,000 children die of TB-related causes each year, the vast majority of whom do not receive treatment due to missed opportunities to diagnose and successfully treat, as current tests do not sensitively detect all forms of pediatric TB disease. We have reported that our novel serum-based TB assay (developed with the support of our previous R01 funding) can detect all forms of pediatric TB with high sensitivity and specificity, and now propose to extend our assay approach to generate a multiplex assay that can also identify individuals progressing from latent TB to active TB disease, as well as rapidly evaluate a patient’s response to TB therapy to determine treatment efficacy. To do so, we will continue identifying new biomarkers secreted by TB bacilli that identify each stage of TB in a well-established non-human primate model of HIV and TB, and determine the best biomarker combinations and thresholds to distinguish these stages their response to anti-TB treatment, and subsequently evaluate the performance of a multiplex assay develop from these parameters in multi-center cohorts of young children with or without HIV, latent TB infection or active TB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We have developed a clinically relevant rejuvenating RNA cocktail that upon transfection elongates telomeres, improves the growth and functionality of cultured human adult cells. Using this rejuvenating cocktail, we propose to develop new cellular technologies that would (1) improve the expansion of human primary somatic cells by promoting their rejuvenation and (2) allow for precise gene editing directly in primary cell lines followed by a clonal expansion of these genetically modified cells to sufficient numbers for transplantation. The successful accomplishment of the proposal will open new opportunities for developing somatic cell gene therapies for a variety of human diseases, including connective tissue disease, hematologic diseases and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Concussion or mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI) is a leading cause of disability in older adults, military service personnel, and athletes. Repeated concussions may lead to increased risk for dementia, but biomarkers which are both diagnostic of mTBI and prognostic for AD have not been identified. The current project is focused on identifying targets for drug development and novel biomarkers for this condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite much effort to identify mechanisms underlying amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and frontotemporal lobar degeneration dementia (FTLD or FTD), effective treatments remain elusive. Motoneuron (MN) excitability dysfunction is tightly linked to disease pathology, yet to date, excitability dysregulation has not been examined in the recent rNLS8 mouse model, which recapitulates pathologic TDP43 inclusions seen in MNs in >90% of ALS patients and in FTD patients. This proposal is relevant to public health because it will examine excitability dysregulation in this highly relevant model of ALS/FTD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This competing continuation of a 15-year predoctoral training program is focused on research training for the design and evaluation of cognitive interventions for older adults. The program has three substantive emphases: (a) behavioral interventions (e.g., cognitive training, exercise, mindfulness) for unimpaired older adults; (b) multi-component compensatory interventions for persons with cognitive impairment; (c) neuromodulation/stimulation interventions. We propose to continue this successful program with six pre- doctoral slots a year, reserved for students beyond the first year of doctoral study.
PROJECT_TERMS: Aging;Alzheimer's Disease;Cognition;Nonpharmacologic Therapy;Research Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Research Training in Non-Pharmacological Interventions for Cognition in Aging, MCI, and Alzheimer's Disease

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Improvements in outcomes with current chemotherapy and surgery treatment approaches for patients with osteosarcoma have plateaued over the past three decades, necessitating new treatment paradigms. Our proposal aims to develop a novel therapy for osteosarcoma using Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)-guided cryotherapy in conjunction with intratumoral injection of an immune adjuvant in the clinically relevant animal model of spontaneously occurring osteosarcoma in client-owned dogs with the intent of priming an adaptive immune response capable of delaying or preventing the occurrence of metastatic disease. A successful immunotherapy approach for the treatment of osteosarcoma would provide significant benefit to patients for whom current treatments result in substantial short-term and long-term side effects from toxic chemotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with cancer may use cannabis to manage symptoms, such as pain, and potentially reduce opioid use. Cannabis’ status as a Schedule 1 substance has made it difficult to study the role of cannabis use on pain and opioid use among cancer patients. This study will generate new knowledge to inform clinical practice and guidelines related to cannabis use in cancer pain and symptom management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The opioid crisis has caused a national decline in average U.S. life-expectancy necessitating a declaration of a federal public health emergency. Opioid use disorder is a chronic condition best managed with long-term use of medications, but even with medication use, compared to those suffering from other substance use disorders, individuals suffering from opioid use disorder continue to suffer from additional deficits. Recovery Community Centers (RCCs) are designed to help individuals with opioid use disorder overcome such deficits, but while promising, systematic research is sorely lacking. This project engages multiple relevant stakeholders at all levels to create a national research infrastructure to facilitate the scientific investigation into the clinical and public health utility and cost-effectiveness of RCCs for individuals suffering from opioid use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE After decades of effort, one malaria vaccine has been approved by the World Health Organization, but improved malaria vaccines with higher efficacy are needed. Antibody responses to infections in infants and young children living in Sub-Saharan Africa who experience multiple malaria infections may hold the key to understanding how immunity to malaria develops. This research will investigate antibody responses against multiple malaria proteins after early childhood malaria infection with the goal of identifying proteins that could be developed into malaria vaccines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Approaches that could combine standard chemotherapy agents with targeted immunotherapy for the treatment of cancer have the potential for high clinical impact, but it has been difficult to identify synergistic combinations. The current proposal identifies Bruton’s Tyroseine Kinase (BTK), expressed in specialized host antigen- presenting cells, as a previously unsuspected pathway that suppresses immune responses following chemotherapy. BTK-inhibitor drugs are already in use for other indications, so re-purposing these agents as part of a multi-modal chemo-immunotherapy approach is highly translatable to the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Relevance: The skin is the largest organ in the body, and its primary purpose is to prevent the loss of body fluids and to protect against biological, physical, and chemical insults by maintaining a functional epithelial barrier. Compromised skin barrier due to burns occurs in more than 1 million US citizens annually and is the seventh cause of injury death in the US alone. Our research focuses on developing new therapies that combine biomaterials capable of delivering homogeneous cell suspension of epithelial cells lifted from small amounts of donor tissues to burn sites.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Spontaneous pain and poor sleep quality are the two main complaints from patients with traumatic neuropathic pain. Our preliminary results strongly support the hypothesis that sleep fragmentation after nerve injury is linked to spontaneous pain. In this project we will test formally if sleep fragmentation after nerve injury is specifically caused by ectopic activation of injured sensory neurons which in turn activate nociceptive ascending pathways. These results will test if sleep fragmentation after nerve injury can be used as a surrogate for measuring neuropathic spontaneous pain in mice. Validating a reliable outcome measure for spontaneous pain is essential to perform mechanistic studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Advances in neonatal medicine have improved survival, particularly in infants born extremely premature, <30 weeks gestational age. However, the impact of extreme prematurity on heart and lung structure and function has not been rigorously assessed in young children. In this proposal, we will conduct the most in depth evaluation of changes in the heart and lung structure and function related to extreme preterm birth ever performed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Type 1 diabetes (T1D) is an autoimmune disease leading to major complications despite advancements in glucose monitoring and exogenous insulin. Adoptive cell therapy with polyclonal Tregs has been proven to be safe but lacks efficacy in preventing T1D progression after disease onset. This research seeks to improve adoptive Treg cell therapy by providing islet antigen specificity and homing to the germinal centers of pancreatic lymph nodes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Persistent HCV is a common cause of liver failure and death. There was limited effect of the only vaccine tested for prevention of HCV infection. We will define the successful immune responses observed in people infected with HCV many times who never become persistently infected and compare them to those seen in the only human vaccine efficacy trial and in vaccine models in order to design a more effective HCV vaccine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Racial/ethnic disparities in atopic dermatitis (AD) outcomes among adults are understudied and remain unaddressed. This proposal aims to use a novel transdisciplinary approach to understand the contributions of individual behavioral, social, and environmental determinants of AD to racial/ethnic differences in AD outcomes among a socioeconomically disadvantaged, urban, adult population in North Philadelphia, Pennsylvania that is vulnerable to a high burden of skin disease. Knowledge gained from this project will inform the development and implementation of future interventions to eliminate racial/ethnic disparities in AD outcomes among adults who are living in similarly underserved, urban neighborhoods in the U.S.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For at least 1 in 3 young adults with an anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction, the injury and surgery are pivotal life events that lead to chronic pain, diminished long-term quality of life, and an increased risk for osteoarthritis. This study will determine how longitudinal changes in physical activity and walking biomechanics throughout the first year after surgery relate to poor symptomatic or osteoarthritis-related structural outcomes over the same period. This study is significant because it will provide foundational evidence for which patients and which visits to target with existing evidence-based interventions to mitigate the risk of poor outcomes following anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The omentum plays an important role in peritoneal immunity but also is the major site of ovarian cancer metastasis. Prophylactic removal of the omentum in ovarian cancer patients who do not present with overt metastasis has been contentious, and there are currently no effective strategies that prevent metastasis of occult circulating cancer cells to the omentum when this site is preserved. By using a preclinical model that recapitulates omental metastasis, this study will evaluate the ability of agents that inhibit a neutrophil response called neutrophil extracellular traps to boost anti-tumor immunity in the omentum and prevent omental metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Due to the significant increase in the US elderly population and growing trend of younger cohorts having worse health outcomes, examining biological aging (e.g., epigenetic profiles) across the life course is a public health priority. There is substantial evidence linking social connectedness and aging-related morbidities, yet we know little about whether biological aging underlies the protective effects of social networks, or the strong mortality risk associated with social isolation. The proposed study will examine whether structural social network characteristics (i.e., stable social signatures) can slow or disrupt biological aging associated with DNA methylation, thereby promoting resilience to stress exposures, reducing healthcare costs, and increasing healthy years of life.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Drugs are currently prescribed to groups of patients (e.g., children) with fixed dosing in each population for the duration of therapy, which results in wide variations in blood drug concentrations between patients and within a patient over time. Our group is uniquely qualified to conduct translational work that combines sophis- ticated machine learning with traditional population drug models and novel laboratory infection models. We will use these capabilities and the VPICU dataset of >20,000 critically ill children to deliver software tools that predict changes in renal function in these patients, that predict changes in drug kinetics over time in patients using vancomycin as an example, and that quantify the degree of within-patient variability in vancomycin con- centrations that is relevant to laboratory kill in our hollow fiber infection model of Staphylococcus aureus, a common and serious bacterial infection in hospitalized children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative DNA double strand breaks are a dangerous, yet common form of DNA damage and their repair is essential for cell survival. In humans, two major pathways rejoin broken chromosomes and the improper utilization of these pathways is associated with the onset of cancer. Using advanced single-molecule imaging in a physiological cell-free extract, this proposal will elucidate the mechanisms by which DNA double strand break repair pathways are selected.

PHR: We are applying to continue a successful interdisciplinary pre-doctoral training program focused on Environmental Epidemiology in Community Settings within the Department of Environmental Health at the Boston University School of Public Health. We will recruit four pre-doctoral trainees each year for a steady state census of twelve trainees. This proposal describes a specific training regimen that is designed to prepare pre-doctoral students to use the most sophisticated methods available to advance the state of knowledge and develop new methods in community-oriented environmental epidemiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite many anti-hypertensive drugs, up to 90% of chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients exhibit uncontrolled hypertension, which accelerates kidney damage and kidney function decline. In fact, CKD is the strongest predictor of treatment-resistant hypertension, and worse, an alarming 96% of those with early, asymptomatic CKD are unaware of their condition. The proposed work will identify novel strategies to combat the detrimental cycle of hypertension and kidney damage in early and late stages, and is thus highly relevant to public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To establish a productive infection, HIV-1 must enter the cell, copy its RNA genome into DNA, enter the nucleus, and integrate into the host cell DNA. Studies in this Project will uncover currently unknown aspects of these different processes in molecular detail, providing a foundation for the identification and development of new anti-viral targets. We will also characterize how the potent new HIV-1 inhibitor, lenacapavir, binds the viral capsid and inhibits nuclear entry.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Patients with lysosomal storage disorders can be treated with enzyme replacement therapies (ERT) but many patients already have signs of the disease by the time they start treatment and may develop immune reactions to ERT. We are conducting a phase 1 clinical trial of in utero ERT in fetuses with several types of lysosomal storage disorders to evaluate the safety and efficacy of this approach in improving long-term outcomes including neurologic and cardiac function, mobility, and growth; we will also analyze pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of in utero ERT and the ability to induce tolerance to the missing enzyme.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although the virus eventually wins in the absence of sustained antiretroviral treatment (ART), humans have an array of innate immune responses that help to limit HIV-1 replication, particularly during viral transmission and when the virus rebounds upon removal of ART. These observations imply that it might be possible to devise effective new antiviral therapeutic strategies if we better understood how innate immune factors sense and inhibit viral replication, and can learn better how to manipulate and harness these responses. The primary goal of this Project is therefore to gain such insights into innate immune factors that act at early steps in the HIV life cycle.
