IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative To make immunotherapy for cancer more efficient, we aim to target macrophages within the tumor microenvironment and recruit them to fight the tumor. Using antibodies against specific pattern recognition receptors on macrophages we can increase efficacy of T cell mediated targeting and provide better therapeutic benefits also against so far unresponsive tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: Bridge2AI Center The promise of using Big Data for precision medicine, drug discovery, and a host of other challenges has remained elusive; barriers to effectively leveraging Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) are both serious and varied — occurring at every stage of the development lifecycle from data to standards to tools and algorithms. Our Bridge to AI Center will engage the scientific community across this lifecycle in order to ensure that data are ethically sourced, machine-understandable, and easily integrated with other data. These advances will catalyze AI solutions to complex biomedical challenges.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nearly half of American adults have hypertension, a known risk factor for severe complications that can reduce life quality or lead to death. We need to understand more of the mechanisms of hypertension to develop new anti-hypertensive therapies. The proposed research will address this serious public health concern by providing fundamental knowledge on the role of prostaglandin EP4 receptors in the development of hypertension.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Puberty is a unique developmental process in which the body develops secondary sexual characteristics and becomes capable of reproduction, yet the mechanisms leading to pubertal onset are not well understood and an important area of scientific exploration. This proposal aims to understand how an important gene, Makorin Ring Finger Protein 3 (MKRN3), which has been associated with early puberty in children, may also be involved in causing delayed puberty, as preliminary studies show that increased expression of Mkrn3 leads to delayed puberty in female mice. The goal of this career development award is to gain further expertise in understanding puberty regulation using both innovative mouse models and human studies, to ultimately improve child health through improving diagnosis and management of disorders of puberty.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Echo planar fMRI is widely used at our institution, and others, for functional localization for patients who are candidates for surgical resection to treat epilepsy. This project will develop and assess accurate, real-time, self-navigated slice-by-slice motion monitoring, retrospective and prospective motion correction strategies to substantially improve the quality of fMRI. These new sophisticated technological advances will enable the reduction of the duration of fMRI scans, and ensure the collection of sufficient high quality data free of motion artifact which in turn will enable improved localization of function. These advances will ultimately increase the quality and utility, and decrease the cost, of fMRI for planning the effective use of surgery to cure epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our promising pilot data suggests that donor vaccination could substitute for 100 days of Prevymis prophylaxis to control CMV reactivation and disease. We will investigate vaccination of the stem cell donor as an alternative to the stem cell recipient to better control early CMV reactivation events or those associated with steroid use in the recently completed Phase 2 randomized clinical trial. To extend the value of Triplex vaccination to the higher risk haploidentical stem cell transplant setting where there can be as many as three HLA mismatches, we will conduct a Phase 1b/2 trial in which we hypothesize that both early and late reactivation will be controlled by vaccination of both the donor and the recipient with minimal or no Prevymis prophylaxis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to use novel patient-reported outcomes to improve the clinical care of patients with urinary symptoms that are secondary to benign prostatic hyperplasia. The use of new patient-centered tools will improve evaluation and clinical decision-making by including symptoms not commonly measured in men, such as urinary incontinence, and allow for more frequent assessment of lower urinary tract symptoms and other non-urologic symptoms through remote surveillance. Through the use of care-coordination checklists, clinicians can be more responsive to post-treatment symptom changes, resulting in reduced bother from lower urinary tract symptoms and higher quality of life in patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Patients with end-stage renal disease on hemodialysis have frequent hospitalizations and poor survival, due in large part to cardiovascular disease: namely, atherosclerotic disease, heart failure, and sudden cardiac death. We currently lack models to effectively risk stratify these patients, and we have a poor understanding of the biology underlying their high rates of cardiovascular morbidity and mortality. We intend to apply a novel test, capable of measuring ~5000 proteins in a tiny blood sample, to over 1000 patients with end-stage renal disease on hemodialysis; we aim to discover proteins that would help us pinpoint cardiovascular risk and understand the disturbances in the biology in these patients, with the goal to carry forward novel proteins as potential targets of new treatments for this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mast cells are localized to the brain and meninges in the central nervous system, and are responsible for initiating immunological defense against invading pathogens and detecting brain injury. This proposal seeks to study the role of a mouse mast cell specific receptor, Mrgprb2, in the regulation of neuroinflammation after ischemic stroke. The proposed research will lead to a more comprehensive understanding of mast cell responses after cerebral ischemia, and potentially validate Mrgprb2 as a novel target in the treatment of ischemic stroke.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The overall goal of this NRSA-T32 program is to foster the development of pediatric investigators who are prepared to pursue independent academic careers examining important issues relevant to health and disease in children. We accomplish this goal by training outstanding pediatric fellows to become successful physician- scientists, addressing questions of fundamental importance to health and disease in children. Candidates for our program are enrolled in our subspecialty fellowship programs and are identified through national searches for talented pediatricians with signficant potential for success as physician-scientists, with particular emphasis on recruitment of women, underrepresented minorities, individuals with disabilities, and other disadvantaged individuals .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opiate addiction is a chronic, relapsing disorder that affects millions of individuals worldwide; however, few effective treatment options for opioid abuse and addiction exist. Here, employing a unique combination of behavioral, molecular, epigenomic and viral gene therapy-based approaches, we will assess the impact of chronic heroin self-administration in rats (a well characterized rodent model of volitional opioid use/abuse) on molecular abnormalities in brain – namely aberrant synaptic protein dopaminylation states – that result in heightened propensities for relapse following periods of drug withdrawal. This proposal thus aims to transformatively integrate expertise from multiple disciplines (e.g., molecular neuroscience, epigenomics and behavioral pharmacology) to fully characterize novel synaptic to nuclear signaling cascades contributing to persistent opioid addiction, with the hopes that such information will aid in the future development of more effective therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Urinary stone disease (USD), is extremely common, affecting up to 12% of individuals in developed countries, is associated with signiﬁcant morbidity including pain, hospitalizations, surgical procedures, and lost work time, and is often recurrent and can lead to progressive chronic kidney disease (CKD). There is strong evidence for a genetic component to both rare and common causes of USD. This proposed project will examine in great detail candidate genes implicated in USD to increase understanding of the underlying pathogenic events, suggest new treatments, and allow assembly of homogeneous cohorts of affected individuals for future study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative This study addresses the immune deficiency in virally suppressed HIV infected young and older individuals that can lead to failure of an effective response to influenza vaccination. It also provides insight into the functioning of a specialized peripheral blood CD4 T cell subset (pTfh for peripheral T follicular helper cell) that can be of critical importance in facilitating Ab responses to influenza and other vaccines. Understanding the underlying defects in pTfh and other cells that impair the antibody secretion by B cells in the context of aging and HIV infection may lead to development of scientific strategies to optimize vaccine responses to improve the immune responses in HIV infected elderly population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The proposed study will interrogate interactions between oligoclonal mouse microbiota and intestinal immune system in old mice to understand how aging immune system, and in particular repertoire of CD4 cells, respond to age-related changes in commensal flora. We will also explore the possible rejuvenating effect of administration of Akkermansia muciniphila and derived from the bacteria antigens on the diversity and function of regulatory T cells in old mice. This research is expected to have an important positive impact on our understanding how to help develop better probiotics that can enhance CD4 regulatory cells in frail individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative A fundamental question in systems neuroscience is how populations of neurons encode sensory input and sup- port perceptual decision making. Here we mathematically model the high-dimensional structure of population responses, identify features that are invariant from trial to trial, and link them to behavioral performance in a discrimation task. This work addresses the Brain Initiative mission to deepen our understanding of cortical func- tion to ultimately improve our treatment of disorders of the central nervous system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic inflammatory diseases of the lung are a major public health and economic concern worldwide and there is an urgent need for deeper understanding of the cellular and biochemical mechanisms that regulate lung inflammation in order to uncover novel targets to improve therapeutic treatments. An immune population called Group 2 innate lymphoid cells (ILC2s) have been shown to be critical in driving lung inflammation through production of type 2 cytokines; however, the molecular mechanisms controlling their functional capacity remain poorly understood. The focus of this R01 proposal is to investigate the role of mitochondrial morphology dynamics in regulating ILC2 function, metabolic programming, and lung inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Modular polyketide synthases are enzymatic assembly lines that aid in the production of human medicines ranging from antibiotics to anticancer agents. In order to engineer them to help in the development and production of new medicines, more must be learned about how they are organized and how they operate. We are making these discoveries with the help of powerful electron microscopes and model assembly lines produced in our lab.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Together, tobacco and alcohol kill more than half a million people in the United States every year, making co- addiction to these substances the leading cause of preventable death. We propose a contingency management (CM) paradigm based on point-of-care urine tests that measure ethyl glucuronide. Theoretically framed within the Addiction Neuroclinical Assessment with hypothesized mechanisms in core domains (i.e., incentive salience, negative emotionality and cognitive function), and proceeding from a sound and innovative scientific premise, we will, for the first time, target smoking and alcohol use by implementing an evidence-based behavioral treatment (CM) for alcohol among participants who have initiated the frontline pharmacotherapy (varenicline) for smoking cessation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This project investigates the ability of two advanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) methods to quantify the impact of a drug treatment on the progression of Alzheimer's disease pathology. These methods, referred to as diffusion MRI and resting-state functional MRI, are sensitive to brain tissue microstructure and brain functional connectivity, respectively. The ultimate goal of this project is to establish better tools for supporting studies aimed at finding improved therapies as well as research into the causes of Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 2 diabetes and obesity are increasing rapidly across the U.S. and worldwide. Lipokines, or signaling lipids, released from adipose tissue have recently been identified as molecules that can mediate metabolic effects, but due to their short half-life their therapeutic potential has not been thoroughly explored. The goal of this proposal is to use a new, non-viral gene delivery platform technology with high translational potential, tissue nanotransfection (TNT), and deliver the genes coding for the enzymes that make the bioactive oxylipin, 12,13-diHOME, resulting in a sustained systemic increase of 12,13-diHOME in circulation, reduced adiposity, and improved metabolic health

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative: This project is focused on the roles of the transcription factors TFEB and TFE3, which are key regulators of lysosomal biogenesis, on the pathogenesis and therapy of renal disease in tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC). Our central hypothesis, based on novel preliminary data, is that TFEB and TFE3 drive cell proliferation via a lysosome-dependent mechanism in TSC. We anticipate both scientific and clinical impact, since TFEB/TFE3- and/or lysosome-focused therapies could inhibit the progression of renal disease in TSC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The prefrontal cortex (PFC), insula, and ventral striatum are prime candidate regions when it comes to understanding the neurobiology of binge eating disorder (BED). However, there is a significant gap when it comes to understanding potential micro-architectural changes (i.e., at the level of synaptic density) that may underpin cortical-insular-striatal abnormalities and related clinical measures. If funded, the proposed study would be the first in vivo examination of synaptic density among unmedicated adults with BED (in comparison to healthy controls), using breakthrough 11C-UCB-J PET methodology to assess synaptic density in the brains of living people.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: SUMMARY Long-lived reservoirs of HIV-infected cells remain a challenge to study because they make up a very small fraction of immune cells, can be located in difficult to sample anatomic sites (e.g., the central nervous system [CNS]), and are generally less well studied in individuals who undergo treatment interruption. We aim at understanding the expansion dynamics, tissue distribution, and rebound predictors of HIV-1 persistence using several unique clinical cohorts and innovative methods to provide critical insight to mechanisms of HIV-1 persistence and strategies for HIV-1 eradication. These results will define high-resolution, multidimensional views of the virus and immune mechanisms that underlie HIV persistence across the stages and tissues of HIV-1 infection. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will use a Sequential Multiple Assignment Randomized Trial (SMART) design to examine and identify alternative combinations of peer-mediated approaches, such as the addition of a speech-generating device, to improve social communication of preschool-age children with ASD and limited or no spoken language. This research is of high relevance to public health for children with ASD and complex communication needs as the focus is on increasing knowledge on how to adapt and tailor peer-mediated social interventions to ensure optimal outcomes for those who do not make anticipated progress. These interventions can be adopted by community-based, early service providers to impact peer-related social competence that is vital to the growth of multiple aspects of child development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Influenza persists globally, causing nearly one billion cases and hundreds of thousands of deaths annually. While temperate regions of the world experience regular seasonal patterns of influenza with high predictability, tropical regions, many of which are resource-scarce, do not have well-established evidence of regular cycles of influenza epidemics. The proposed research seeks to use mathematical models to determine whether tropical regions experience regular cycles of influenza epidemics or irregular epidemics, using surveillance data from Vietnam as a case study, which can allow tropical nations to understand the predictability, or lack thereof, of influenza.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative: We will establish novel genetic and metabolomic technology for newborn screening (NBS) from dried blood spots, and apply machine learning to reduce false-positive screens and delayed diagnosis of true-positive cases. Early detection and confirmation of inborn errors of metabolism that can present in the first weeks of life is critical, specifically when screening in diverse multiethnic populations where we have less understanding of the biochemical genetic and clinical phenotypes. We will work with local hospitals and the NBS program to establish clinical and translational validity to this new project, which will contribute to maintaining parental trust in public NBS.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: The human microbiome is key for proper development and for maintaining our health. However, many widely administered drugs, that are not prescribed as antibiotics, can inadvertently inhibit the growth of some of its bacterial members. We will identify what are the processes inside bacterial cells that are targeted by these drugs, and we will find the mutations that may help bacteria resist this inhibition that is detrimental to our health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The oncogene cyclin E is amplified/overexpressed in ~20% of high grade serous ovarian cancers, but no current treatment strategies exist to target this patient population. In this study, we will quantitatively assess acetyl-CoA metabolism and subsequent histone hyperacetylation that enhances homologous recombination-mediated DNA repair and evaluate inhibition of this axis with emerging standard-of-care PARP inhibitor treatment. The results will have a direct impact on the development of novel therapeutic strategies to obtain a therapeutic response in high grade serous ovarian cancer patients with high cyclin E expression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The present proposal targets unique mechanisms that contribute to the molecular and genetic and epigenetic basis of high blood pressure (BP) and kidney injury and dysfunction. It is anticipated that men and women can have distinct differences in progression of hypertensive kidney diseases; the proposed studies will utilize genetically modified mouse models to provide new insights in developing the therapeutic strategies to appropriately target the treatment and prevention of high BP and kidney injury and disorders. The podocyte and nephron tubule injury and kidney dysfunction can lead to chronic kidney disease and complications that are directly relevant to the mission of NIH/NIDDK.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Atherosclerotic cardiovascular diseases remain the leading causes of death in the United States. The high saturated fat, cholesterol, and refined carbohydrate intakes associated with a Western-type diet is considered a major cause of atherosclerosis. However, we discovered that high protein intake could also be involved in the adverse vascular health effects of a Western-type diet. In this proposal, we will discern the mechanism of how dietary protein impacts immune cells that are involved in forming atherosclerotic plaques. This work has important public health implications, because it may lead to new dietary guidelines. Currently, high protein intake is considered healthy and has become popular. Our work also has the potential to uncover new avenues for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cell-cell fusion is fundamental to the conception, development and physiology of multicellular organisms. It is involved in processes as diverse as fertilization, myogenesis, bone remodeling, placental development, immune response and tumor metastasis. Thus understanding the mechanisms of cell-cell fusion is not only important for fundamental biology, but may also provide basis for its manipulation in therapeutic settings for human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The functional interpretation of genetic variation in diseases faces critical roadblocks, due to the lack of scalable methods to assess the significance of candidate variants experimentally, while accounting for genomic context. This proposal introduces a morphological profiling method, that is able to rapidly identify disease-associated phenotypes in patient cells and offers a cost-efficient and unbiased way to determine the significance of putative pathogenic variants at scale. If successful, this proposal will establish cellular profiling of patient cells as a powerful platform to advance genomic and translational medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Mammalian DNA methyltransferases are essential for establishing and maintaining DNA methylation patterns during development. Aberrant DNA methylation patterns are associated with numerous human diseases, including cancer and neurological disorders. This proposal will lead to a better understanding of the regulatory mechanisms of mammalian DNA methylation and epigenetics, and ultimately benefit the development of new strategies for the therapeutic intervention of many human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: STICHTING RADBOUD UNIVERSITAIR MEDISCH CENTRUM I.O.
PHR: Project Narrative Tuberculous meningitis (TBM) is the most lethal manifestation of TB, is associated with permanent neurological disability among many survivors, and is now one of the commonest causes of meningitis worldwide. Considering that TB drug concentrations are the key intermediary link between administered doses and disease outcome, HARVEST-PK provides a unique opportunity to improve understanding of achieved drug exposures, key predictors of exposure, and optimal target concentrations in TBM. This project aims to enable better medical care for persons with meningitis, by enabling exposure optimized drug therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For this proposal, we engage experts in clinical (MPI Feldstein Ewing) and quantitative (Co-I Bryan) evaluations of HIV/STI and syndemic risk reduction with youth, advanced longitudinal models of youth alcohol and cannabis use and their intersection with HIV/STI risk (MPI: Chung), and longitudinal mixed-effects machine learning and patient-provider relationships (Co-I Yang, Consultant Choudhary). Together, we aim to collaboratively harmonize our 6 sizable HIV/STI and syndemic behavioral intervention studies to interrogate these data using cutting-edge analytic methods and robust machine learning model testing. This innovative approach will unearth crucial relations in youth HIV/STI and syndemic intervention response, in a diverse sample of youth at very high risk for HIV (M = 17 years of age, range 13-24 at baseline; 43% female; 21% SGM; 54% Hispanic; 9% African American; 7% Native American/Alaska Native). These data are crucial to informing next step HIV/STI and syndemic intervention programming, as they will illuminate what works (and does not) in this age group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project utilizes synthetic chemistry, microbiology, genetics, and proteomic methods to develop novel compounds to combat bacteria. This research will develop narrow-spectrum and antivirulence tool compounds as potential therapeutic agents that either inhibit growth or biofilm processes within pathogenic bacteria. The compounds are derived from natural product scaffolds isolated from regions rich in chemical diversity and bioactivity, which will undoubtedly shed light on the chemical underpinnings of these complex microbial communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative Inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate receptors (IP3Rs) are calcium channels that are ubiquitously expressed in all eukaryotic cells and play important roles in regulation of a broad range of physiological processes in humans. Dysfunctions in IP3Rs are associated to numerous human diseases, including neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer’s, Parkinson’s and Huntington’s diseases, stroke, and cancer, and therefore these channels are important drug targets. The proposed studies aim to understand the detailed structure and fundamental mechanisms governing IP3R channel function and to elucidate how they are perturbed in disease states that will aid in search for novel therapies to treat disorders related with abnormal cell calcium homeostasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Autophagy plays a role in normal physiological processes including fetal development and innate immunity, and its dysfunction has been implicated in a wide range of human diseases including cancer, some types of neurodegeneration, bacterial and viral infections, gastrointestinal disorders, diabetes and heart disease. It may be possible to modulate autophagy for therapeutic purposes, turning it on and off at precise times, and in specific tissues, to prevent or ameliorate the onset of diseases or their symptoms. To use autophagy in this manner, however, will require a complete understanding of its mechanism and regulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Nuclear morphology is often deregulated in cancer cells, many cancers are diagnosed and staged based on graded increases in nuclear size, and little is known about the causes or effects of nuclear morphology changes in cancer. We will identify regulators of nuclear size and shape, elucidate mechanisms of nuclear morphology regulation, and use this information to investigate how nuclear morphology affects embryonic development, cell differentiation, and carcinogenesis, shedding light on novel approaches and targets for the diagnosis and treatment of cancer. Aberrant nuclear morphology in cancer might be necessary for cell homeostasis and viability, so therapeutic manipulation of nuclear morphology could provide a means to selectively target and kill only affected cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Comparative genomics and genetic engineering in model organisms are powerful tools that can be used to understand the biology underlying human traits, diversity and disease. We will study how essential proteins can evolve given the constraints imposed by the often multifaceted functions they perform, including for example, the important drug-target Na+,K+-ATPase, which has repeatedly evolved insensitivity to steroid inhibitors across diverse animals. Our work will yield insights into how new proteins associated with neurological and physiological disorders in humans, like Na+,K+-ATPase, can evolve new functions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Statement: Obesity and Alzheimer’s disease (AD) devastate millions of Americans and place a tremendous burden on our healthcare system. Necessities of modern society put immense pressure on human physiology by forcing incongruity between endogenous circadian rhythms and environmental cycles, which worsens a range of health issues including obesity associated maladies and AD. This project aims to identify the neuronal circuits and the molecular players that control circadian rhythms and therefore identify therapeutic targets to circumvent these pathologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Many types of cancer cell utilize a special outer layer – called a glycocalyx – to help stick to and invade soft tissues such as the brain, lung, and breast. This proposal seeks to 1) use DNA-based nanosensors to elucidate how the glycocalyx helps cancer cells become invasive, and 2) develop screening methods for early detection of glycocalyx-coated cancer cells in the bloodstream. The outcome of this research may offer new design principles for targeted cancer therapy, as well as technologies for early detection of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This impactful proposal will enable multiplexed detection of both PD-L1 and CD8 immunomarkers simultaneously in vivo and monitor response to immunotherapies through a cutting-edge multimodal nanoprobe, immunoactive gold nanoparticles (IGNs). IGNs, labeled with antibodies, Raman reporters, and radiotracers, seamlessly integrates depth-resolved whole-body imaging of positron emission tomography (PET) with high spatiotemporal resolution and multiplexing of surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) allowing to track the dynamic changes in both immunomarkers during treatment directly in vivo. IGNs is a generalizable platform and our strategy can be mapped onto multiple disease models where PD-L1 and CD8 markers play a key role transforming the therapeutic outcome for responders, and accelerate clinical decisions for nonresponders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will determine the mechanisms by which preoperative exercise therapy suppresses surgical stress-induced colorectal liver metastasis. These studies will provide a more comprehensive understanding of the role of preoperative exercise therapy in ameliorating surgical stress-induced pro-tumorigenic inflammatory responses and sustaining an anti-tumor immune microenvironment. The anticipated mechanisms will be valuable to identifying potential pharmaceutical targets in hepatic CRC metastasis and provide the intellectual framework for devising new exercise therapies that are mechanism-based and effective in improving surgical outcomes of cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This research program aims to develop and apply linear and multidimensional spectroscopy in combination with residue-selective labeling of proteins with frequency-resolved vibrational probes to advance understanding of functional roles of conformational ensembles and protein dynamics in important biological processes, ranging from signaling to drug metabolism and tumor suppression. Understanding how conformational heterogeneity and dynamics contribute in these selected systems will not only elucidate fundamental aspects of biology, but also generate testable models for how they contribute to biological processes that underlie human health generally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Efficient intracellular delivery of nucleic acids, proteins and drugs is a critical step in diverse scenarios ranging from cell-based therapy and gene editing to regenerative medicine and fundamental biology. This proposal will develop a novel NanoEngineered Surface Technology Microfluidics to quantitatively study cell membrane disruption and recovery response and create a next generation intracellular drug delivery system with precise dose control, low toxicity, low cost, high efficiency and high throughput.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Viruses called bacteriophages kill bacteria through fascinating and diverse mechanisms making them timely therapeutic candidates to combat antibiotic resistant pathogens. Here, I study a phage that potently kills Pseudomonas aeruginosa using bizarre and previously unobserved mechanisms to hide from anti-phage immune enzymes like CRISPR-Cas. This multidisciplinary project will unveil the molecular details of this remarkable immune evasion mechanism to guide identification and development of better phage therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Summary: Failure to efficiently repair DNA damage plays a role in the progression of many different diseases, including neurodegenerative diseases such as Ataxia Telangiectasia. Our goal is to understand how R-loops, three stranded structures comprised of an RNA strand complimented with a DNA strand and another free-floating DNA strand, are regulated in the DNA damage response pathway through an ATM-METTL3-m6A axis. Such studies may provide novel targets for therapeutic treatments for Ataxia Telangiectasia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Food allergy is a serious public health concern affecting 8% of children in the US. The goal of this proposal is to further investigate racial/ethnic differences and disparities in food allergy outcomes between Black, White, and Latinx children in FORWARD, a prospective longitudinal cohort, and identify factors that contribute to differences in developing and outgrowing food allergies, managing food allergies during middle childhood and adolescence, and variations in phenotypes and endotypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed studies will provide a comprehensive, mechanistic understanding of how peripheral sensory nerves regulate progenitor cell fate, aberrant wound healing and heterotopic ossification (HO). Facilitated by the use of conditional deletion animals and near-clinical therapies, these results will provide novel insights into key regulatory elements of the HO program, while serving to identify new targets for therapeutic intervention of this currently untreatable process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Adolescence is typically when initial signs of psychosis develop, and social impairment is often one the first of these signs to emerge; however, little is known about specific factors that contribute to social impairment. The proposed study seeks to use cutting-edge ambulatory technology to examine physiologic threat dysregulation (TD) and its relation to social impairment and psychotic-like experiences in adolescence, and whether these relationships are partially mediated by aberrant cognitive and affective responses to threat. These results should develop ambulatory technology as a novel “early warning system” for assessing psychosis, thus contributing to reduced disability and early mortality associated with psychosis and other psychopathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We will use falsifiable forecasting, mathematical modeling and statistical methods to help world-health partner organizations identify when and where Trachoma (a blinding disease) will be eliminated as a public health problem worldwide. This includes modeling approaches for resolving persistent infection in hot spot areas, and improving surveillance to detect any resurgence of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vocal learners, like humans and songbirds, require experience with adults of their species while they are young to learn and ultimately imitate their vocalizations, but how this early experience is encoded and interacts with circuits for vocal production is not well understood. The essential song learning and motor production nucleus, HVC, contains non-overlapping cell types that project to different regions. This research will elucidate if there are cell-type-specific genetic and synaptic changes in HVC that underly sensory learning and how learning from social experience interacts with motor circuits in HVC.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Antimicrobial-resistant and healthcare-associated pathogens are a global health threat. The goals of antimicrobial stewardship are to minimize unnecessary and inappropriate antimicrobial use as a means to combat antimicrobial resistance. Previously, we implemented a Videoconference Antimicrobial Stewardship Team (VAST) at 2 VA Medical Centers (VAMCs), using telehealth to connect clinicians at a rural VAMC to a geographically distant infectious disease expert Both VASTs successfully decreased overall antibiotic use in acute and long-term care units. This project will expand the VAST approach to other VAMCs and test the hypothesis that quarterly reports that quantify facility-level antibiotic use will enhance the efficacy of VASTs to support antimicrobial stewardship. This work will directly increase access to antimicrobial stewardship consultation at rural VA facilities, which are often underserved by infectious disease expertise.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Despite efforts to implement universal HIV testing in the United States, late HIV diagnosis—diagnosis at an advanced stage of infection—remains highly prevalent, contributes to increased morbidity and mortality among people with HIV as well as transmission of infection, and is a priority to address to end the HIV epidemic. The proposed research will provide a fuller understanding of 1) the current demographic, behavioral, and psychosocial health disparities associated with late diagnosis using a large public health surveillance dataset; 2) the longitudinal HIV clinical outcomes (e.g. viremia and CD4 count) post-late diagnosis; 3) the clinical significance of different definitions of late diagnosis on longitudinal outcomes and factors associated with different definitions; 4) reasons for late diagnosis and lack of engagement in healthcare not captured in routine surveillance and survey data, and 5) the influence of alcohol specifically on the late diagnosis and HIV outcomes. The results of this research can inform impactful interventions and policies to reduce late diagnosis by identifying health disparities and multidimensional barriers to and missed opportunities for HIV testing and engagement in healthcare.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Our focus on the kappa opioid system is justified by the growing appreciation of the therapeutic potential of selective kappa agonists and antagonists in the treatment of pain, affective disorders, and addiction. We will apply structural and pharmacological approaches to comprehensively characterize the structural basis that governs KOR ligand selectivity, receptor activation and signaling. The long-term goal is to leverage these data to generate new chemical matter for therapeutic applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project narrative:  α7 nicotinic acetylcholine receptors are widely expressed and play a role in numerous human diseases including Alzheimer’s disease, schizophrenia, and inflammation. Despite promising preclinical evidence for α7 targeted molecules, clinical trials have been largely unsuccessful. This proposal aims to answer key questions surrounding α7 structure-function, improve our understanding of α7 pharmacology, and provide a basis for future rational drug design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative RNA localization and modification play a key role in cellular functions including development, immune response, and motility, and are frequently dysregulated in disease. This research will develop a suite of technologies to study and control localization and editing, as well as the interplay between these pro- cesses, which will aid in the development of new diagnostic and therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this project our goal is to use computer modeling and medical imaging to better understand why some people experience stroke. We will create a new infrastructure that reads in a patient’s MRI scans then outputs an accurate and custom-tailored measurement of stroke risk based on simulations of structure, electrical activity, contraction, and blood flow in their heart. Through this work we hope to better understand links between disease- related changes to the heart (i.e., fibrosis), abnormal heart rhythms, and clotting events that lead to stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the United States, poor adherence accounts for up to 70% of all medication-related hospital admissions and an estimated 50-80% of pediatric patients are non-adherent. Behavioral economics (BE) suggests that small “nudges” or reminders can produce and sustain behavior change, thus with mobile health (mHealth) access nearly ubiquitous and an estimated 3.7 billion mHealth application downloads in 2017 alone,13 technology has great potential to improve adherence. Nurses could easily deliver these universal mHealth intervention approaches as a frontline approach to family education and care, addressing the critical need to improve adherence and clinical outcomes among children to ultimately prevent morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Delirium is terrifying, costs an estimated $164 billion annually in the US alone and is associated with a greater risk of death, institutionalization, and Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD); ADRD, in turn, affects more than 5 million Americans and exacts an incalculable human toll. Sleep-wake disturbance (SWD) is an observable, measurable, and potentially modifiable aspect of both delirium and ADRD. It may offer novel opportunities to prevent and treat delirium as well as to mitigate the development of subsequent ADRD. This project aims to examine home-based measures of SWD as physiological markers for delirium risk in aortic valve surgery patients while serving as a vehicle for career development for the PI to become an independent physician-scientist in delirium pathophysiology and its relation to ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cell-cell communication through signaling controls cell behavior from embryonic development to adult tissue renewal and is fundamental to health. This proposal will improve our understanding of the complex signaling inputs that instruct human pluripotent stem cells to differentiate into specific cell types. The resulting data will provide new insight into how cells interpret combinatorial signals over time, which can be exploited to improve a wide range of disease treatments and aid efforts toward stem cell-based therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Projective Narrative Diabetes and obesity increase the toxic lipid accumulation in the heart and increase the risk of developing heart failure. The mechanisms through which lipids cause heart injury is unclear, and thus there are no available therapies targeting this process. I propose to study the role of lysosomal biogenesis and function in cardiac lipid overload, with the goal of developing therapies to improve this condition and prevent heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Alcohol-induced “blackouts” – or memory loss for events that occur while one is drinking – are prevalent among young adults and reliable predictors of alcohol-related harm. The proposed study will test the feasibility and initial efficacy of a dynamic personalized feedback intervention in reducing heavy drinking and alcohol- related consequences among young adults (18-30y) with a history of blackout. Findings will inform future research and clinical practice by documenting the utility of the intervention in reducing the health, social, and economic burden of alcohol use among young adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE This project uses biophysical measurements to determine the mechanisms of molecular machines that are used in gene editing applications or are targets of antibacterial drugs. Using newly developed single-molecule approaches, CRISPR- Cas9 and related enzymes will be observed in real time as they unwind DNA, search for matches with a guide RNA molecule, and selectively cleave their DNA substrate. The same approaches will be applied to determine how DNA gyrase enzymes from pathogenetic bacteria harness ATP hydrolysis to wind up the genome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic stress is a prominent factor in the development of aberrant reward-seeking behavior in disorders like substance use disorder which affect an alarming proportion of the global population, yet we lack a basic understanding of the innate neurocircuitry that are disrupted by stress exposure which subsequently alters motivation to seek rewards. We have recently identified a nociceptin neuropeptide and receptor circuit that suppresses reward-seeking and increases aversion, central components of approach-avoidance behavior. The goal of this proposal is to investigate how the endogenous ventral tegmental area nociceptin opioid circuit is engaged by diverse forms of stress exposure to regulate the expression of approach-avoidance behaviors, opening new avenues for exploring nociceptin receptors as a viable therapeutic target for reward-related disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Helminth infections and allergic disorders pose a significant public health burden. The common factor in these illnesses is that they both induce type 2 immunity, the hallmark of which is the development of CD4+ helper type 2 cells. In this proposal, we aim to better understand the metabolic regulation of these cells as such knowledge may facilitate the design of therapeutic approaches for inhibiting or potentiating type 2 immunity.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Our project entitled “Impacts of structural racism on racial and ethnic disparities in perinatal health” will leverage established partnerships among Baylor College of Medicine, UTHealth McGovern Medical School, and Texas Southern University through our NIMHD/NIEHS/NICHD P50 Center of Excellence on Environmental Health Disparities Research to conduct a retrospective cohort study using electronic health records from major labor and delivery hospitals serving women in the third largest county in the nation (Harris County, Texas) that includes the city of Houston. We will assess the independent effects of structural racism across five domains on racial/ethnic disparities in both maternal morbidity (hypertension in pregnancy and gestational diabetes) and adverse pregnancy outcomes (low birth weight and preterm birth), explore whether combined exposures to multiple domains of structural racism enhance disparities, and apply machine learning methods to identify the key structural racism predictors of adverse perinatal health outcomes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV-1 associated neuroinflammation and neurotoxicity lead to cognitive impairments (HIV-1-associated neurocognitive disorders or HAND) even in those under suppressive antiretroviral therapy (ART). IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Encoding the amplitude modulations (AMs) in sound is a critical task of the auditory system, as AMs are important features of complex sounds such as human speech and other species-specific vocalizations. The inferior colliculus (IC) has been implicated as a site of transformation from temporal to rate coding of AM stimuli, however, the cellular and circuit mechanisms underlying how this process occurs remains largely unknown. The proposed research will determine how NMDA receptors facilitate the transformation from temporal to rate coding in IC neurons, providing fundamental insights into encoding mechanisms for AM stimuli that can be used to facilitate better interventions for those with hearing loss.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infertility affects nearly 13% of reproductive-age couples, yet the mechanistic basis of infertility remains unclear, hindering targeted therapies. The Massachusetts General Hospital Harvard Center for Reproductive Medicine will perform cutting edge genomic, phenomic, and transcriptomic studies in humans with both rare and common forms of infertility to identify causal biologic drivers and pathways that will inform clinical care and treatment of infertility and improve overall health. The Center will serve as a vibrant hub for training future reproductive biologists and will provide outreach and community engagement with patients, families, and clinicians to reduce the physical and psychological burden of infertility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol use during pregnancy is very common and can result in the development of Fetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorder in offspring, which is often associated with impaired social function. The proposed experiments are designed to explore possible mechanisms that are disrupted by prenatal alcohol exposure and contribute to deficits in social behavior. Identification of mechanisms that are dysregulated by prenatal alcohol exposure may help inform target treatment development for individuals with prenatal alcohol exposure induced social impairments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: JMJD3 (KDM6B) – a gene that produces a protein that modifies the structure and function of the human genome – has roles central to both normal brain development and a wide range of neurological diseases. Understanding how JMJD3 functions in brain development will provide important basic insights into major neurodevelopmental disorders and how the adult brain can continue to generate new neurons throughout life from a population of neural stem cells. Furthermore, results obtained will help inform the development and use of JMJD3 inhibitors, which have shown promise as a drug treatment for pediatric brain tumors.

PHR: Project Narrative: In this R01 grant application, we will study immunometabolism in the context of tick-borne diseases. Tick-borne illnesses are the most prevalent arthropod-borne maladies in the United States and Europe and affect public and veterinary health. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Superoxide is a threat to all forms of life and its toxicity is harnessed by the immune system to combat infection. Superoxide dismutases are metal utilizing enzymes that enable us and invading microbes to cope with superoxide, yet we do not know the molecular or environmental factors that dictate the metal utilized by these enzymes. The proposed studies will address this unanswered question, providing insight into how both humans and invading pathogens overcome the universal threat of superoxide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Bacterial intercellular communication is required to induce adaptive traits and community behaviors such as competence, biofilm formation, and virulence gene expression. A range of Gram positive bacteria, including highly pathogenic species, use small cyclic peptides to signal to nearby bacterial cells. We will investigate newly uncovered mechanics of cyclic peptide maturation in Staphylococcus aureus with goals of improving our understanding of bacterial cell-cell communication and promoting development of novel therapeutics.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS, UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF
PHR: According to Clinical Practice Guidelines, psychosocial interventions for pain are recommended as first-line treatments to manage pain, yet barriers to care, including patient beliefs, interfere with initiation of such treatments. The proposed study uses a cognitive-behavioral intervention to target beliefs to increase the initiation and engagement in psychosocial interventions for pain among Veterans using prescription opioids. This study will test the effects of this evidence-based intervention on increasing treatment initiation of and retention to psychosocial interventions for pain and the subsequent effects on pain and substance use outcomes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Women Veterans using VA health care are increasingly diverse in terms of race/ethnicity, sexual orientation, and gender identity, and have complex medical and mental health care needs, and a high prevalence of sexual trauma. These characteristics and experiences shape their experiences of VA health care and their outcomes. We propose to develop the first patient-reported experiences measure for VA women’s health care (WV_PREM) to inform patient-centered quality improvement. We will use semi-structured interviews, Veteran focus groups, and psychometric validation in a cohort of women Veteran VA health care users. Our innovative approach will intentionally incorporate the voices and experiences of those with marginalized identities. We will work with our operational partners to implement WV_PREM for surveillance of VA health care quality and equity.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: WM S. MIDDLETON MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSP
PHR: Nearly 8 in 10 Veterans meet criteria for overweight/obesity. Three evidence-based treatment options are available within VA (behavioral weight management [MOVE!], obesity medications, and bariatric surgery). However, all treatments are significantly underutilized. This study will evaluate the effectiveness of a novel intervention designed to increase obesity treatment initiation and subsequently weight loss within VA. The intervention, Teaching Obesity Treatment Options to Adult Learners (TOTAL), involves an educational video and multiple motivational sessions delivered via telemedicine. If effective, TOTAL could be implemented throughout VA without requiring significant resources and could be integrated into the existing VA behavioral weight management program, MOVE!, which is present at nearly every VA medical center.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Veterans face serious risks when taking long-term opioid therapy for chronic pain and there is evidence that this treatment approach is not effective. The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) and other agencies have recommended carefully reducing or discontinuing long-term opioid therapy when benefits of therapy no longer outweigh risks. However, reducing long-term opioid therapy can present risks to patients including withdrawal symptoms, worsened mental health conditions, substance use, opioid overdose, and death. Early research evidence suggests that some holistic treatments such as yoga, exercise, and chiropractic care can improve pain and facilitate reductions in opioid therapy. In this study, guided by advisory groups made up of VA leaders and Veterans with chronic pain, we will test whether Veterans who have used such holistic treatments tended to have better outcomes when reducing their opioid treatment. Results from this research will be used to suggest changes in how long-term opioid therapy is reduced.

PHR: NARRATIVE At present, methods to predict pregnancy-induced and cytokine-induced changes in transporter-mediated drug disposition are not available. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Differentiated cells of the epidermis form the essential barrier of the skin. This work examines the role of differentiated cells of the skin in controlling their stem cell parents. Understanding the regulation of skin stem cell behavior is essential to allow us to manipulate these cells for regenerative/wound-healing therapies and/or for the treatment of diseases that result from stem cell dysregulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE – OVERALL Adolescence is a critical time of development where teens increase their identification with peers, establish their independence and autonomy, and some begin experimenting with substances, including vaping products. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Impulsivity and compulsivity are core behavioral issues that can exacerbate a wide variety of psychiatric issues, including depression, ADHD, traumatic brain injury and substance abuse. The goals of this project are to identify physiological markers that can be used (instead of or in addition to behavior), as a tool to test for drugs that can ameliorate impulsivity. Thus, we will identify physiological markers of brain function relevant to impulsivity across several tasks; measure whether pharmacologic agents targeting dopamine and serotonin modulate task-relevant oscillations; and finally directly manipulate serotonin and dopamine and measure impacts on physiology and behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE – PROJECT 1: Vaping Behavior, the Emergence of Dependence, and Well-being The use of electronic cigarettes may lead to important health consequences for adolescents including the development of dependence and a reduced capacity to flourish across the different aspects of an adolescent’s life. Project 1 will assess how vaping behavior and the symptoms of vaping dependence emerge during high school and how these changes are related to adolescent well-being. Project 1 will also evaluate how adolescents perceive the relationship between vaping and their daily lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE We have developed a novel strategy to dedifferentiate fibroblasts into induced myogenic progenitors (iMPCs) using a combination of MyoD expression and treatment with small molecules. To our knowledge, iMPCs represent the first expandable and engraftable myogenic cell population with stem/progenitor cell characteristics derived directly from unrelated, differentiated cells. We expect that iMPCs will provide a powerful system to study the mechanisms of cell fate change including muscle development and disease. In three complementary aims, we propose to (i) define the molecular and functional similarity of primitive (Pax7+) iMPC subsets to satellite cells in vivo, (ii) dissect the genetic and epigenetic mechanisms underlying this dedifferentiation process, and (iii) investigate the potential utility of iMPCs to study and treat dystrophy, including an effort to generate human iMPCs. !

PHR: Microembolization occurs during coronary stenting, when debris from a coronary narrowing in the vessel wall blocks the microvessels downstream, causing heart damage. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The O2 activating iron enzymes that are the focus of this research are widely utilized in Nature and key in human health.1–3 They are involved in antibiotic,4–9 collagen,10 neurotransmitter11,12 and natural product biosynthesis,13–15 bioremediation,16–18 DNA19–25 and hypoxia regulation,26 drug metabolism and toxicity27 and are related to a wide range of diseases.28–36 Understanding their mechanisms on a molecular level enables control of these reactions, enzyme engineering for biotech applications, the rational design of new drugs, and provides the insights required to develop new chemistries and catalysts.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Innovative approaches are needed to improve uptake of evidence-based interventions and to de-implement ineffective and harmful practices, such as inappropriate antimicrobial use. The long-term goal of this implementation study is to improve the health and longevity of Veterans undergoing cardiac device procedures by leveraging a novel clinical informatics tool applied to the VA electronic medical record with the capabilities to track rates of compliance with clinical guidelines and post-procedural outcomes to promote adoption of best antimicrobial use practices. Lessons learned about how a multi-faceted implementation strategy including automated audit and feedback can be used to improve uptake of guidelines and de-implementation of ineffective practices will advance the field of implementation science and improve outcomes for cardiac device recipients.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: WM S. MIDDLETON MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSP
PHR: Clostridium difficile is a major pathogen causing serious healthcare-associated diarrheal illness in veterans. Prevention of healthcare facility-onset of C. difficile infection (CDI) is essential. A significant proportion of CDI is caused by transmission of the pathogen from asymptomatic colonized patients. However, data on interventions focusing on colonized patients are sparse. Universal gloving by healthcare workers for all patient contacts may reduce CDI. The work proposed will examine the effectiveness of universal gloving versus standard of care in a cluster randomized trial for preventing C. difficile acquisition and CDI, the results of which will inform infection control measures for CDI prevention throughout the VA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: The goal of the proposed research is to identify the circuits for learning to hear in noise. This is achieved by using a combination of electrophysiological, imaging, optogenetic and behavioral approaches in the mouse system. Verbal communication and auditory navigation require rapid reorganization of the representation of the acoustic environment under varying behavioral demands. Patients with hearing deficits, age-related hearing loss and communication deficits, as well as patients with hearing aids and cochlear implants exhibit extreme difficulty hearing in complex acoustic environments, and especially transitioning between different environments with varying noise levels. Identifying which neuronal circuits underlie the ability to modify the representation of complex acoustic scenes, is a prerequisite for development of new and improvement of existing therapies for these large groups of patients. In particular, these important insights into the function of feedback circuits in auditory processing will inform future design of hearing aids and cochlear implants by configuring their outputs for optimal stimulation of these circuits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE – PROJECT 3: Lung Health and Inflammation The health risks associated with vaping are not yet well understood. Project 3 will evaluate the effects of vaping in adolescence on early changes in respiratory health, oxidative stress and inflammation. Knowledge gained from Project 3 will inform on the potential of vaping to alter respiratory health as early as adolescence, and the potential for vaping to modify pathways known to contribute to tobacco-related lung disease and extrapulmonary diseases, including atherosclerosis and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Public Health Relevance Given the limited effectiveness of informational and psychosocial interventions in addressing the continuing major health risks associated with maternal heavy alcohol consumption and binge drinking during pregnancy, there is growing interest in new approaches, such as nutritional interventions, that may be more effective in reducing the risks associated with fetal alcohol spectrum disorders (FASD). Extensive data from animal studies and preliminary data from our R21 maternal choline supplementation feasibility study suggest that daily supplementation with a high dose of the nutrient choline initiated early in pregnancy can be effective in mitigating a range of adverse effects on growth and neurobehavioral function seen in FASD. The proposed fully-powered, phase II, double blind, randomized placebo-controlled trial is designed to confirm these findings, thereby providing the basis for implementation of this promising, highly innovative intervention in clinical settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE  Previous research, including that of our team, shows that a significant portion of those regularly using opioids—particularly filling opioids at community pharmacies—also are involved in the co-use of alcohol. This study proposes to adapt a previously developed intervention for opioid medication misuse; test its acceptability, feasibility, and preliminary efficacy; and identify barriers and facilitators to large-scale research and system-level implementation. Results of this study will directly inform a fully-powered subsequent multisite trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Ovarian cancer (OC) is the most lethal gynecologic malignancy, with 90% of women diagnosed receiving chemotherapy. Timely and successful completion of chemotherapy is critical as delayed or reduced chemotherapy dosage for OC is associated with decreased survival, yet chemotherapy dose delays and dose reductions are common (~30% to 50% of OC patients), with the primary reason for dose delays and reductions being chemotoxicity. We propose to conduct a multi-site randomized trial of an 18-week medical nutrition therapy and exercise intervention vs attention control in a racially and ethnically diverse sample of 200 women newly diagnosed with OC (stage I-IV) and initiating curative intent chemotherapy to assess the effect of the intervention on chemotherapy completion rates, patient-reported chemotoxicities, and body composition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Telomeres are nucleoprotein structures that protect the ends of chromosomes from replicative erosion, nucleolytic degradation and from the DNA damage signaling and repair pathways. While telomeres are considered to be heterochromatic, their exact chromatin composition remains debated and, more importantly, whether heterochromatin is important for telomere functions and regulation remains elusive. Using a novel approach, we will modulate histone modifications specifically at telomeres and determine the function of heterochromatin marks in the biology of telomeres.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Underrepresented minorities in medicine (URM) physicians are critical providers for our increasingly diverse nation and underserved populations, yet little is known about how fairly their performance is assessed during their key formative years in Graduate Medical Education. Using a national integrated dataset, we will examine whether discriminatory biases are observed for URM resident physicians as measured by standardized national assessments in U.S.-accredited family medicine and internal medicine residency programs. Results will inform national policies to promote minority health and to improve the training needs for URM physicians who serve as a critical workforce to address health disparities that persist in the U.S.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Cholera, a severe dehydrating diarrheal disease caused by Vibrio cholerae, remains a global threat to public health. In this project, we will study the processes that control the pathogen’s intestinal colonization, the host intestinal responses to experimental cholera, and the factors that control the pathogen’s transmissibility. This work will yield new understanding of the interactions between V. cholerae and the host and has important implications for creation of new cholera therapeutics and vaccines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The Public Health Relevance of the MARC Program at Temple University is related to its significant impact on preparing underrepresented and disadvantaged students to successfully complete the undergraduate degree and pursue a PhD or MD/PhD in biomedical sciences, ultimately increasing the diversity of PhD-level scientists that bring diverse perspectives to investigate health issues to reduce health disparities. The MARC program is a university-wide collaboration between College of Science and Technology and Research Centers at Lewis Katz School of Medicine at Temple University, which will enhance mentored-research projects and science- based activities. As a result, MARC scholars who are more aware of and engaged in health disparities research in underserved minority communities, will be more likely to pursue a long-term career in the field of biomedical sciences.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A persistent issues in the treatment of cocaine addiction is the reinstatement of cocaine seeking even after the long period of withdrawal. IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Historically, many Veterans had to travel long distances to VA Medical Centers to be evaluated for and undergo kidney or liver transplantation. The ongoing implementation of the MISSION Act will allow a large number of Veterans to undergo kidney or liver transplantation and receive post-transplant care in non-VA transplant centers closer to their homes. Our study will examine how the MISSION Act has changed where Veterans receive transplant care (i.e., within VA or Community Care) and whether the site of transplant care affects how long they wait for a transplant, their likelihood of receiving an organ, and their health following transplantation. We will also explore the perceptions of Veteran patients, VA providers and administrators on the facilitators and barriers to Veterans’ use of VA for transplant care. Information gained from this study will help the VA adapt its transplant program to enhance Veterans’ treatment experiences and enable Veterans to choose the site of transplant care that optimizes their long-term health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Relevance Neurons in the developing auditory system that will process similar frequencies of sound exhibit highly correlated activity before hearing onset; however, the role of this activity in shaping the development of brain circuits involved in hearing is not yet known. This proposal will test the hypothesis that correlated neuronal and astrocyte activity induces functional refinement of sound processing circuits to enable acoustic discrimination. This knowledge may provide insight into how disruptions of cochlear function early in life lead to hearing impairment and identify new strategies to improve the performance of cochlear implants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Vaccines are efficient measures to prevent infections, a critical problem is that aging-associated changes in the immune system lead to decreased immunogenicity and clinical efficacy of most currently used vaccines; novel strategies that increase vaccination efficacy and specifically target the aged immune system are imperative. An essential facet of these efforts is the use of combinatory adjuvants that synergistically potentiate more effective vaccine-induced immune responses against various pathogens. Our goal is to deliver a novel, efficacious combination of innate cytoplasmic PRR adjuvants with rASP-1, a unique parasite protein adjuvant, that promotes protective long-lived adaptive responses and boosts efficacy of vaccines in aged populations.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Glaucoma describes a group of optic neuropathies that lead to progressive and irreversible vision loss and frequent blindness. An increase in intraocular pressure (via reduced outflow facility) is a major modifiable risk factor. Although tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) is known to play a key role in regulating outflow facility and thus IOP through non-enzymatic activity, the long-term use of an enzymatically inactive tPA has not been tested for efficacy in preventing functional visual loss and safety. The purpose of this proposal is to directly answer this question and further elucidate this pathway with a goal of developing a new therapeutic aimed at reducing high IOP to prevent functional loss in glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Vascular, thrombotic, and inflammatory diseases, such as sepsis, heart attack or stroke, will affect most of us at some point in life, with a profound impact on the quality and duration of life thereafter. Available therapeutic solutions are limited and mortality rates remain unacceptably high. Guided by the beneficial cytoprotective effects of activated protein C in a broad range of in vivo injury and disease models, the proposed studies will identify novel molecular mechanisms and investigate novel approaches for potential therapeutic applications using engineered molecular biologics.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Firearm injuries are the second leading cause of death for U.S. children and teens (age 1-17) and constitute a major public health crisis requiring urgent attention from the scientific community. Advances in our understanding of this public health problem and the evidence-based solutions needed to reduce both morbidity/mortality and the substantial health disparities associated with firearm injury have lagged other fields of pediatric injury science due to a lack of federal research funding and the absence of a critical mass of trained research scientists. This new T32 application addresses the critical need to develop a scientific workforce that can capitalize on the recent expansion of federal research funding by establishing the nation’s first program dedicated exclusively to providing post-doctoral research training on the prevention of firearm injuries among children and teens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because the discovery of how intermediate filaments use specific molecular mechanisms to regulate human tissues is ultimately expected to generate therapeutic targets for multiple human diseases. Intermediate filaments are mutated or dysregulated in over eighty human diseases, as well as have involvement in the pathogenesis of human cancers. Thus, by connecting molecular mechanisms to human disease pathogenesis and to pharmacological discovery, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that concerns the development of fundamental knowledge that will help extend healthy life and reduce burdens of illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: We will study the physiological functions of astrocytes in the basal ganglia striatal circuitry. Our data will provide new information on the roles of astrocytes in the normal healthy brain and in diseases of the nervous system, including the processes that lead to the development of neurological disease. Our work is also highly relevant to all forms of brain damage and to a diverse range of brain disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative: The proposed research will impact human health by providing new insights into the role of inner ear organization in refinement of properties expressed by auditory neurons in the brain. These insights will be informative for optimizing therapeutic approaches to early hearing loss or cochlear hypoplasia that aim to preserve normal structure and function of the brain. The proposed experiments address questions fundamental to the mission of the National Institute on Deafness and other Communication Disorders, by investigating processes of both normal and disordered auditory development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The primary cilium acts as the cell’s antenna, with recent evidence suggesting that it is critical to the cell’s ability to respond to signals, such as insulin signaling, that are relevant to the development of diabetes. However, we do not yet know if changes in genes important to ciliary function increase a person’s risk to develop diabetes, nor do we understand how ciliary genes act in the cell to affect insulin signaling. Using a combination of genetic and molecular techniques, this proposal seeks to answer these questions to advance our knowledge of cilium biology, open new avenues for patient risk assessment, and identify novel therapeutic targets for common diseases, like diabetes, with huge public health burdens.
