IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Low frustration tolerance and uncontrolled aggression are common and impairing symptoms in psychiatric disorders as varied as PTSD, bipolar disorder, and autism. Little is known, however, about the neural basis of these behaviors. This proposal uses cutting-edge technologies to reveal the neural circuits underlying frustration and aggression, with the ultimate goal of developing more effective therapies for patients across multiple disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Mental health, which accounts for a significant percentage of the global health burden, can be effectively managed through mobile and digital tools, yet suffers from limited access, inconsistent treatments, and qualitative approaches that do not scale. Taking aim at an increasingly pervasive and canonical mental health problem, autism, we plan to build a game-based solution that can treat (addressing issues social interaction, eye contact, and social-emotional awareness, among other things) while tracking progress, and that can automatically generate computer vision libraries for deep learning models that permit enhanced diagnostic feature extraction in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neuropsychiatric disease often impairs human cognitive and social capabilities arising from the evolutionary expansion of the human neocortex. A major roadblock to interpreting the effect of genetic variants increasing risk for neuropsychiatric disease is that they almost entirely fall into non-coding regions of the genome that regulate gene expression. Here we develop and apply experimental approaches to functionally interrogate gene regulatory elements in discrete aspects of human cortical development to gain new insights into the underlying mechanisms of these disorders that may serve to develop therapeutics.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Electronic health record (EHR) and clinical registry data are commonly used for monitoring hospital surgical quality. Clinical registry data, like the VA Surgical Quality Improvement Program (VASQIP), are robust because they are hand abstracted by trained personnel, but the time and costs associated with data collection limits hospital performance evaluation to only a sample of all cases performed. Hybrid data (i.e.: EHR combined with clinical registry variables) is an alternative that could increase the number of cases used for measuring hospital performance (providing a more comprehensive picture of the quality of surgical care) and lower the burden of data collection for quality improvement. This mixed-methods proposal will evaluate the reliability of VASQIP’s current case sampling strategy for identifying outlier VA hospitals, explore the use of hybrid data as a means of enhancing data collection efficiency, and will identify how more efficient data collection could enhance local QI through semi-structured interviews with Surgical Quality Nurses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE When people get infected with viral infections like SARS-CoV-2 and influenza, some get very sick while some barely notice their symptoms. The goal of this project is to support research that will help us understand if this variation in patients’ susceptibility to severe disease is explained by differences in the microbiome (the microbial communities living on and in our bodies). The project will also support the development of a training program at the University of Michigan for junior investigators interested in conducting patient-oriented research related to the microbiome, critical illness, and lung disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Respiratory dysfunction is a common, often fatal, symptom of many developmental and genetic disorders such as sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) and Rett syndrome. Abnormal breathing likely arises from impaired signaling through the neural circuits that control breathing. This proposal is aimed at understanding the molecular mechanisms of respiratory neural circuit assembly in an attempt to identify novel therapeutic targets for breathing disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project is focused on obtaining basic knowledge about protein-protein interactions that are responsible for the beneficial, protective activities of the enzyme, activated protein C, which can provide multiple activities that reduce damage to cells and tissue. Based on preclinical studies in animals, activated protein C shows beneficial, often mortality reducing effects in the settings of ischemia/reperfusion injury of the heart, kidney and lungs, ischemic stroke, graft vs. host disease, kidney transplant, inflammatory lung injury, gastrointestinal inflammatory diseases, pseudomonas lung infection, acute neurotrauma, pancreatic islet transplantation, diabetes, and severe whole-body radiation. Thus, new knowledge about activated protein C variants may lead to improved 2nd or 3rd generation biologics for man.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The overall goal of this program is to improve outcomes in the treatment of human leukemias with more effective and less toxic therapies. We will employ novel methodologies and approaches to develop therapeutics that degrade proteins that are essential to leukemia cells, target signaling pathways in specific genetic subgroups, and modulate the apoptotic threshold of leukemia cells. Following pre-clinical studies in common model systems, the most promising therapeutic combinations will be tested in clinical trials with deep molecular characterization of patient samples.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Accurate non-invasive optical measurements of cerebral hemodynamics require suppression of confounding contributions from superficial tissue (scalp, skull, etc.) and motion artifacts. This project aims to develop an optical technique that minimizes these confounding contributions, thus paving the way for a more effective assessment of brain function and neurovascular pathologies. A wearable device, also developed in this project, will further extend this optical technique to point-of-care diagnostics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative While we have seen several exciting new drugs receive approval for treatment of acute myelogenous leukemia (AML) in the last couple of years, most patients with AML still die of their disease. We propose to expose actual patient leukemia cells to candidate drugs, and then measure which drugs cause cell death signaling, to choose active drugs for AML patients. Our overall goal is to establish a novel strategy by which a patient's AML sample can be tested to identify the best drugs with which to treat that patient.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations in the CBL gene are common in leukemia, but there are currently no therapies specifically for patients with mutations in this gene. CBL mutations create opportunities for targeted therapy because these mutations lead to activation of signaling pathways that can be inhibited by FDA-approved drugs. We will identify the pathways that are activated when CBL is mutated, characterize the biology of these mutations, and test candidate therapies for CBL-mutant leukemia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite historic advances in the treatment of acute leukemia, acute myeloid leukemia (AML) remains a poor prognosis diagnosis for adult and pediatric patients and defines an area of significant unmet medical need. Mutations that drive leukemia development frequently lead to alteration of genes encoding proteins that control gene expression, leading to corruption of normal blood development programs and leukemia. Thus, we propose an innovative strategy integrating chemical and leukemia biology to target aberrant gene transcription by (a) characterizing and developing therapeutic agents targeting zinc finger transcription factors and (b) by revealing functionally validated therapeutic targets for further therapeutic discovery and development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Objectives of our K12 Program are to: (1) recruit and train outstanding Scholars who will be engaged in an individualized curriculum and in mentored health care research during a three-year period in this multidisciplinary, multicultural K12 program, (2) enhance the mentoring environment for translational science Scholars through a robust program for both mentors and mentees built on the NRMN training platform, and (3) provide a highly focused mentored research experience that fosters Scholars' successful transition to independence and continued engagement as leaders of translational health care teams. Meeting these objectives will require continued campus-wide, multidisciplinary participation of faculty as members of mentoring teams for K12 Scholars. Additionally, the ICTS, home of the only CTSA in the State of Iowa, will collaborate with CTSA hubs across the United States to enhance the learning environment and increase the opportunities for our K12 Scholars to build successful careers in translational science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative With nearly 6 million Americans living with disabilities resulting from a traumatic brain injury, at an estimated annual cost of $90 billion per year, development of an effective neuron replacement strategy could have enormous impact. The proposed research will develop a cell transplantation procedure to replace a specific type of neuron, cortical interneurons, following experimental head injury. Understanding the therapeutic potenital of these newly generated inhibitory neurons is essential before these discoveries can be translated into new therapies for human brain injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE Alcohol use disorders (AUD) and alcohol-related liver disease (ALD) are major public health problems with substantial and yet rising levels of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The goal of the Translational Alcohol Research Program (TARP) is to facilitate the ability of emerging post-doctoral researchers to bridge the gap in the application of knowledge gained from basic to clinical and social behavioral science research in AUD and ALD. The TARP is designed to improve clinical treatment of AUD and ALD by increasing the availability of appropriately-trained young scientists who are conversant in basic and clinical sciences and able to comfortably traverse the translational gap between these sciences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - Core 2 Biostatistics The goal of Core 2 Biostatistics is to assure that all experiments conducted through this P01 in in myeloid malignancies have access to state-of-the-art statistical support for their design and analysis. This extends to the basic science and murine experiments described in the four Projects, as well as to the clinical and correlative studies undertaken in conjunction with the Clinical Core (Core 3) and the Biospecimen Core (Core 1). This assures that the work performed on this P01 will be robust and reproducible, and thereby contribute to an improved understanding of these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  There is some intriguing evidence that changes in the way older individuals carry out a complex activity of daily living may herald the beginning of cognitive decline. One of these complex activities is driving. We propose testing the ability of the increasingly popular sensors placed in cars to track driver behavior (following too close, drifting out of one's lane, distracted driving) to provide early warnings of cognitive decline, allowing the individual time to seek further testing and treatment and to make plans for the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because high-grade serous ovarian cancer is a particularly deadly cancer that is often only identified at late stage and treatment options are limited. Specifically, we pro- pose to use single-cell profiling to identify the biologic basis of subtypes of this disease, because researchers could then develop treatments that target the unique vulnerabilities of each subtype. The proposed work, which identifies the pathway and cell-type basis of these subtypes, are highly relevant to NCI’s mission and particu- larly timely with the advent of single-cell profiling and immunotherapies, which will likely need to be paired with other treatment strategies for large solid tumors such as most high-grade serous ovarian cancers.

PHR: Project Narrative Kidney stones are common, costly, and a major cause of morbidity. This proposal will study two mechanisms contributing to high urine oxalate and low urine citrate in kidney stone patients, including high risk obese and post-gastric bypass patients. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative / Relevance Our proposed research is aimed at developing new chemical tools for analyzing the interactions and functions of messenger RNAs in the cell, and applying them to address important biomedical questions. Our new methods will establish easy-to-install chemical handles on large, complex RNAs that allow them to be labeled, tracked, analyzed, and controlled. We will use them to investigate how drugs and metabolites interact with RNAs in the cell, and to study the effects of chemical modifications that are included in mRNA vaccines and upcoming RNA therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The overall purpose of this R01 grant application entitled “Self-Management to Optimize Survivorship Care and Outcomes in Lung and Colorectal Cancer” is to test whether an advanced practice nurse (APRN)-led Survivor Self-Management (SSM) Intervention can improve care coordination, communication, and quality of life in lung and colorectal cancer. In collaboration with the Beckman Research Institute of City of Hope and the University of California, Riverside, we have a unique opportunity to understand whether a self-management and oncology/primary care shared care model can optimize outcomes for lung and colorectal cancer survivors, a growing population that are traditionally underrepresented in cancer research. Completion of the study will improve our understanding on how to best transition lung and colorectal cancer survivors to post-treatment follow-up care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: In order to successfully transmit disease, mosquitoes must survive midgut invasion by human pathogens, which often causes damage to the mosquito gut epithelium. In model organisms, stem cell-mediated gut epithelial repair has been shown to be essential for host survival of oral infection, however the role of intestinal stem cells in the epithelial infection response of mosquitoes has not been explored. In this proposal, we aim to characterize gut epithelial dynamics in Aedes aegypti under conditions of homeostasis and pathogenic challenge and identify the role of stem cell-mediated midgut repair in mosquito survival of pathogenic invasion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetic variants are typically transmitted from the parents to their offspring, but they can also arise after conception (post-zygotically acquired) during embryonic development. Genetic variants in SLC35A2 arising during brain development have recently been implicated in intractable focal epilepsy. In this study, we seek to: (1) determine the brain cell types involved in SLC35A2 epilepsy, (2) study effects of the variants on neuronal glycosylation, neuronal development, and neuronal activity, and (3) assess the ability of galactose supplementation to reverse the deleterious effects of the variants on neurons.

PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE. Microsporidia, pathogenic protists related to Fungi (Cryptomycota), are oportunistic pathogens in humans, particularly in patients with AIDS. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Substance use is a major public health concern that disproportionately affects individuals from low socioeconomic status (SES) backgrounds. The proposed project will use data from three population- representative, longitudinal cohort studies to test both (a) whether one mechanism linking childhood socioeconomic status and problematic substance use is individual differences in distributed neural networks underlying different aspects of self-regulation and (b) whether these associations generalize across different racial/ethnic groups. Identifying these mechanisms will guide needed prevention and intervention efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Stress is a major risk factor for mental health problems and has been strongly linked with the development of anhedonic symptoms (i.e. “stress-induced anhedonia”), however, the mechanisms by which stress leads to anhedonia are not fully understood. The goal of this K01 proposal is to explore the independent and additive contributions of mPFC glutamate function and inflammatory cytokines to stress-induced anhedonia. Elucidating these pathways will inform new targets for the treatment of anhedonia.

PHR: We discovered that anticoagulant Protein S (PS) inhibits FIXa. Here, we will identify the region of PS that binds and inhibits FIXa. Precise definition of the binding site of FIXa on PS may enable us to make a polypeptide mimetic of PS to treat individuals with PS deficiencies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative Cells must fold and organize the DNA in their nucleus. Most cells follow the same basic rules for organizing their DNA, but a few types of cells have been shown to bend these rules in order to organize their DNA in new and distinctive ways that serve specific functions. In order to understand when and how this happens, we will study the specialized 3D DNA structures that form in mouse olfactory neurons and in mouse spinal cord.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative (Spreng/Bzdok, McGill University) ! PROJECT NARRATIVE Loneliness in older adulthood is associated with cognitive decline and more rapid onset of Alzheimer's disease (AD), increasing burdens on the individual, caregivers, and the healthcare system. How loneliness impacts brain structure and function in later life, and whether it precedes or promotes accelerated neurodegeneration and the emergence of AD, is unknown. The proposed research will investigate how loneliness, a modifiable risk factor for AD, impacts the brain in normal aging and pre-symptomatic AD, towards the longer term goal of better surveillance and intervention. ! !1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE Microbes influence immunosurveillance as well as the efficacy of chemotherapy and immunotherapy that shape cancer outcomes, but underlying mechanisms remain unclear. Microbes themselves or metabolites derived by bacterial metabolism may be the mediating factors that alter the tumor microenvironment to impact anti-tumor immunity. Upon conclusion, this study will determine whether microbial-modification of bile acid pools and activation of bile acid receptor signaling act as novel mechanisms that can be leveraged to enhance anti-tumor immunity to improve patient outcomes in triple negative breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative It is important to map and preserve language areas of the brain during surgery for drug-resistant seizures, to prevent language impairments. At present, clinicians rely primarily on electrical stimulation of the brain for this, but now, language mapping can be performed with passive recordings of the brain's electrical activity. This project seeks to understand the similarities and differences between these two brain mapping techniques and to validate passive electrical recordings as a safer and equally effective alternative to electrical stimulation mapping.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative As regenerative medicine technologies bring us ever closer to generating organs in a dish, a central challenge is to understand how cells coordinate their behaviors into large-scale movements to generate proper form and function. We have discovered two novel collective cell behaviors reminiscent of embryonic gastrulation that occur during formation of epithelial placodes in the mammalian skin. Our model system offers an opportunity to understand these processes at unprecedented spatial and molecular resolution and to reveal how congenital birth defects arise when these processes go awry.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Preterm birth remains a significant cause of neonatal death and lacks an effective therapy. This proposal will test the therapeutic efficacy of Rytvela, a novel interleukin-1 receptor inhibitor, for the prevention of preterm birth and fetal injury due to bacterial infections in a nonhuman primate model. Completion of these experiments is essential for determining whether IL-1 is a key molecular target for preventing preterm birth and to enable translation of our findings into preclinical studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Current treatments for psychiatric disorders with deficits in cognitive and emotional Research Domain Criteria (RDoC) domains have limited efficacy, necessitating more effective treatment strategies. Disorders with NMDA receptor hypofunction lead to septohippocampal circuit dysfunction and circuit-specific cognitive dysfunction. Deep brain stimulation (DBS) alters focal and diffuse networks and has recently been posited as a treatment for psychiatric disorders. This project aims to evaluate the the role of electrophysiological networks involved in NMDA receptor hypofunction and utilize DBS to improve cognitive behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE We will reveal the proteomic consequences and discover new protein-protein associations in the aneuploidy models that are relevant to human lung cancer and trisomy disorders, providing a deeper biological understanding of disease development process. The proteostasis rules discovered and datasets generated may offer opportunities in predicting the impact of a patient-specific gene copy number alteration on the abundance of specific disease biomarkers and thus the clinical phenotypes. The studies will provide a list of important protein targets for further functional studies and therapeutics managing disease phenotypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most patients with metastatic bladder cancer die of their disease. In the previous funding period, we studied CD24, a metastasis driver and prognostic marker and discovered CD24 is induced by Discoidin Domain Receptor Tyrosine Kinase 2 (DDR2), which unlike CD24, has drugs available to block its function. In the current application, we propose to use novel approaches and technologies in both animal models and human samples to study the function of DDR2 in bladder cancer and then use this knowledge to develop unique, more effective therapies against the metastatic form of this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROGRAM INTRODUCTION NARRATIVE: Platelets, circulating anucleate fragments of bone marrow megakaryocytes, provide primary hemostasis by forming hemostatic plugs at sites of vascular injury; likewise, platelet thrombi are predominantly responsible for the morbidity and mortality of arterial vascular disease. Although much is known about platelet biology, large gaps in our knowledge remain. Here, we propose to close these gaps by studying processes that occur in the platelet cytoplasm, on the platelet surface and in the interior of platelet thrombi, and as well as the summation of these processes when platelets participate in host-defense against sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Abstract: Platelets are a blood cell that is important for blood clotting and associated with severe human diseases such as heart attacks and strokes. In the bone marrow, platelets are derived from another type of blood cell called a megakaryocyte, and our proposed studies aim to understand how megakaryocytes develop normally so that they can make normal platelets. This research will have the potential to reveal novel therapeutic strategies to target this process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project 2: Narrative Integrin-mediated cell-cell and cell-matrix adhesion is essential for many fundamental biologic processes and is an important contributor to human diseases such as thrombosis and cancer metastasis. Although the major platelet integrin αIIbβ3 has been a model for integrin function, its behavior may not be typical for integrins in general. The objective of this project is to compare the behavior of αIIbβ3 with that of the other integrins present in platelets to gain a more general understanding of integrin function, thereby enabling the future generation of more effective and safer anti-integrin therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project 3 Narrative Platelet activation and accumulation are part of the normal response to vascular injury, producing a platelet- rich plug that limits blood loss. Heart attacks and strokes occur when platelets are activated inappropriately, blocking blood flow and damaging tissues such as the heart and brain. The goal of this project is to better understand platelet plug formation and translate that understanding into improved methods to prevent thrombosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A marked decrease in essential micronutrients such as iron perturbs the gut microbial community during intestinal inflammation, depleting beneficial commensals. Despite being central to maintaining the overall microbiota structure and functions in the face of perturbations, the mechanisms underlying commensal resilience remain poorly understood. By elucidating the mechanisms of how the prevalent gut bacterium Bacteroides thetaiotaomicron survives iron starvation in the inflamed gut, we will advance our knowledge of both fundamental bacterial physiology principles and resilience mechanisms of the gut microbiota.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Sepsis is a life-threatening complication of an infection, overwhelming the body’s defenses in spite of receiving antibiotics and this toxicity is in part due to neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) released from activated white blood cells. Results of Project 4 should provide a better understanding of how platelets in the blood can decrease the toxicity of NETs and offers several new testable interventions to limit this toxicity based on this biology. This Project will interact with the other Projects on this grant to better understand platelet biology in health and disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Anxiety disorders and insomnia are common during pregnancy and treatment with benzodiazepines and non- benzodiazepine sedative hypnotics is often indicated, yet rigorous and comprehensive safety data to inform the risk-benefit trade-off are sparse, evidence is conflicting, and numerous safety concerns have been raised. To address this critical information gap we propose to generate high-quality evidence on the safety of benzodiazepines and non-benzodiazepine sedative hypnotics during pregnancy considering a broad range of clinically relevant adverse pregnancy outcomes. Evidence generated will not only prevent unnecessary exposure for mother and fetus at time points during pregnancy when the medication may be harmful but will also provide guidance and reassurance as to when the medication can be used safely.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Mutations in the gene that encodes the skeletal muscle type I ryanodine receptor (RYR1) result in a wide range of muscle disorders that collectively comprise the most common cause of non-dystrophic myopathy. The most severe cases of RYR1-related myopathy (RYR1-RM) exhibit a recessive pattern of inheritance and present in infancy with muscle hypotrophy, weakness, and a marked reduction in RYR1 protein expression. The overall goals of this project are to use two novel mouse models to define and interrogate patho-mechanisms responsible for recessive RYR1 RM and to evaluate the efficacy of interventions designed to counteract these aberrant mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The current challenges in melanoma targeted therapy are due to an incomplete understanding of the mechanisms underlying the key influence of the tumor microenvironment on tumor cell response to therapeutic agents. The goal of the proposed project is to systemically explore how cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) respond to BRAF inhibitors and remodel a protective tumor niche that induces growth and therapeutic escape in melanoma cells. The knowledge gained will advance the understanding of the contribution of CAFs in treatment responsiveness and melanoma recurrence. If successful, the data will accelerate the development of novel strategies to co-target both melanoma cells and the host microenvironment for improved patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Currently, patients on the kidney transplant waitlist undergo repeat cardiac screening tests at frequent intervals, but relatively few interventions result. This project proposes to refine the cardiac screening strategy and personalize it for specific patient subgroups (e.g. elderly patients without diabetes mellitus), by examining strategies that reduce the frequency of cardiac testing and use performance-based risk stratification to reduce the number of patients who need cardiac testing. If successful, this project will reduce the cardiac testing burden and facilitate activation for transplant for patients on the kidney transplant waitlist.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative Diabetic foot infection is one of the most detrimental complications in diabetic population and along with impaired wound healing a main contributor of lower leg amputations in diabetic patients, resulting in a major impact to patients’ quality of life and significant burden and associated costs to the health care system. Our long term goal is to target intracellular pathogens in patients with diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs) by understanding mechanisms by which human skin fights intracellular infection and participates in wound healing. We will implement this knowledge to develop novel advanced therapeutic approaches to prevent and treat diabetic wound and skin infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative The goal of this project is to test the effect on spatial working memory of focused ultrasound for noninvasive brain stimulation and targeted drug delivery directed to the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex and dorsal striatum. Focused ultrasound could provide a new research tool for establishing causal brain-behavior relationships, mapping neural circuits in healthy humans, and a novel method for introducing neuroactive drugs that do not cross the intact blood-brain barrier (BBB). Focused ultrasound therapy could become a non-surgical alternative to treat cognitive impairments in patients with neurological or psychiatric disorders who experience working memory deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: This T32 application, the Center for Drug Discovery “Training Program on Medications Development for Substance Use Disorder (SUD)” is to provide broad training to PhD students and postdoctoral scientists on discovery and development of medicines to treat SUD. The Training Program rationale is driven by the socioeconomic burden and medical need associated with lack of safe and effective medications to address SUD in the US and globally. The Training Program blends mentorship, coursework, and research activities supervised by Center for Drug Discovery faculty based at Northeastern University, McLean Hospital/Harvard Medical School, and Tufts University and Medical Center to equip trainees to develop as productive biomedical research scientists, with consummate expertise in SUD medications development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Family caregivers of persons with dementia (PwDs) often lament missed opportunities to record meaningful moments with their loved ones, experience distressing and disabling grief in advance of the PwD’s physical death and report a deterioration of their relationship with the PwD. We propose to adapt our online Living Memory Home bereavement reminiscence resource to the context of home-based caregiver-PwD dyads as a pre-loss activity so that memories can be recalled and recorded collaboratively between the “care pair”. We expect it will prove a welcome resource, reduce feelings of caregiver pre-loss grief, and improve the quality of the care pair’s relationship.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Overall Narrative Transplantation tolerance, a state of immune hyporesponsiveness to a graft following cessation of immunosuppressive therapy, can prevent complications from life-long global immunosuppression but is rarely attained in the clinic. This PPG addresses the barriers to both the induction and long-term maintenance of transplantation tolerance, and explores two potential solutions that leverages the natural ability of pregnancy to tolerize fetus-reactive T cells and harnesses the capacity of chronic antigen exposure to drive immune hypofunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol use disorder (AUD) is a common cause of hospitalization, especially among racial and ethnic minorities. Yet, treatments that work to address alcohol use, including medications and cognitive behavioral therapy, are typically not offered in the hospital. We plan to compare the impact of different treatment approaches on promoting AUD treatment engagement and reduction in alcohol use among a diverse sample of patients with untreated AUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Public Health Relevance The proposed work will determine the causal cardiorespiratory effects resulting from co-activation of sympathetic and parasympathetic autonomic nervous systems in autonomically compromised subjects. This confluence of events lies behind Sudden Unexpected Death from Epilepsy (SUDEP) in various animal models. Systematic physiological monitoring across those models, acute and chronically, will provide insights relevant towards the treatment and prevention of some of the over 4,000 annual human deaths from SUDEP in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: OVERALL: PROJECT NARRATIVE  HOPE & CAIRHE 2gether (HC2) brings together the expertise, infrastructure, partnerships, and resources of the Center for Health Outcomes and Population Equity (HOPE), Huntsman Cancer Institute, and University of Utah, with the Center for American Indian and Rural Health Equity (CAIRHE) and Montana State University. The overall, long-term goal of HC2 is to increase the reach of evidence-based cancer prevention and control interventions in areas of persistent poverty. The two research projects will work in persistent poverty census tracts and in partnership with Community Health Centers in Utah, and with Cooperative Extension Systems and American Indian communities in Montana, Oregon, South Dakota, and Wisconsin, to mitigate adverse impacts of the social determinants of health, increase tobacco cessation, and prevent obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Automated tools will be developed to better identify those with suspected prenatal alcohol exposure using a combination of 3D facial imaging and neurocognitive testing using low-cost imaging devices. We will utilize outputs from online cognitive assessment (FASD-Tree and Brain-Online) tools to improve sensitivity/specificity for the identification of FASD. Machine learning approaches will be applied to achieve automated objective analysis of facial images and deployed on a cloud server for worldwide, multi-device accessibility. To ensure our tools are optimized, we will investigate the impact on facial dysmorphism of age, ethnicity, sexual dimorphism, and co-exposures. These tools will facilitate and support the recognition of individuals with FASD, who may need further support, and will include infants through to adults using a fully automated and objective approach, using low-cost solutions and providing an accessible toolkit for clinicians.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Glaucoma is a leading cause of blindness worldwide. Until now, mechanistic-based studies focused on optic nerve head (ONH) and sclera biomechanics and their intraocular pressure (IOP) –related behavior. This project posits a new hypothesis proposing an intrinsic mechanical interaction between sclera and vitreous humor as modulator of the ONH-sclera biomechanics during dynamic IOP variations occurring in physiological conditions. This project will define the impact of the age-related vitreous degeneration and vitreous replacement on sclera biomechanics. Additionally, we will determine how sclera response to IOP dynamics can be restored/improved by using hydrogel vitreous substitutes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Listeria monocytogenes continues to be an increasingly significant health threat as it has been associated with numerous multi-state food-borne outbreaks that have resulted in thousands of illnesses and several hundred deaths within the past few years. The largest and most expensive recalls of food products in history have occurred as a result of L. monocytogenes contamination, and the bacterium poses a significant threat to pregnant women who may not even realize they have been infected. This proposal is focused on identifying and deciphering how select subpopulations of L. monocytogenes are enhanced for transmission from mother to developing fetus during pregnancy.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: INSTITUTE FOR BASIC RES IN DEV DISABIL
PHR: Project Narrative Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a complex set of related neurodevelopmental disorders expressed within the first two to three years of life and carries a high economic cost to the affected families as well as to their communities. In contrast with the neonatal brain, the placenta represents a universally accessible organ suitable for population screening that may provide markers for ASD risk. The proposed project is a retrospective review of electronic medical records and biospecimens (placental formalin-fixed, paraffin- embedded tissue blocks) and newborn dried blood spots, which will be analyzed for ASD genetic risk, a broad range of markers of placental and newborn inflammation, and epigenetic modifications to ASD diagnoses after adjustment for maternal and neonatal covariates

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative: We propose to develop the DisEase PrOgression Trajectory (DEPOT), an evidence-driven, graph- based clinical informatics approach to model chronic kidney disease (CKD) progression trajectories and individualize clinical decision support. The goal of this work is to use the IUSM EHR data collection to establish EHR-based CKD progression trajectories and to learn actionable knowledge to prevent drug-induced acute kidney injury (AKI) and CKD. The success of the proposed work will generate novel knowledge about the landscape of CKD health trajectories and nephrotoxic drug-drug interactions, bridging gaps between rich longitudinal EHR data and decision support for precision medicine in CKD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mayaro and chikungunya are alphaviruses that cause Mayaro fever and chikungunya fever, respectively; they present with fever, headache, muscle pain, chills, and long-term debilitating joint pain. These viruses are transmitted by mosquitoes, and adaptation to urban mosquitoes allows them to cause large outbreaks. Understanding how these viruses adapt to urban mosquitoes is essential for improved surveillance of variants and studies of how these viruses interact with host factors will spur the development of countermeasures against Mayaro and chikungunya viruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is substantial clinical interest in suicide risk models as tools to more accurately identify patients at risk for suicide but little scientific evidence about the effectiveness of these models in real world settings compared to standard screening practices alone, and almost no guidance for their implementation in healthcare. This high-impact, innovative study has important clinical implications as health systems consider whether it makes sense to enhance their existing suicide prevention care models with a suicide risk model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypertensive disorders of pregnancy (HDP) are a major cause of maternal and infant morbidity and mortality, and emerging evidence suggests that environmental exposure during pregnancy may play an important role in the development of HDP and subsequent cardiovascular disease (CVD) after pregnancy. However, multiple challenges and knowledge gaps exist in previous studies such as the lack of studies considering different subtype, onset, and severity of HDP, the lack of considerations of the totality of environment (i.e. the exposome), and limited understandings on how environmental exposures during pregnancy may impact subsequent maternal CVD risk after delivery. Leveraging the unique statewide linked electronic health records-birth records data from OneFlorida, this study builds on our prior work in the external exposome, aiming to examine the associations between the external exposome and risk of HDP and early risk of maternal CVD after pregnancy as well as to develop predictive models of HDP and maternal CVD after pregnancy to guide precision preventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Asthma is a chronic disease of the lungs, which has been on the rise in recent decades. Our studies strongly suggest that E3 ligase pathway plays a central role in airway smooth muscle (ASM) dysfunction that is relevant to asthma and therefore, studies in this proposal aim to elucidate the role of novel E3 ligase, RNF145 in ASM functions. Establishing RNF145 as a target to ameliorate multiple components of lung pathology in asthma may lead to the development of novel, effective therapy for asthma in future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Degenerative cervical myelopathy (DCM) is the most common form of spinal cord injury in adults and causes worsening neurological dysfunction including hand weakness and diminished coordination. Surgical management of DCM is challenging due to the low diagnostic certainty of the underlying pathology and the lack of predictive factors to determine which patients may or may not improve. Here we aim to use advanced brain, spinal cord, and muscle magnetic resonance imaging techniques to fully characterize the mechanisms of hand dysfunction in DCM and then develop neuromuscular signatures of hand function that predict surgical outcomes in DCM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Meals containing high amounts of oxalate may induce urinary nanocrystals, stimulate immunity, and promote calcium oxalate kidney stone (CaOx KS) formation. This proposal will use human translational studies and experimental models to investigate the impact of dietary oxalate on nanocrystalluria, monocytes, and macrophages. Our ultimate goal is to identify therapeutic targets to enhance macrophage metabolism and clearance of CaOx crystals from the kidney.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The purpose of the proposed work is to test the hypothesis that mechanical forces directly drive tissue assembly in corneal stromal matrix produced by human corneal cells. A sophisticated battery of mechanobiological tools will be combined to permit both local mechanical measurements and single molecule tracking while tissue is being elaborated in vitro. The results may change our understanding of how load-bearing tissues are made and could guide mechanotherapeutics for problems such as keratoconus, fibrosis, ectasia, myopia, glaucoma and even aid efforts at corneal stromal regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative In addition to physical, neurocognitive, physiological and behavioral abnormalities/deficits that occur following prenatal alcohol exposure (PAE), our findings in CIFASD 4 suggest negative impacts on both physical and mental health outcomes in midlife, with many health problems occurring earlier than would be expected in the general population. Findings also indicate that PAE is associated with long-lasting, adverse changes in immune and endocrine function, starting in infancy and lasting into adulthood. Using a “whole body, whole lifespan” approach, we will investigate how PAE-induced alterations in the immune and endocrine systems may be key drivers of early-onset health and functional deficits in adults with FASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Our objective is to develop better assays for measuring antibodies produced in people after influenza infection or vaccination. We’ll develop assays that measure total antibody responses, and assays that specifically measure the antibodies responsible for protection from infection. The assays will be faster and more practical than existing methods, and will provide important tools for accelerating the development of new influenza vaccines. †The sections on documents contained in this proposal that are marked with an asterisk contain proprietary/confidential information that MSD requests not be released to persons outside the Government, except for purposes of review and evaluation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this project, the applicant will identify novel features of the digital clock drawing test most correlated with pathophysiological events in preclinical Alzheimer’s disease (AD) using machine learning and multimodal neuroimaging and establish the longitudinal performance of the digital test. Outcomes of the project will provide a non-invasive assessment of individual cognitive status in the context of progressive pathophysiological events in preclinical AD. This will enable efficient and cost-effective participant screening for AD therapeutic trials and facilitate the translation of digital testing into AD primary care settings, especially for underserved populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative If science is to inform effective substance misuse prevention policy and ultimately improve public health, the field needs an effective strategy for directly supporting policymakers’ use of research evidence, yet our field lacks an evidence-based model designed for this purpose. Accordingly, we propose a state-level randomized controlled trial (N = 30 state legislatures) of a formal, theory-based approach for supporting policymakers’ use of scientific evidence that does not involve lobbying—the Research-to-Policy Collaboration (RPC) Model. This work can reduce population-level substance misuse by improving the use of scientific information in policymaking, thus increasing the availability of evidence-based prevention programs and policies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to develop a transformative multimodal experimental platform to uncover the brain-wide architecture of neuronal circuits underlying parenting behavior in molecular, functional, connectivity-based and computational terms. We will use this experimental framework to shed light into the sensory motor transformation underlying parenting behavior as a function of the animal sex and physiological state.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Live cell therapies to intelligently and specifically treat human disease are the next frontier of medicine. These therapies will rely on engineered cells that are capable of understanding their environment and making autonomous decisions about when and where to deliver treatment. This project will uncover fundamental principles for how cells control their behavior based on their environment and will make important contributions to both basic biology and the engineering of next generation therapeutics

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a devastating age-related neurodegenerative disorder that causes extensive deterioration of cognitive functions. Altered gut bacteria and their effects on the gut, immune system, and brain have been recently implicated as causative in disease. The IgA isotype antibody produced predominantly in the gut is the primary protection in the intestine from harmful pathogens such as bacteria. Using a mouse model of disease, we demonstrate that female AD mice have elevated IgA in the intestine that recognizes unique disease- associated bacteria capable of producing memory dysfunction. We hypothesize that these IgA coated bacteria are directly contributing to disease in particularly females and will test this in the proposal. Completion of the study will identify pathogenic gut bacteria contributing to AD progression in a sex-selective fashion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The larynx plays a pivotal role in protection of the lungs from aspiration and subsequent pneumonia. Opioid use is associated with impairment in the function of the larynx to protect the lungs from aspiration. Further, opioids are often prescribed to older adults who are particularly at risk of developing aspiration pneumonia due to impairments in airway protection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Severe delirium, a type of acute confusion often experienced by older adults, leads to worsening Alzheimer’s Disease and related Dementias and quality of life. Healthcare clinicians need a more timely and comprehensive measurement of severe delirium in critically ill older adults. Therefore, the current study aims to develop a passive digital marker for measuring delirium severity that relies on routinely collected data and then tests if this passive digital marker is usable and acceptable by frontline healthcare clinicians.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: An imbalance of certain bacterial groups within the human gut is associated with diseases such as obesity and inflammatory bowel disease, however, we lack a mechanistic understanding of these associations. This project will determine how human gut bacteria interact with their host by producing a previously undescribed syringe-like structure that promotes interactions by injecting proteins into target cells. Our results will lay a foundation for technology employing microbiome bacteria and their syringe-like structures as probiotics to modulate the human microbiome and host health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This study proposes to conduct a fully powered cluster randomized controlled trial of a novel, integrated urban gardens and peer nutritional counseling intervention (ProMeSA) to support the goal of improving ART adherence, HIV care retention, and HIV virologic suppression (undectectable viral load). The study will involve 20 HIV clinics and 500 people with HIV and food insecurity in the Dominican Republic and will assess intervention efficacy on HIV clinical outcomes; examine intermediate outcomes (food security, diet quality, HIV stigma, and competing needs) posited to mediate the impact of ProMeSA on ART adherence, HIV care retention, and HIV viral suppression; and explore barriers and facilitators to intervention uptake, implementation, and sustainability.

PHR: Project Narrative Most people with fetal alcohol spectrum disorders (FASD) cannot access FASD-informed interventions and experience lower quality of life. This project will develop and evaluate three developmentally-appropriate FASD-informed interventions targeting quality of life at a different life phase. Each intervention leverages technology to increase accessibility and overcome significant barriers to care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH While stroke patients experience dramatic bone loss and high rates of bone fracture not explained by bedrest alone, the underlying causes remain largely unknown. Microdevices are uniquely qualified to mimic 3D microenvironments in a highly controllable manner, allowing localized effects of bone-vascular pathologies at the cellular level to be isolated from confounding systemic effects present in vivo. This research will leverage microdevice technology to investigate changes to bone cell behavior in response to chronic inflammatory conditions following stroke, providing key insights into a potential initiator of bone loss that can inform better treatment strategies to improve bone health for stroke survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative In the United States, as many as 3 million individuals with epilepsy experience cognitive and sleep problems, in addition to seizures, contributing to poor quality of life. This project will characterize the sleep architecture patterns in epilepsy that are associated with memory and attention deficits. The long-term goal of this project is to develop therapeutic interventions for sleep disorders and cognitive deficits in people with epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE: In this application, we propose to examine the relationship between experiences of family- and community-level promotive factors, exposure to childhood adversity, DNA methylation, and risk for depressive symptoms within two established and distinct longitudinal studies: (1) the Avon Longitudinal Study of Parents and Children (ALSPAC); and (2) the Fragile Families and Child Wellbeing Study (FFCWS). Findings from this research will help identify not just windows of vulnerability when childhood adversity and DNAm changes are most harmful, but also windows of opportunity when enriching family- level caregiving environments and community-level resources may be more impactful. Our findings will aid in identifying potentially modifiable targets for intervention that could be deployed to promote positive adaptation and reduce risk for depression across the life course for all people, including among those who have experienced childhood adversity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative There is significant interest in therapeutically targeting chromatin complexes for cancer treatment, yet the precise molecular mechanisms driving aberrant epigenetic states remain unclear. To interrogate the function of chromatin complexes, we are leveraging multi-disciplinary approaches that combine chemical biology with functional genomics, specifically focusing this application on lysine-specific histone demethylase-1 (LSD1) and its interactions with transcription factors and E3 ubiquitin ligases. Our studies will provide deep insight into chromatin complex structure and function as they relate to disease mechanisms and drug action.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pleiotropy is a poorly understood phenomenon in human genetic disorders wherein defects in a single gene results in multiple seemingly unrelated clinical conditions. In this proposal, the investigators will identity and characterize human genes that interconnect disorders of reproduction and craniofacial development. Using human studies and zebrafish models, this study will help understand the extent of genetic pleiotropy, the reasons behind the pleiotropy of these genes and its effects on overall human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The mitochondrion is an intracellular organelle most famous for its “powerhouse” role in promoting ATP synthesis. Recent studies have found that mitochondria also have crucial, ATP-independent metabolic roles in supporting cell function, but a detailed understanding of these other mitochondrial functions is lacking. This proposal seeks to disrupt mitochondrial processes and measure the effects on cell metabolism and cell function to gain a new, holistic understanding of the metabolic functions of mitochondria and to identify therapeutic targets for diseases associated with mitochondrial dysfunction, including mitochondrial diseases, neurodegeneration, cancer, aging, and others.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE  Numerous pathologies, tissue deficits, and injuries involve microvascular dysfunction and would significantly benefit from innovative approaches to better understand angiogenesis and vessel rarefaction. This project attacks these significant global health problems and addresses several objectives of the NHLBI Strategic Vision by further developing an emerging cell force biosensor platform to better understand the importance of pericytes in vasculogenesis and angiogenesis. Project outcomes are expected to demonstrate engineered control of pericytes during microvascular expansion and rarefaction in physiological and pathophysiological conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: In response to RFA-AI22-024 we propose “Exploring, Predicting, and Intervening on Long-term Viral suppression Electronically (EPI-LoVE)” to enroll, retain, analyze HIV care outcomes, and test digital health interventions among a large diverse digital cohort of people living with HIV (PLWH) who are struggling to engage with care and maintain consistent viral suppression. With multiple recruitment methods including social media and AIDS Healthcare Foundation current and former patients, we employ an evidence-based digital platform (HealthMpowerment, HMP) and multiple data sources (e.g., surveys, biologic specimens, app data). Capitalizing upon cross- cutting expertise to articulate the drivers of the ongoing HIV epidemic among the most vulnerable populations in the US we will identify the digital strategies that address the intersectionality of this ongoing public health crisis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Parkinson disease (PD) is an incurable and progressive neurodegenerative condition marked by the accumulation of ⍺-synuclein in affected neurons. To inform innovative therapeutic strategies with disease- modifying potential, this proposal takes advantage of a human induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC) PD model system to investigate the autophagy suppressor, myotubularin-related phosphatase 5 (MTMR5). These studies promise to reveal discrete therapeutic targets for selectively augmenting autophagy in neurons and reducing neuronal death in PD, while simultaneously uncovering the unique biology of myotubularins and their contribution to autophagy flux in neurons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: This project is directly relevant to public health concerns related to the effects of prenatal alcohol exposure on child health and development. This study aims to improve the screening of FASD by deploying web-based tools that aid in clinical evaluation. Two main tools will be used, the FASD-Tree and the Brief Assessment of Individual Neurobehavior – online version (BRAIN-online). Both tools use web-based technology for collecting data and provide the clinician with information about the individual’s physical, behavioral, and cognitive attributes. Data from these novel tools will be combined with traditional and advanced physical measurements collected through other CIFASD projects and will enhance clinical decision-making.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because the research findings will elucidate mechanisms for effects of slow stroking and deep pressure – components of massage therapy – on touch pleasantness and pain modulation. The proposed research will also characterize a novel pathway for affective deep pressure and elucidate its peripheral and central mechanisms, opening new horizons in mechanistic research on massage. The project is relevant to NCCIH’s mission because it addresses fundamental, real-time mechanistic processes of components of massage therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative The consequences resulting from prenatal alcohol exposure are wide-ranging, a major and costly public health problem, and can be life-long and impact numerous body systems. The goals of CIFASD are to improve the recognition of fetal alcohol spectrum disorders (FASD), implement interventions, and increase the capacity for dealing with these effects. Utilizing the resources of a multisite, multidisciplinary collaboration, CIFASD can address issues not achievable by individual projects.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The epigenetic machinery is essential for the proper regulation of gene expression, and mutations in components of this machinery can have wide-ranging effects on development and human health. A deeper understanding of how defects in the epigenetic machinery contribute to disease is currently hindered by our lack of knowledge about how different cell types are affected when components of the epigenetic machinery are perturbed. The proposed research will address this gap in knowledge by dissecting gene regulatory changes in mouse embryos engineered to carry precise mutations in epigenetic regulators, yielding deep insights into the functions of epigenetic regulators as well as fundamental mechanisms of gene regulation in development and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Patients with corneal injuries or disease can develop limbal stem cell deficiency (LSCD), resulting in blindness due to an irreversibly opaque cornea. While donor allogeneic ABCB5+ LSC transplants are currently already being evaluated as a therapeutic cell source for patients with bilateral LSCD, we hypothesize that it is also possible, in order to avoid immunosuppressive therapy for prevention of allograft rejection, to manufacture and expand autologous ABCB5+ LSCs for treatment of patients with bilateral LSCD using (i) full reprogramming in vitro, (ii) partial epigenetic reprogramming in vivo, and (iii) ligand-based activation of LSC signaling pathways. These autologous ABCB5+ LSC are anticipated to fully regenerate and maintain a normal limbus and corneal epithelium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Preterm born infants are at high risk for neurosensory impairments and developmental delays. In the NICU, infants are often deprived of infant-directed parental speech because of numerous challenges to parental visitation, resulting in reduced differentiation of speech sounds, altered brain structure and poor language outcomes. The result of this proposal will be a fully developed clinical device ready for submission to FDA for clearance, utilizing caregiver recorded infant-directed speech as the first intervention specifically designed for preterm infants and their brain development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because, gaining a better mechanistic understanding of how natural immune responses in the liver control malaria is expected to promote the development of novel anti- malarial drugs and vaccines. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the core mission of the NIH pertaining to acquisition of fundamental knowledge about the nature and behavior of living systems, and the application of that knowledge to enhance health, and reduce the burdens of illness in our society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE We have conducted a pilot study of an intervention for children with neurodevelopmental abnormalities resulting from prenatal alcohol exposure (PAE) that consists of a combination of computerized cognitive training (attention and executive functioning) and strategic brain stimulation (transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS)) - which is very low voltage stimulation designed to momentarily enhance “plasticity” in the cortex. The study will test five initial sessions of cognitive training and active tDCS vs. sham tDCS (placebo) and then go on to test two different dosages (5 active sessions vs. 10 active sessions). Outcome measures will assess attention, executive functioning, parent-reported behaviors related to these underlying cognitive functions, and functional brain network changes using state-of-the-art functional MRI methodologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Prediabetes (PD) and type 2 diabetes (T2D) affect 122 million Americans and are critically underdiagnosed— 81% and 23% of those with PD and T2D, respectively, are unaware that they have the condition. Screening guidelines for PD and T2D have been unable to mitigate this severe diagnostic gap due to their coarseness, subjectivity, and poor performance (e.g., low positive predictive value). The ultimate goal of this research is to develop and implement an innovative, practical, and scalable PD and T2D detection strategy by leveraging digital data obtained using personal consumer smart devices (smartphones and smartwatches) to improve the yield and reach of PD and T2D screening.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Individuals with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) and their spouses commonly experience sleep problems that may have negative consequences for their psychological well-being and cognitive function. This project will collect data from couples aged 60 and older in which one partner has early-stage ADRD to examine whether each partner’s reports of daily perceived stress and positive experiences are associated with daily sleep and long-term well-being and cognitive function over 2 years. Identifying potentially modifiable mechanisms at the daily level that explain both daily and long-term health effects within couples managing early-stage ADRD will optimize timely interventions to improve the health and functioning of both partners.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ability to accurately and rapidly measure extremely low levels of biomolecules is essential for diagnosing and monitoring many diseases, as well as for detecting pathogens and toxins in food and in the environment. While sufficient for certain biomarkers, the sensitivities of most existing diagnostic systems are inadequate for measuring many protein biomarkers that exist in easily accessible biofluids at concentrations much lower than the picomolar range. In this application, we propose to engineer and refine a new ultrasensitive single molecule protein analysis platform, Molecular On-bead Signal Amplification for Individual Counting (MOSAIC), that will be able to routinely measure attomolar protein concentrations and perform high-multiplex measurements, using common laboratory infrastructure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Substance use and substance use disorders, which have increasing prevalence in the US, place a huge personal, social and economic burden on society. Addressing this burden requires state-of-the-art epidemiologic research to detect and monitor trends, and to identify malleable risk factors in different populations in order to inform interventions that will reduce the toll of substance abuse on individuals and society. Since its start in 2012, the Substance Abuse Epidemiology Training Program (SAETP) at Columbia University Medical Center has been training productive, successful junior substance abuse epidemiologists; in a renewal cycle, we propose to continue such training, making the public health relevance of this program very strong.
PROJECT_TERMS: substance abuse epidemiology;Training Programs;Universities
PROJECT_TITLE: Substance Abuse Epidemiology Training Program (SAETP) at Columbia University

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Obesity is both a disease, affecting 1 in 3 Americans, and a risk factor for other chronic diseases, such as cardiovascular disease, type 2 diabetes, and 13 forms of cancers. Diet and exercise are the cornerstone of obesity prevention and treatment; however, a considerable number of individuals are non-responsive to existing weight-loss interventions and obesity rates continue to rise. Chronic (8 weeks), overnight (8 hours/night) low oxygen exposure may provide a non- conventional approach to supplement current weight-loss strategies, inform new strategies to accelerate weight loss, aid long-term weight management efforts, and benefit metabolic health in individuals with obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project narrative Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a progressive degenerative disease that affects motor neurons, and recent studies with animal models of the disease identified the EphA4 receptor as a disease- modifying gene, that is, it was found to be critical for the progression of the disease. We have preliminarily obtained a novel family of EphA4 targeting agents binding to its ligand binding domain. Given the properties of the molecules and our preliminary data, we believe that these agents may be rapidly developed into a novel targeted therapy to treat ALS.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The UCSD Clinical and Translational Research Institute (CTRI) will continue to support and transform clinical research by providing guidance and support from initial planning of research through data analysis and dissemination. It will provide an educational pipeline to train the next generation of clinical and translational scientists and involve the community in setting the direction and priorities of the organization. PHR: NIH R25 (PAR-19-215) “Team-Based Design in Biomedical Engineering Education” Narrative The proposed BiCEP program aim to integrate the clinical setting and relevant, contemporary biomedical practice in to the undergraduate curriculum and consists of two parts: i) Summer Immersion in Design Experience (SIDE) course focusing on the device design and development process and entrepreneurship in the biomedical space, and ii) a Clinical Immersion Experience (CLINEX) program that engages students with clinical mentors in a hospital setting. The goal of this is to provides a contextual bridge between students’ varied lower-division coursework and their more integrative upper-division core courses in the BMED program, ultimately leading to a more innovative and relevant educational experience. Integrating the clinical and medical context with design experiences throughout the BMED curriculum, and focusing on team-based design experiences is expected cultivate an ecosystem to support innovative projects and educate creative Biomedical Engineering professionals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Individuals with GOF-STAT3 mutations and Down Syndrome have a forty- and five-fold greater risk, respectively, of developing Celiac Disease, while the treatment options are limited to a gluten-free diet. We hypothesize that JAK-STAT overactivation is a primary genetic cause of the predisposition to Celiac Disease. The proposed research will collect samples and clinical data from familial CeD, GOF-STAT3-CeD and DS-CeD individuals and will investigate the JAK-STAT pathway in the pathogenesis of gluten-specific CD4+ T cells. Overall, the study will provide a proof-of-concept that JAK inhibitors may be beneficial for some Celiac Disease patients with an JAK-STAT dependent signature.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cannabis and alcohol co-use is a major public health concern, but little is known whether specific cannabinoids, alone or in combination with initial drinking, increase or decrease alcohol risk in humans. The project will use a combination of controlled laboratory methods and mobile technology to examine the immediate influences of Δ-9-tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and cannabidiol (CBD) on alcohol consumption in the laboratory and in real life contexts in a person’s daily life. The project will provide information critical to the development of policy, prevention, and treatment efforts to reduce the significant health and economic impact of alcohol use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Overall Narrative The forests and plantations of Southeast Asia form a complex and rich ecology that is home to all major malaria parasite species of public health importance. This study will use state-of-the-art tools in genetics, serology, parasitology, and vector biology to tackle current challenges confronting the malaria-elimination effort in this region, focusing on the factors underlying disease transmission and the rapid spread of Plasmodium knowlesi, a malaria parasite of monkeys that often causes severe and fatal infections in humans. The expected outputs of this project range from fundamental knowledge underlying parasite virulence and transmission to new diagnostic tools for point-of-care and surveillance applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women living in eastern and southern Africa are at high risk for HIV, but effective use of oral pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) for HIV prevention in this population is low. Integrating curable sexually transmitted infection (cSTI) testing for women into African HIV programs may improve PrEP uptake and use through (1) improved identification of women at high risk for HIV acquisition and (2) increased awareness of HIV susceptibility among those diagnosed with a cSTI. This study aims to conduct a randomized trial of cSTI testing to improve PrEP uptake and use among women at high risk of HIV in Uganda, with complementary mixed methods research and mathematical modelling for program optimization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Molecular targeted therapy has emerged as a promising approach for combating complex human diseases. Nonetheless, discovering effective, personalized small-molecule drugs presents a significant challenge. This research program aims to address this challenge by investigating transferable, cell type-specific drug response and combinatorial response models, and therefore provides valuable tools for guiding drug development efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Medications to treat HIV, called antiretroviral therapy or ART, benefit individuals and society, but do not resolve all immune system problems in people with HIV infection (PWH). In this project, we will study whether one part of the immune system - the interferon-stimulated gene, or ISG, system - remains abnormal in PWH even when they are taking ART. This could help identify ways to target new treatments to reduce immune system problems that remain in PWH despite antiretroviral treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Due to its prevalence and synergistic, deleterious effects on overall health and quality of life, arterial stiffness and neurocognitive disorders are public health concerns in older adults living with HIV. Therefore, this proposal is relevant to public health because it seeks to determine the vascular contributions to cognition and the preliminary impact of exercise, which is in accordance with the NIA Strategic Directions for Research as it addresses the development of “effective interventions to maintain health, well-being, and function to prevent or reduce the burden of age-related diseases, disorders, and disabilities.” This project will inform targeted interventions aimed at reducing the public health burden of arterial stiffness and neurocognitive disorders to promote healthy aging with HIV, which is responsive to the NIH’s HIV Research Priorities to reduce HIV- associated comorbidities and coinfections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH CTR AT TYLER
PHR: Project Narrative The human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) enters host cells that fight infection and uses those cells to reproduce itself, causing infected people to become vulnerable to other infections and diseases. Structural dynamics of the HIV surface protein envelope promotes HIV entering susceptible cells via membrane fusion and helps the virus evade antibodies. This research will provide valuable new insights into the time-resolved structural dynamics and allostery of the HIV envelope to better inform the design of envelope-centric interventions such as vaccines, antibody therapy, and anti-viral drugs.
