IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Anopheles stephensi invasion into the African continent has brought serious new challenges for malaria control and elimination in Africa. Knowledge gaps regarding An. stephensi ecology and behavior and the effectiveness of intervention methods in Africa have impeded the development of effective surveillance and control programs. This project will facilitate malaria control in Ethiopia by shedding light on An. stephensi biology, developing new surveillance tools, and identifying cost-effective vector control methods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pregnancy is a high-risk time for acquiring HIV; pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) is an effective, woman- controlled, evidence-based intervention that is recommended during pregnancy in high-risk settings. In Kenya, PrEP is being delivered in some regions during pregnancy and postpartum integrated into maternal and child health services, but scale-up has been sub-optimal. This project aims to develop a community of practice; then test a combination of community of practice, quality improvement, and a training toolkit, to enhance implementation and clinical outcomes; and identify patterns attributes associated with successful implementation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: The research outlined in this proposal will lead to new mechanistic and structural insights into the functioning of bacterial protein organelles – complex megadalton protein assemblies – and their roles in bacterial metabolism, stress resistance, nutrient utilization, and pathogenicity. This research will lay the groundwork for future therapeutic approaches aimed at disrupting protein organelle function to reduce microbial fitness and pathogenicity. Additionally, this work will generate the necessary fundamental knowledge for co-opting protein organelles for future biomedical applications ranging from improving the biological production of drugs to drug delivery and bioimaging.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: The Depression and Anxiety AI-COA™ is a Drug Development Tool (DDT-IST-000014) that uses machine learning to analyze audiovisual signals of clinical interviews and infer HAM-D and HAM-A scores, which will increase power in clinical trials and will get novel therapeutics to market faster, cheaper and safely; ultimately reducing the disease burden to society. The proposed research project will augment the pilot dataset to ensure a more representative sample, re-train the AI-COA™ model, and evaluate its performance and generalizability across different subgroups. The results will reduce uncertainty regarding the design and dimensions of a confirmatory trial that will be proposed in the Qualification Plan (QP) phase.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: DDT-IST-000014: Progressing towards the Qualification Plan of AI-COA™ for Automated Depression and Anxiety Severity Measurement

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Candida spp. is the most common cause of invasive fungal infections among individuals living with HIV and oropharyngeal candidiasis (OPC) is the most frequent opportunistic infection in HIV-infected individuals. We propose the evaluation of hydrogels loaded with two natural compounds with activity against Candida spp. These studies have the potential to develop local treatments that will deliver natural compounds to prevent and treat oral candidiasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The patients infected with HIV require lifelong treatment with antiretroviral drugs. Integrase inhibitor (INI) based two-drug regimen such as dolutegravir-rilpivirine is effective for HIV therapy whereas cabotegravir-rilpivirine intramuscular long-acting nanosuspension is available for HIV prevention and therapy. However, both dolutegravir and rilpivirine have low and fatty meal dependent oral bioavailability and injectable cabotegravir- rilpivirine nanosuspension is invasive and cannot be self-administered. This project will develop novel strategies to improve oral and transdermal delivery of dolutegravir-rilpivirine combination for non-invasive and effective management of HIV infections and for HIV prophylaxis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Single-cell biochemical analysis greatly benefits biomedical research by providing insights into tissue microenvironments, interactions between cell types and specific responses to therapies that cannot be determined using bulk measurements. While unbiased single-cell proteomics has advanced rapidly in recent years, few efforts have been made to extend these measurements to post-translational modifications or to other classes of biomolecules that are readily profiled by mass spectrometry. We will develop technologies for mass spectrometry-based single-cell biochemical analysis beyond the global proteome, which is expected to have a transformative impact on biomedical research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: This project will study immune responses to vaccines from birth to 6 years of age in an ongoing cohort of Kenyan children. We will conduct longitudinal modelling of antigen-specific antibody and T cell responses to determine whether maternal immune activation and early-life exposure to the immune-modulating viruses HIV and cytomegalovirus (CMV), as well as other co-infections, nutrition, and intestinal inflammation, affect vaccine- induced immune responses from birth through middle childhood. These data will inform improved vaccination strategies for children living in areas with a high prevalence of HIV, CMV and malnutrition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Progress in reducing the burden of malaria has recently stalled and even reversed course in some of the highest burden countries of Africa, including Uganda. New strategies are urgently needed to respond to emerging threats including the use of multiple sources of data to better understand malaria risk at the sub- national level and target interventions. The central theme of our program will be to improve malaria surveillance to better assess the impact of malaria control interventions and guide evidence-based utilization of interventions to reduce the malaria burden using an adaptive approach.

IC_NAME: National Center for Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious Diseases
PHR: Project Narrative. This project addresses issues of critical importance to management of vector-borne disease (VBD) in the United States, including those caused by viruses transmitted by mosquitoes (West Nile) as well as tick-borne pathogens like Borrelia burgdorferi (Lyme Disease). Because the upper Midwest is a national hotspot for Lyme Disease and other tick-borne diseases and is notable for endemic transmission and periodic epidemics of West Nile and Eastern Equine Encephalitis viral diseases, we believe the Midwest Center of Excellence for Vector-borne Disease (MCE-VBD) is ideally positioned to address these challenges. The Center is a truly regional organization covering Wisconsin, Minnesota, Illinois, Michigan, Indiana, and Iowa. Center activities will focus the efforts of a formidable group of nationally recognized public health entomologists, epidemiologists, public health experts, and public and private vector control leaders to improve prevention and control practices. The goals include testing and improving existing methods of mosquito and tick management and bite prevention, evaluating new products and methods, supporting the training of the next generation of medical/public health entomologists, and enhancing a strong community of practice. Our efforts will engage academics, public health partners, public vector control agencies, and private pest control operators. Results and conclusions will be directly relevant to both the major VBD issues of the region as well as broadly applicable to public health entomology in the United States.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: CK22-005, The Midwest Center of Excellence for Vector-Borne Disease

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project will unfold though a community-based participatory research process that will be responsive to feedback from impacted communities about how Extreme Risk Protection Orders (ERPOs) are implemented and the need for ERPO implementation processes that recognize the fractured relationships between impacted communities and law enforcement. We will develop an implementation strategy for agencies and organizations to use to implement ERPO in a just and equitable manner.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-CE-22-004, Developing and evaluating an extreme risk protection order implementation protocol with impacted communities

IC_NAME: National Center for Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious Diseases
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Pacific Southwest Center Excellence in Vector-Borne Diseases (PacVec) offers an opportunity to address an urgent and compelling public health challenge—the ongoing rise in vector-borne diseases, particularly those transmitted by mosquitoes and ticks—by leveraging the resources of seven leading research and teaching institutions that have well-established partnerships with mosquito control and public health agencies around our region. Together, we propose a center that is responsive to and reflective of the needs of the broader US Southwest population, with applied research to advance methods to prevent the spread of vector-borne diseases and to train a culturally diverse “community of practice” including public-health scientists and other professionals.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: CK22-005, Pacific Southwest Center of Excellence in Vector-Borne Diseases

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Current ways of collecting employee injuries greatly underestimate the true numbers and risk involved. Our work will improve upon current methods by actively reaching out to healthcare workers to report physical injuries, near-misses, and other health effects by means of a user-friendly mobile application. We will also design a system that will combine information from employee injuries with risk factors from the patient care environment to provide early warnings about high risk areas – leading to improving the health and safety of healthcare workers and can be applied to other industries interested in improving worker safety.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Enhanced injury surveillance using real-time reporting among healthcare workers
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Safety and Occupational Health Study Section[SOH]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Everyone uses the cartilage in their joints for daily activities like walking. Understanding how cartilage responds to the compressions caused by movement will advance basic understanding of the musculoskeletal system. The project is relevant to the mission of NIH, NIA, and NIAMS because it will 1) provide a basic understanding of how chondrocytes respond to mechanical compression and 2) address the question of how compression affects chondrocyte energy utilization. These advances are likely to identify candidate biochemical reactions for drugs to repair and grow cartilage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Bariatric surgery is the most effective treatment for severe obesity, yet more than 20% of individuals experience an alcohol use disorder after surgery due to metabolic and behavioral changes. Despite significant risks of problematic alcohol use among a growing number of individuals undergoing bariatric surgery, there is a lack of knowledge regarding the factors associated with post-surgical alcohol use. The proposed study moves the field forward and impacts public health by identifying the distal and proximal factors that contribute to re- initiation of and episodic alcohol use following bariatric surgery, which could lead to effective interventions to reduce post-surgical alcohol use and prevent the development of an alcohol use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Bacteria are known to generally lack membrane-bound organelles and were assumed to be disorganized. However, we discovered that bacteria contain non-membrane bound organelles called “biomolecular condensates” which organize their biochemical pathways. Therefore, by determining the mechanisms of bacterial “biomolecular condensates” we could identify novel antibiotic targets to combat rising drug resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Psoriatic Spectrum Diseases (PSD), which includes psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis, affects over 8 million individuals in the United States and is associated with chronic pain and loss of function for many patients. We assembled a world class, multidisciplinary team of scientists in PSD to recruit patients with the goal of defining the disease pathways that promote skin and joint inflammation and joint damage through the analysis of molecular signatures in the blood, psoriatic plaques and joint tissues. We will perform state-of the-art technologies to gain knowledge about the key cell-cell interactions and immunologic molecules that promote inflammation and damage with the goal of identifying new therapeutic targets and develop targeted strategies to improve outcomes for patients with psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance This proposal aims to determine key mechanisms by which altered cellular metabolism drives disease risk, for instance an up to 28% higher rate of breast cancer incidence in patients with type 2 diabetes. Our innovative solutions map events driven by the metabolism-linked protein modification O-GlcNAc with control over cellular timing and the cellular location in which they operate, filling critical existing gaps in knowledge that do not track spatiotemporal mechanistic aspects. We apply our “time and space” cellular tools to the oncogenic transcription factor NFkB to determine actionable therapeutic strategies for metabolism-linked cancer risk and establish a well-rounded research program to target fundamental and applied mechanisms able to link metabolism with human disease risks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: This R01 application proposes to develop and test a novel machine learning accelerated online adaptive replanning (MOLAR) solution for magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) guided adaptive radiation therapy through a unique academic and industry partnership. The MOLAR solution aims to fully account for interfraction variations, thereby substantially improving the accuracy and effectiveness of radiation therapy (RT) for cancer. This solution will enable clinicians to routinely practice “image-plan-treat”, a drastic departure from current practice and representing the future of RT delivery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE All organisms make use of redox-based processes for energetic transformations that span the fundamental chemistry of living, as well as the protection of the organism from highly reactive radical-based species. Often these transformations are catalyzed by metal-containing cofactors such as iron-sulfur clusters and heme units that are bound within proteins and enzymes. Understanding the diversity of the strategies that nature makes use of in the design and function of such redox-catalysis is critical to understanding the biological chemistry of ourselves and pathogens alike.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: SHORT NARRATIVE Sepsis is one of the leading causes of death in the US, and African American/Black (AA/B) and LatinX people with sepsis experience lower quality of care and higher rates of complications and death compared with Non- Hispanic White (NHW) populations. We will develop and evaluate a coalition-based leadership intervention to equip eight health systems and their surrounding communities to name and address structural racism and drive measurable reductions in inequities in sepsis outcomes. Findings from the mixed-methods evaluation will be useful across sectors (within and beyond healthcare) seeking to address racial inequities in health outcomes for people with sepsis and other complex health issues.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it develops and assess a novel strategy to improve treatment of individuals with Familial Hypercholesterolemia (FH), namely identifying and treating them through the blood donor program. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This proposal is to understand the repair mechanisms of cells that comprise the alveoli, which form gas exchange area of the lung damaged by cigarette smoking. Focusing on bioactive lipids and their metabolic control, we propose experiments to improve the ability of human lung endothelial cells to withstand the irreversible injury and loss from smoking. We designed experiments to test new therapeutic targets to repair the lung in emphysema models which are of clinical significance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This grant examines how we can stimulate the formation of new brain cells after stroke by using pharmacological drugs to increase molecules that promote neurogenesis and block those which reduce it. We will also study how we can block blood vitronectin in females and the male hormone, testosterone, in males, as they seem to play a unique detrimental role in blocking new cell formation. We expect to identify new treatments to maximize new cell formation after stroke, with different treatments for women and men, which might extend beyond to treatments of other neurological disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH  Chronic postoperative pain is a poorly recognized potential outcome of surgery affecting millions of people every year, making it a significant public health problem. The goal of this project is to determine the efficacy of using the dynamic parameter of diffuse noxious inhibitory controls to predict who might be susceptible to developing chronic postoperative pain and understanding the mechanisms responsible for it. We anticipate the studies will provide genetic and phenotypic biomarkers to guide diagnosis and treatment decisions in chronic postoperative pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Aging is the biggest risk factor for Alzheimer's disease (AD) and related dementias (ADRD). In this application we present data showing ATP synthase to link aging and ADRDs at the molecular level and propose a model on how it extends lifespan and restores memory in aged symptomatic mouse models of ADRD through GeroNeuroProtection. We show ATP synthase to be druggable and how the concept of geroneuroprotection can be expanded to test other geroproprotector drugs identified by the intervention testing program (ITP) for their ability to protect neurons from age-associated toxicities in ADRDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Most of our clinically used antibiotics are derived from a group of small molecules produced by bacteria. We have recently learned that bacteria harbor a much larger potential for the biosynthesis of antibiotic-like molecules, though our understanding of how the corresponding biosynthetic pathways are regulated and how they can be activated is in its infancy. Our research aims to elucidate the mechanisms that lead to the biosynthesis of such molecules, and to use these insights to discover new compounds with possibly therapeutic properties.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Given the lack of data on the relationships between prenatal exposures and stressors with postpartum maternal health, the Maternal And Developmental Risks from Environmental and Social Stressors (MADRES) Center will focus on two maternal health outcomes of utmost concern: maternal depression and cardiovascular health in the years after childbirth. The MADRES Center will examine whether prenatal environmental exposures and social stressors lead to higher depression and/or cardiovascular risk factors postpartum and whether patterns in exposure disparities from the built environment and physical, chemical or social stressors at the residential and neighborhood level relate to individual-level characteristics including allostatic load.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disease of the blood vessels in the brain, known as cerebral small vessel disease (cSVD), is an important modifiable risk factor for decline of mental abilities and dementia. This novel, longitudinal experimental design will use neuroimaging in cognitively normal older adults to study enlarged perivascular spaces, a poorly defined biomarker of cSVD. Clinically informative biomarkers could identify people most at risk for developing cSVD-related cognitive dysfunction and point to avenues of therapeutic improvements for patients with cerebrovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Data from our ongoing Renal Risk Reduction (R3) study in Nigeria has shown that ~37% of our HIV-positive, ART-treated adults have microalbuminuria. We aim to perform more in-depth testing among cohorts of HIV- positive and HIV-negative adults to determine what factors (including hypertension, co-infection with certain viral, parasitic, and bacterial infections that lead to immune activation, and exposure to potentially nephrotoxic ARV medications) contribute most to microalbuminuria in our population. Findings from this study will support the development of interventions to address microalbuminuria in PLWH to reduce kidney and cardiovascular morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative: Circadian clocks regulate daily rhythms in mRNA levels and protein production to control cell physiology, and defects in the clock are associated with sleep disorders, metabolic syndrome, cancer, and heart disease. As a consequence of clock regulation of protein levels and metabolism, many drugs are more effective or more toxic depending on the time of administration. We will investigate a new and unexplored way that the circadian clock regulates the levels and accuracy of protein synthesis, which may provide insights into new approaches to treat clock-associated diseases and improve the timing of drug treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Traumatic stress exposure is a major risk factor for physiological and psychiatric diseases with avoidant behavior as a common indication. The bed nucleus of the stria terminalis (BNST) projects to important regions in the hypothalamus involved in stress regulation, but it is not understood how the functionality of these discrete circuits become hyperactive during stress and promote avoidance over approach in future stressful situations. This proposal will investigate the role of the GABA and glutamate BNST to the hypothalamus projections as a mechanism for stress-induced avoidance, thereby elaborating on the involvement of specific cell-types and circuits in stress psychopathologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Prolonged intensive care unit (ICU) stays are devastating, expensive, psychologically and ethically challenging for providers, patients and families, and disproportionally burdensome to healthcare systems. Traditional risk- prediction models have failed to identify patients at risk of prolonged ICU stays early in their ICU course, hindering advancements in the implementation of evidenced-based practices to prevent its development. This proposal aims to leverage physician knowledge in building better risk prediction models by prospectively and retrospectively surveying physicians and evaluating hospital factors which contribute to the development of a prolonged ICU stay.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Single cell sequencing technologies are incredible tools for characterizing differences in the sequence of cells in a heterogeneous sample. Many questions on the frontier of genomics consider not only the difference in the sequence of these cells, but also how the sequence encodes differences in the phenotype of the cells. This work aims to develop a novel sequencing technology that can simultaneously profile the phenotype and sequence of individual cells, opening the door to entirely new research questions previously unaddresable.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Temporomandibular joint (TMJ) condyle degeneration affects approximately 50M Americans, and tissue- engineered implants have the potential to regenerate osteochondral defects on the TMJ condyle. This proposal will characterize the TMJ condyle of the Yucatan minipig, engineer neocartilage-bone implants with robust interfacial properties, and regenerate osteochondral defects of the TMJ condyle in a large minipig model. Successful completion of this proposal will enhance translation of neocartilage-bone implants toward human use by showing safety and efficacy in an in vivo model, modeled after FDA preclinical definitive animal studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Our laboratory has recently discovered that high cell density quorum sensing signaling promotes a symbiosis between V. cholerae and the model arthropod host Drosophila melanogaster. In particular, the high cell density master regulator HapR activates interactions of V. cholerae with the host intestine that are normally attributed to intestinal symbionts including increased host innate immune signaling, digestion of the mucus-like peritrophic matrix synthesis, and host tryptophan metabolism. Here we seek to elucidate the host and pathogen regulatory pathways that engender this response. These findings will expand our appreciation of the role of quorum sensing in the persistence of the human pathogen V. cholerae and will establish new paradigms for metabolic communication between intestinal pathogens and their hosts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The burden of perinatal HIV-1 infections remains high despite remarkable advances in prevention. The PAVE Collaboratory will accelerate progress towards developing strategies to achieve virus eradication and/or sustained viral remission after cessation of antiretroviral therapy. We plan to address the knowledge gaps relevant to the control and eradication of persistent HIV-1 infection among pediatric populations that are currently a barrier to ART-free remission and cure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human social interactions are important to maintaining our physical and mental health. However, some people experience undesirable outcomes (e.g., alcoholism, depression, addiction) despite having many social ties, and other people report high life satisfaction despite being socially isolated. Here, we use a computational and statistical model-based approach to test how brain sensitivity during social interactions, a measure of how important an interaction is to an individual person, may protect from negative outcomes of social isolation or confer vulnerability despite social connectedness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Heterotopic ossification is the process of abnormal bone formation in soft tissues and is caused by genetic mutations and musculoskeletal trauma, both of which involve inflammation. Commensal microbiota can regulate inflammation in mouse and human hosts. This proposal will determine whether commensal microbiota contribute to HO and potentially define a new mechanism by which to control heterotopic ossification.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The mission of the National Evaluation System for health Technology Coordinating Center (NESTcc) is to catalyze the timely, reliable, and cost-effective development of real-world evidence (RWE) to enhance regulatory, clinical, and coverage decision-making throughout the total product lifecycle (TPLC) of a medical device. NESTcc enables research using real-world data (RWD), serves as a Collaborative Community for ecosystem-wide initiatives, and develops capabilities in Active Surveillance for medical device safety. NESTcc provides the infrastructure and expertise to lead the development of RWE research and surveillance activities.

PROJECT_TITLE: NESTcc Renewal -Continuation of the National Evaluation System for Health Technology (NEST) Coordinating Center (CC)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal employs novel methods to identify key determinants and consequences of concurrent HIV infection and regular cannabis use. We will acquire extensive phenotype data from peripheral and brain markers of immune activation, brain structure, and neuropsychological performance in persons living with HIV (PLWH) receiving combination anti-retroviral therapy (cART) (80 regular cannabis users and 80 non- users) and HIV uninfected (HIV-) controls (80 regular cannabis users and 80 non-users). We hypothesize that cannabis use leads to increases in inflammation in the peripheral and brain compartments. We also hypothesize that phenotypic signatures due to regular cannabis use and HIV will be delineated through neuropsychological performance and neuroimaging measures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Some arthropod-borne obligate intracellular Rickettsia species are among the most virulent human pathogens. Research in the field of Rickettsia-host interaction is stymied by their obligate intracellular life style, and negatively impacted the progress towards development of effective vaccine against these increasingly recognized rickettsioses. Our overall objective is to determine the mechanism by which secreted effectors from virulent Rickettsia species manipulate macrophage polarization and induce autophagy to subvert inflammasome-dependent proinflammatory cytokine signaling to establish host colonization and identify a link that could be exploited for anti-virulence strategy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Field cancerization is a condition of major clinical significance in photo-damaged skin of aging individuals and immune suppressed patients, consisting of multi-focal and recurrent tumor lesions with widespread alterations of surrounding tissues. Our main working hypothesis is that the ULK3 nuclear kinase plays a key role in the field cancerization process and can be targeted for prevention and management of the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Salmonella Typhi causes typhoid fever in humans. 1-5% of those with typhoid fever become asymptomatic chronic carriers primarily due to biofilm formation on gallstones. In this proposal, we will study the epidemiology of disease, genetic and phenotypic traits of the strains, and the association of the infection with gallstones of patients in Kenya where typhoid fever is prevalent. The findings will help better understand the transmission of typhoid fever and the development of chronic carriers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Several diseases are associated with changes in the response of cells to force and altered cell metabolism, but little is known about how these two processes are coordinated. The work in this proposal will provide an understanding for how the response to force is linked to cell metabolism. This information will provide insight into the origin of numerous diseases, ranging from muscular dystrophies and cardiomyopathies to cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE DENV and ZIKV are significant causes of morbidity and mortality worldwide, as half of the world’s population is at risk of DENV and ZIKV infection. DENV and ZIKV vaccines are a global public health priority. To avoid the risk of immune-mediated enhancement of disease, DENV and ZIKV vaccines should induce long-lasting, protective immunity to all four DENV serotypes and ZIKV. This project evaluates a combinatorial DENV-ZIKV vaccine that is designed to induce both humoral and cellular immunity and to provide long-lived protection against infection with DENV1-4 and ZIKV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a shortage of well-trained research-oriented physicians who are prepared to develop new approaches to prevent, diagnose and treat childhood respiratory diseases. This proposal will provide a 10 week summer research fellowship for 12 students following their first year of medical school. The strengths of our research programs in the areas of pulmonary and sleep medicine combined with an enthusiastic faculty and a well-organized summer program provides an excellent opportunity to attract physician trainees at early and critical stages in their careers and increase the likelihood they will want to further pursue research as physician-scientists.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Epithelial cancers, including squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the skin, represent approximately 95% of malignancies plaguing our Veterans and the U.S. population as a whole. SCC itself arises from sunlight- induced mutations and disproportionately affects the U.S. Veteran population due to the intense sun exposure incurred in military service around the world, including from service efforts in Southeast Asia and the Middle East. To invade tissue and exert destructive effects on health, intrinsically abnormal cells in cancers like SCC must interact with surrounding cells and proteins. The current proposal uses human tissue models of invasive cancer to study both cell intrinsic abnormalities in cancer cells, as well as how such abnormal cells interact with surrounding tissue, with an eye to provide insight for future development of new strategies for cancer prevention and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease that leads to restrictions to daily communication through quantifiable changes in speech acoustics, intelligibility, and speech naturalness. This project seeks to understand the causal linkages between acoustic speech features, perceptual characteristics associated with clinical impressions (listener effort, speech naturalness), and communicative participation in ALS. Understanding these relationships will inform treatment designed to mitigate restrictions by 1) guiding the development and use of evidence-based clinical tools that are associated with communicative participation for assessment and monitoring, and 2) identify specific treatment (e.g., articulatory precision, speech prosody) targets to support communicative participation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Social relationships, which are intricately tied to our health and well-being, are necessarily reciprocal. The reciprocal interactions that underpin relationships are accompanied by a synchronization of neuronal activity across individuals, referred to as interbrain correlation, which scales as a function of relationship strength. In this proposal, I will measure and manipulate neural activity in monogamous prairie vole pairs to identify the functional contributions of correlated neural activity between animals within the context of pair bonding.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE P-TEFb phosphorylates the C-terminal domain of the promoter-proximal paused RNA polymerase II as well as other transcription regulatory factors, leading to productive transcription elongation, and it is also an essential host cofactor for HIV-1 transcription. 7SK RNA-protein complexes directly regulate the activity of P-TEFb, sequestering it in an inactive state, but little is known at a structural level about how proteins assemble with 7SK RNA to form a functional RNP and how P-TEFb is hijacked from it by the transactivator of transcription (Tat) protein. Structural studies will provide fundamental molecular insights into and a structural basis for drug targeting of the 7SK RNP that is essential for HIV-1 transcription and therefore escape from latency.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM) is the most common genetic heart disease worldwide with a projected burden of ~2 million affected individuals in the United States and the most common symptom being limitations to physical activity. Approximately ⅓ of these patients have risk for complications with no definitive medical or surgical therapy. Our project will study if exercise training improves exercise tolerance in these patients, and the possible changes in the heart that lead to such improvements, by using sophisticated and modern heart imaging technologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative . Over 1 million older adults with serious illness have major surgery or severe trauma each year, and palliative care delivered alongside surgical care can help relieve patient suffering, improve post- operative outcomes, and reduce healthcare utilization. Although seriously ill surgical patients benefit from palliative care, they are less likely than other patients to receive it. The proposed study will provide an innovative and layered examination of the role of palliative care in surgery in order to directly inform bedside clinical decisions and the implementation of targeted palliative care interventions to improve care for older seriously ill surgical patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is clinically relevant as it could lead to improved health care policies, as well as provide a foundation for future dementia care workforce research in skilled nursing facilities. By studying the dementia care workforce and the training they receive to care for residents in skilled nursing facilities, the project supports the Notice of Special Interest (NOT- AG-20-026) to examine the impact of this workforce on care outcomes. By studying two priority populations: (1) racial and ethnic minority workers and (2) the elderly, the project supports research aimed at improving the quality of care and the work environment in skilled nursing facilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Work is central to the lives of American adults, but the relationship between work, unemployment, and ADRD across the lifecourse has been understudied. This proposal evaluates lifecourse employment trajectories (Aim 1) and lifecourse cognitive demands (Aim 3); we will further create a longitudinal database of job demands (Aim 2). We hypothesize that fewer spells of unemployment and more cognitively stimulating employment are protective for cognitive decline and dementia, independent of education and other sociodemographic factors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The health of the elderly in the United States has improved substantially in recent decades, but immense disparities persist across geographies, race, and socio-economic groups. The objective of the proposed research is to examine the relative roles of two broad-based forces affecting elderly health and health behaviors: person-specific factors and place-specific factors. These findings will generate a clearer understanding of the factors that affect the elderly’s health behaviors and health and shed light on the likely efficacy of alternative policies aimed at improving elderly health behaviors and health.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Excessive alcohol consumption and binge-drinking behavior is a major health concern in the United States, which manifests differently between males and females but lacks efficient treatments. This project will determine whether Neuropeptide Y1 projection-neurons between the central amygdala and lateral hypothalamus are involved in a mouse model of binge-like ethanol consumption. These results will help establish the basis of sex-specific neurocircuitries involved in binge-drinking behavior, ultimately leading to improved treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Public Health Relevance  Young adults are disproportionately affected by HIV and have the highest rates of new infections in the U.S. Contrary to intuition, up to one-third of these young adults suffer from HIV-associated neurocognitive impairment (HAND) that impacts daily functioning and long-term brain function. However, the diagnosis of HAND remains difficult due to a lack of biomarkers to measure ongoing inflammation and an incomplete understanding of its causes. Substance abuse, including high rates of marijuana use among young adults, have untold effects on neurocognition and may modulate levels of inflammation. However, the impact of marijuana on inflammation and cognition is understudied despite increasing use and legalization. This study will combine neuroimaging, neurocognitive testing, and advanced immunology to understand HAND immunopathogenesis and identify novel pathways and measures of inflammation. Results will provide much needed data upon which future clinical trials and clinical practice can better diagnose HAND to develop therapies for this common complication of HIV infection in young adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Chronic kidney disease (CKD) affects 276 million people worldwide and can ultimately progress to complete renal failure and the need for dialysis or transplantation. A hallmark of CKD is the abnormal leak of serum proteins into the urine (i.e., proteinuria), and high urinary protein excretion carries an overall worse prognosis and greater likelihood of disease progression. This proposal targets a novel mechanism for proteinuric CKD, the β-catenin/MCP-1 pathway, the results of which will lead to a new understanding of CKD and contribute to the development of rational treatments for this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed longitudinal study examines the maturation of brain and behavioral mechanisms that motivate the exploration of novel choice options in adolescents and young adults with varying degrees of alcohol use problems. We will test the overarching hypothesis that persistent immaturity of exploratory decision making computations predicts greater alcohol use problems in adolescence and young adulthood. This study uses an innovative computational developmental neuroscience approach to chart the growth curves of different novelty- directed behaviors in adolescence and young adulthood, which could aid in the design of preventative interventions for reducing alcohol use disorder risk in adolescence.

PHR: Project Narrative The antigen presenting molecule MR1 is fundamentally different than any other antigen presenting molecule in the human immune system. It is ubiquitously expressed in tissues, including the lungs, and is poised to rapidly detect intracellular infection. A better understanding of how MR1 presents antigens from Mycobacterium tuberculosis will be critical to the development of future MR1 based therapies against the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative: 40-72% of people living with HIV use cannabinoids to reduce anxiety, stress, depression, antiretroviral drug side effects and/or for pleasure. There is abundant evidence that cannabinoids have anti-inflammatory and immunomodulatory effects; however, the mechanism that underlie these effects are not understood. We propose to determine the effects of cannabinoids on three cells of the central nervous system in the context of HIV infection and antiretroviral therapy treatment in the hopes of identifying anti-inflammatory mechanisms to reverse neurological dysfunction in people living with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Multidrug-resistant Acinetobacter baumannii and Streptococcus pneumoniae among other bacterial human pathogens, are significant threats to global human health. In this proposal, we outline a broad-based experimental strategy to significantly enhance our understanding of two regulatory processes linked to the survival of these organisms in the infected host. How bacterial cells adapt to host-mediated changes in the availability of essential transition metal nutrients and leverage hydrogen sulfide biogenesis and signaling are the focus of these studies, potentially leading to the identification of new targets for the development of novel antimicrobial therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Relevance Syphilis rates in the U.S. are rising. The tests used to diagnose syphilis do not become positive until 3-5 weeks after a person becomes infected. This proposal will evaluate whether a new, molecular test for syphilis is better than older tests in diagnosing people with syphilis soon after they become infected. If the new test is superior, its adoption could lead to earlier diagnosis and treatment, thereby preventing illness in people with syphilis and transmission of the infection to others.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Transplant recipients must take lifelong anti-rejection medications that cause side effects and decrease their ability to defend against infections and cancers. We will use a novel method of liver storage in a rat model of liver transplantation to examine the impact of interventions aimed at increasing regulatory cells within the liver, thereby making the entire organ less likely to cause an immune reaction in the recipient. This exploration of strategies to decrease patient reliance on harmful drugs holds tremendous promise not only for liver transplantation, but all solid organ transplants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Mitochondria play a central role in cellular metabolism, and alterations in the function of this organelle contribute to the development of numerous human diseases. This proposal seeks to understand the regulation and function of a new cell biological pathway discovered in our lab that controls mitochondrial homeostasis in response to cellular nutrient changes. Because of the prominence of mitochondria in cellular metabolism, the proposed studies will enhance our understanding of the cellular regulation of metabolism, and provide new avenues for controlling cellular metabolic health to combat mitochondrial-associated disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are 34 million adults in the U.S. who have diabetes, and half use diabetes medications that put them at risk for having low blood sugar, a serious side effect of diabetes treatment. Doctors can help prevent this side effect by counseling patients on prevention strategies and by making changes to diabetes medications. This application will fund studies to understand how primary care doctors are communicating with patients about low blood sugar, and to develop and evaluate an intervention to help primary care doctors prevent low blood sugar more effectively.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tourette Syndrome (TS) is a chronic neurodevelopmental disorder that is characterized by tics, which are involuntary, repetitive movements and vocalizations. A major limitation in TS healthcare is the lack of clinical assessment measures to objectively diagnose and quantify tics and their severity, one reason that many individuals with TS go unrecognized or experience long delays in diagnosis and treatment access. In this study, we will create a large video and questionnaire dataset of N = 1,000 individuals with tics, code the videos for tic symptoms using human raters to better understand the spectrum of symptoms, and use the coded videos to train a computer algorithm to automatically detect and quantify tics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is to use an agent-based HIV transmission model, the HIV Calibrated Dynamic Model (HIV- CDM), to evaluate the role of the PrEP care continuum in the Getting to Zero/Ending the Epidemic (EHE) campaigns in the United States. We will expand the HIV-CDM to incorporate the behavioral, epidemic, and PrEP continuum data for men who have sex with men (MSM), men who have sex with men and women (MSMW), people who inject drugs (PWID) and heterosexuals. Using the HIV-CDM, we will model the population level impact of PrEP strategies (identification, testing, linkage, access, and retention) on the EHE goals of 50% and 90% reduction in HIV incidence over the next 5 and 10 years, respectively.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is devoted to the development of a novel integrative, structure-based, artificial intelligence driven methodology for rapid chemical probe discovery against any target protein. The candidate molecules will be experimentally validated for three selected targets, transcription factor brachyury, hydrolase NUDT5, and bromodomain BAZ2B, and then optimized, using computational algorithms, into lead molecules to seed chemical probe development. We expect that our AI-based computational approach to convert crystallographically- determined chemical fragments into lead compounds coupled with the experimental validation of computational algorithms will accelerate the discovery of new chemical probes, expand the coverage of druggable proteome, and support future drug discovery studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol use disorder carries tremendous personal and societal costs, and in spite of best clinical efforts, this disorder is characterized by very high relapse rates following treatment. There is a pressing need for novel interventions that prevent alcohol use relapse, and help individuals achieve sustained remission. This study will develop the algorithms that will enable the biosensors embedded in commercially available smartwatches to detect stress in real time using physiological measures of autonomic arousal, which will ultimately be used to trigger smartphone relapse prevention apps to prompt patients with real-time coaching to mitigate alcohol use relapse risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Public Health Impact Statement The proposed study responds to a need for innovative culturally grounded parenting interventions to serve diverse urban American Indian/Alaska Native (AI) communities across the nation and address unacceptably high levels of substance use, risky sexual behavior, depression and suicidality among urban AI youth. This study will test whether a parenting intervention proven efficacious in one state is effective in distinctive and geographically dispersed urban AI communities. It will also demonstrate whether the intervention prevents youth risk behaviors through improvements in parenting skills and family functioning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Type 1 diabetes (T1D) is an autoimmune disease characterized by autoantibody development and beta cell dysfunction prior to the immune-mediated destruction of the insulin producing beta cells of the pancreas and clinical diagnosis. The goals of this proposal are to determine the roles immune dysregulation plays in beta cell dysfunction, the mechanistic origin of the beta cell dysfunction, and whether MHC class I hyperexpression develops and causes the beta cells to be more visible to the immune system. The information gained through this proposal will be used to determine the mechanistic origin of T1D and to identify possible therapeutic targets to halt disease progression.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although early interventions can improve health equity in young children living in poverty, this promise often is not realized because of barriers to family engagement. The proposed study will target co-morbid behavior and sleep problems in early childhood, comparing child outcomes and family response to sleep and behavior interventions and investigating the novel strategy of letting families select their intervention. Results will provide crucial information about how best to engage low-income families for effective early intervention to reduce behavioral and sleep health disparities in toddlers living in poverty.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The goal of this proposal is to elucidate the evolutionary trajectory of the mating type locus (MAT) and how this region controls sexual development and pathogenicity of the human fungal pathogen Cryptococcus. This eukaryotic pathogen is a complex of related infectious species that are of significant global public health impact, and which infect both immunocompromised and immunocompetent individuals to cause life- threatening diseases of the lungs and brain (pneumonia, meningoencephalitis); together these species are responsible for >220,000 infections each year, and more than 181,000 deaths worldwide resulting in >15% of all HIV/AIDS associated deaths. Recent studies, including our own, have implicated auto-antibodies to the cytokine GM-CSF as a risk factor for C. gattii infections in humans, and we will employ animal models to study the impact of loss of GM-CSF signaling as a risk factor for cryptococcal infection, and assess this in the context of the distinct species in this pathogenic complex and the contributions of mating types to virulence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it is expected to advance understanding of the mechanisms underlying blood-brain barrier dysfunction in Alzheimer’s disease with epilepsy as comorbidity. The research is designed to provide a novel therapeutic intervention that repairs blood-brain barrier dysfunction to improve seizure control and reduce cognitive decline in patients that have Alzheimer’s disease with epilepsy. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the missions of the NIH/NINDS and the NIH/NIA that pertain to developing fundamental knowledge that will help reduce the burden of neurological disease and improve the health and well-being in aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Although the ability of the nervous system to predict sensory input is critical for accurate perceptions, coordinated movements, and normal cognitive function, detailed accounts of the underlying neural circuitry and plasticity are lacking. This proposal addresses this challenge by applying novel experimental approaches and theoretical modeling to an advantageous model system where neural correlates for learned predictions are highly accessible to mechanistic investigation. The detailed circuit-level models we plan to develop will provide a foundation for understanding how disruptions of predictive mechanisms contribute to neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Use of oral anti-cancer treatment has increased significantly over the past decade for many cancers. In exchange for eliminating trip to infusion units, cancer survivors on oral agents must self-manage their symptoms at home. This project tests a highly scalable automated intervention for monitoring and managing symptoms during oral anti-cancer treatment, adding a counseling intervention for survivors in need with high psychological distress.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Black individuals have a disproportionately higher burden of insulin resistance and cardiometabolic diseases, the reasons for which are poorly understood. Neprilysin enzyme, which has increased expression in Blacks, breaks down natriuretic peptides and glucagon-like peptide-1, which are important regulators of cardiometabolic health. This study will assess the impact of neprilysin inhibition on the cardiometabolic indices in Blacks, who already have low natriuretic peptide levels and impaired postprandial glucagon-like peptide-1 response, and provide a novel therapeutic pathway for the treatment and control of the burgeoning cardiometabolic disease burden in Blacks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Age related-Meibomian gland dysfunction (ARMGD) is a common eyelid disorder with a prevalence of up to 50% in the US population. Our recently published work and preliminary data show that the overexpression of hyaluronan in Meibomian glands leads to enlarged Meibomian glands and resistance to the development of ARMGD, with a striking 4-fold increase in Meibomian gland volume and an overall 10-fold increase in lipid production at 1 year of age, when compared to age-matched controls. This proposal will characterize the precise composition of the hyaluronan matrix present in Meibomian glands (Specific Aim 1), characterize how this matrix regulates Meibomian gland progenitor cells and prevents ARMGD and dry eye disease (DED) (Specific Aim 2), and allow us to develop novel strategies for treating Meibomian gland dysfunction, ARMGD and DED (Specific Aim 3).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Project Narrative  We propose to investigate the role of experience with tastants at the time of weaning on the development of taste preference in adulthood. The focus on this postnatal developmental window was chosen to determine the neural mechanism underlying gustatory experience when animals transition from relying on their mother’s milk to foraging and consuming foods. We will determine the role of GABAergic inhibitory circuits in the gustatory cortex (GC) in the postnatal development of taste preference. GC is required for taste-motivated behaviors and for learning about the chemosensory and affective dimensions of tastants, but no study to date has investigate the role of gustatory experience on the maturation of this important circuit. Successful completion of this study will provide novel insight in the contribution of early exposure to gustatory stimuli on dietary preferences in adulthood by focusing specifically on the experience-dependent refinement of neural circuits for taste perception.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because dysfunction of membrane trafficking pathways to the lysosome are linked to genetic disease, and exploitations of these pathways are essential for the spread of HIV-1 and other viral pathogens. Membrane trafficking pathways to lysosomes use evolutionarily conserved mechanisms. Therefore, the proposed research is relevant to the mission of NIGMS in understanding biologi- cal processes as a foundation for advances in disease diagnosis, treatment, and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Many individuals with substance use disorders experience significant psychological distress or meet criteria for comorbid psychiatric disorders, such as mood and anxiety disorders. In this proposal we plan to examine the impact of such comorbidity on outcomes of over 5,000 patients with substance use disorders participating in 20 randomized controlled trials of pharmacological and psychosocial treatments sponsored by the National Institute on Drug Abuse. We further aim to examine how such comorbidity and its treatment changes the effect of substance use treatments these individuals receive.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Reproductive health is not only critical for fertility and propagation of the species, but also underlies many key parameters of human health and longevity. This tri-institutional annual symposium will feature reproductive scientists, clinicians, and clinician-scientists in an informal local meeting that will facilitate collaboration and co- operation between institutions that have a strong focus on reproduction and infertility research. The emphasis of this meeting will be on trainee development and will engage neighboring institutions in order to facilitate greater communication among reproductive biologists in the Northeast.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: There is currently no effective treatment for motor neuron (MN) disorders in part due to a lack of understanding of the molecular mechanisms that allow distinct MN subtypes to acquire and maintain their function-defining properties. We recently identified several evolutionarily conserved regulatory factors (e.g., UNC-3, BNC-1, PBRM-1) that control MN subtype development and function, and the proposed research will employ cutting-edge methods to illuminate their molecular mechanism of action. Completion of these experiments will advance our understanding of how MNs become and remain functional, aiming to provide key insights into the etiology, diagnosis or treatment of MN disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is the most effective therapy for adults with major depression; however, some patients fail to respond despite an adequate trial, and ECT can produce negative cognitive effects. In this revised four site, prospective study we propose the first investigation of ECT outcome integrating multiple types of data including clinical and cognitive measures, whole-brain neuroimaging, EEG, and E-field modeling to establish the mechanisms underlying ECT-induced antidepressant response (response biomarkers) and negative cognitive effects (safety biomarkers). Using this approach in patients with major depressive disorder (n = 230), we will confirm the “sweet spot” of ECT dosing in order to maximize antidepressant benefit and cognitive safety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Sophisticated brain imaging techniques are more frequently being used to better detect, understand, develop new medications, and track and prevent drug abuse. Since its inception 19 years ago, we have built and maintained an integrated, multidisciplinary Drug Abuse and Brain Imaging Training Program that currently supports 4 postdoctoral slots to train postdoctoral fellows how to merge imaging technologies with basic and applied clinical research and translational models of drug and alcohol abuse in order to meet these important needs. The extensive breadth of credentials of program mentors offers our trainees the best opportunity to learn to apply these skills in order to further our understanding of the neurobiological bases of the addicted brain.

PROJECT_TITLE: Training in Drug Abuse and Brain Imaging

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Both α-synuclein aggregates in the brain and mutations in the gene GBA1 associate with cognitive decline in Parkinson’s disease and Dementia with Lewy bodies. The goal of this project is the determine if the lipid, glucosylsphingosine, plays a role in toxicity caused by pathologic α-syn and mutant GBA1. We will accomplish this using mouse models of mutant GBA1 and α-synuclein aggregations along with analysis of glucosylsphingosine in cortex and limbic regions from human PD-GBA1 patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Dysregulation of chloride homeostasis caused by chloride channel mutations results in a significant healthcare burden, such as kidney stones (39 million people in US), Osteoporosis (10 million people in US, 43 million people in the risk group). This project will develop “organelle chemotype fingerprinting” and employ this technique to elucidate the physiological role of organellar chloride, which is essential for developing new effective treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE More than one-third of Americans living with an opioid use disorder are publicly insured by state Medicaid or Children’s Health Insurance Plan (CHIP), but many of these state programs fail to provide sufficient access to lifesaving medications for opioid use disorder [(MOUD), i.e., buprenorphine, methadone and naltrexone] in their plan benefits. Research is critically needed to understand how policymakers overseeing Medicaid/CHIP benefit arrays solicit, receive, and use evidence to define their benefit and utilization management policies for MOUD. Aligned with NIDA’s goals to support evidence-based policies supporting substance use treatment, the proposed study will advance policy dissemination science methods to: (1) develop and administer a national survey to Medicaid/CHIP agency and MCO policymakers to identify determinants, mechanisms, and intermediaries that influence their evidence use behaviors; (2) empirically identify and describe distinct subgroups of Medicaid/CHIP agencies and MCOs based on their evidence use behaviors when designing MOUD benefits; and, (3) design and pilot test the acceptability, appropriateness and feasibility of dissemination strategies, tailored to each latent class, for promoting policymakers’ evidence-based decision-making regarding MOUD benefits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Interstitial cystitis/bladder pain syndrome (IC/BPS) is a severe pain condition lacking effective treatments that affects 4-12 million people in the United States. The way individuals with IC/BPS experience symptoms varies widely, and new research shows certain IC/BPS sub-groups differ in their pain and symptom presentations based on the mechanism causing their illness. To help improve treatment for IC/BPS, this project seeks to understand how IC/BPS sub-groups may respond differently to two separate therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Having ascertained and clinically assessed over 65,000 participants (cases and controls) in the Genomic Psychiatry Cohort allows us the unique opportunity to study individuals with highly penetrant rare mutations that, in most cases, cause schizophrenia. We will test the hypothesis that these mutations may converge on shared pathways or targets using induced pluripotent stem cell and induced neuronal cell technologies derived from subject from the GPC with diverse genetic background. The tools and data generated herein will support the mental health field aligning with NIMH priorities, lead to transformative insights into the neurobiology of SZ, and uncover novel targets that may be a launch point for therapeutic discovery.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prenatal stress has devastating effects on children's neurobehavioral development, including elevating the risk for mental health disorders. What remains virtually unknown, however, is how the differential timing of prenatal stress affects the risk for later psychopathology, how this risk is mediated by children's capacity to self-regulate, and the role of the postnatal family environment in exacerbating or reducing this risk. The proposed study will provide essential information about how the timing of prenatal stress, child regulatory capacity, and the postnatal environment interact to increase risk for emerging psychopathology, which will inform strategies for developing and implementing interventions to prevent poor mental health and other negative child outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The specific mediators of neuroinflammation produced by activated microglia that promote neurodegeneration in Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and related dementias (ADRD) are poorly understood. A metabolite of cholesterol that regulates lipid metabolism and promotes neuroinflammation will be examined in this proposal. Successful completion of this project may enable the development of novel therapeutic strategies towards ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative The focal point of this project is to understand how transcription factors regulate the function of astrocytes and circuits in the brain and apply these findings to neurodegenerative diseases, including Alzheimer’s Disease. Given that astrocyte function is linked to a wide spectrum of neurological disease states, including Alzheimer’s and other neurodegenerative diseases, these studies are likely to reveal new mechanisms that can be applied to the understanding and possible treatment of these disorders. The transcription factor families we are studying NFI- and Sox- families, have been implicated in a host of neurological disorders, underscoring the direct connections between these studies and associated disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because the findings will significantly advance our understanding of how natural and synthetic ovarian hormones influence methamphetamine effects and motivation to use methamphetamine. The findings will apply to a large number of US women who currently use oral contraceptives and are expected to provide a strong framework for women-focused approaches to prevention and treatment of methamphetamine and other stimulant use disorders. Thus, the project is relevant to the NIH strategic plan for women's health and sex/gender differences research, to NIDA’s Strategic Plan 2021-2025 specifically the Cross-Cutting Research Topic ‘To Understand Sex/Gender Differences’, and to NIDA’s mission to advance science on the causes and consequences of drug use and addiction and apply that knowledge to improve individual and public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Ascending urinary tract infections (UTIs) commonly result in pyelonephritis (PN), which can lead to clinically significant renal scarring and functional impairment. To date, the cellular mechanisms underlying the development of renal fibrosis and kidney dysfunction following PN remain unknown. Our proposed research is relevant to public health because we will identify the mechanisms by which macrophages and neutrophils mediate the development of renal scarring following PN, which will allow us to establish the foundation for new treatment paradigms to prevent loss of kidney function in patients with PN.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: 1. PROJECT NARRATIVE Estimates from NIDA established that pre-pandemic costs associated with drug misuse and addiction, including harms to individuals, families and society, exceeded $600 billion annually; these are likely to have increased sharply during the pandemic, given the massive increase in opioid overdose deaths alone. Thus, the nation needs a workforce equipped to impact the modifiable risk and protective factors for substance misuse and addiction, particularly among vulnerable populations including racial, ethnic, sexual and gender minorities. Through a mentoring team approach, TranSTAR aims to train future addictions researchers to work across disciplinary boundaries, to produce translatable, rigorous and reproducible research that will inform services to, treatment of, clinical correlates of and policies affecting populations vulnerable to substance use disorders and co-occurring and comorbid conditions.

PROJECT_TITLE: Transdisciplinary Training in Addictions Research

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Hidradenitis Suppurativa (HS) is a prevalent and debilitating disease that results from chronic skin inflammation. Experiments in this grant application will discover why the immune system is chronically activated in the skin of HS patients. In addition, we will determine if enhancing specific immune cells that suppress inflammation can effectively treat this disease. Our results will help establish new therapeutic approaches for patients with HS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Body weight is regulated by neural circuits that track food intake and trigger satiety. While these circuits have long been studied using many approaches, their natural activity patterns during a meal are almost completely unknown. Here we propose to apply approaches from systems neuroscience and physiology to define how these key neural circuits that control satiety are dynamically regulated in mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE  In our work we’ve found that Heat shock protein 90 (Hsp90) has a crucial role in regulating opioid signaling in brain and spinal cord. We’ve further found that isoform-selective Hsp90β inhibitors can enhance the potency of morphine to control acute and chronic pain, while reducing tolerance and leaving constipation and reward unchanged. In this proposal we will thus develop optimized Hsp90β inhibitors based on our KUNB106 scaffold; this will result in a drug that could be given to humans in order to reduce the doses of opioid needed to control pain, resulting in fewer side effects, most notably tolerance and addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Blood pressure is an important, modifiable risk factor for poor clinical outcomes in hemodialysis patients and yet the optimal treatment of blood pressure remains poorly understood in this population. Our hypothesis is that outcomes will improve in hemodialysis patients if physicians measure and treat home blood pressure, rather than blood pressure measured at the time of dialysis, which is the current practice and what guidelines recommend. We propose a 2-center cross-over randomized controlled trial (N = 200) to test whether targeting a home vs. pre-dialysis systolic blood pressure <140 mmHg will reduce rates of intradialytic hypotension, an important clinical outcome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Several virulence factors have been proposed to contribute to the ability of Porphyromonas gingivalis, a dental pathogen closely associated with periodontitis, to colonize and thrive in diseased sites. In this application the ability by which P. gingivalis lipid A, an essential component of the cell wall and prime contributor to immune evasion, modulates its structure will be characterized. We have identified three key P. gingivalis lipid A modifying genes and we will determine how they are regulated, play a role in virulence factor production, and how their expression correlates to health and disease clinical status.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: Project Narrative  There is a need to develop an effective therapeutic strategy that prevents or alleviates age-related cognitive dysfunction. Using a mouse model of aging, this proposal focuses on testing the efficacy of a non-invasive, intranasal administration of extracellular vesicles generated from human induced pluripotent stem cell-derived neural stem cells for maintaining better cognitive and memory function in old age. If successful, the approach would provide the benchmark for the clinical translation of extracellular vesicle therapy to combat age-related dementia in the future.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The strongest genetic risk factor for developing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease is carrying the E4 allele of APOE, which codes for the protein apoliprotein E (APOE). IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Characterizing mechanisms that create and sustain racial disparities in Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD) is of critical importance to the diverse, aging population of the U.S. The proposed project will fill an important void in examining the extent to which neighborhood resources contribute to disparities in brain and cognitive aging, as well as whether social networks can buffer against neighborhood disadvantage. Results could have implications for interventions targeted at multiple levels to prevent or delay age-related cognitive decline and reduce racial disparities in ADRD.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The formation of new nerve populations within and around solid tumors plays an active role in cancer development, progression, and treatment resistance. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative A common effect of alcohol and many other drugs of abuse is the disruption of presynaptic long-term synaptic depression in striatal neurocircuits and restoring this lost plasticity may be therapeutic for treating alcohol and substance use disorder and/or pathological sequelae associated with long-term drug abuse. Here we develop an innovative technique to decipher components of the presynaptic interactome that are engaged during the induction of striatal synaptic plasticity at distinct striatal synapses (corticostriatal versus thalamostriatal) that display different forms of plasticity and have differential responses to in vivo alcohol exposure as well as determine how alcohol affects those presynaptic interactomes. In using this novel approach, we hope to identify previously unknown signaling proteins that may be promising therapeutic targets for pharmacological intervention in alcohol use disorder and addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: IMPERIAL COLLEGE OF SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY AND MEDICINE
PHR: Next-generation influenza vaccines need to induce long-lived heterosubtypic immunity, particularly in the upper respiratory site of initial infection. Existing technologies are insufficient for profiling mucosal humoral immunity at the functional level required for testing future vaccines. To resolve this limitation, this proposal aims to partner highly standardised sampling of the upper airway by nasosorption with flexible, scalable, sensitive assays for neutralisation and Fc- dependent antibody function.
