IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Establishment of a multi-center biobank of patient-specific pluripotent stem cells for pediatric sepsis research. PROJECT NARRATIVE:  Children with sepsis—a life threatening condition due to an abnormal patient response to an infection— represent a mixed group with varying underlying biology. Our inability to easily study differences in patient- specific biology at the cellular level has prevented the development of the right drugs for the right patients. To address this problem, we seek to establish a vast collection of induced pluripotent stem cells from children with sepsis, which can be used to better understand disease mechanisms and improve patient health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is the fifth most common cancer in the world with over 600,000 new cases per year and a dismal five-year survival rate at less than 9%. Most HCC patients have chronic liver disease resulting mainly from HCV/HBV infection, chronic alcohol consumption or aflatoxin exposure. Although most patients that develop HCC have cirrhosis or hepatitis, the mechanisms promoting HCC differ between pathologies such that not all cases, in principle, should be treated the same. Thus, it is important to understand the mechanisms that promote HCC due to chronic ethanol exposure, a form of HCC that is on the rise as HCV and HBV infections are being better prevented and treated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Colorectal cancer is the second leading cause of cancer death in the United States and disparities in mortality by race and ethnicity persist. This application seeks to elucidate why colorectal cancer disparities may persist even when similar rates of screening have been achieved by comprehensively evaluating the entire screening continuum from the tests used and screening quality to follow-up care and guideline-concordant treatment in a dynamic cohort of about 3.8 million people per year over the 2003-2019 17-year period. We will perform mixed- methods studies among people 45-85 years old in Kaiser Permanente in both Northern and Southern California and model the extent to which differences along the screening process cumulatively contribute to disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative There are still no effective drugs to treat Alzheimer’s disease (AD). However, there are resilient people who have evidence of disease pathology without displaying cognitive decline. Non- coding RNAs (ncRNAs) are powerful regulators of coding and non-coding gene expression, critical for maintaining homeostasis, resisting cellular stresses, and preventing disease processes. Here we systematically identify ncRNAs that regulates the resilience in AD using comparative transcriptomic analysis, explore the regulatory mechanisms these ncRNAs in neural cells, and validate their protective roles using advanced three-dimensional human neural cell culture models of AD. If successful, future trials on safe-to-use non-coding RNAs could be performed to protect humans against Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative The long-term goal of this research is to decipher cardiovascular health outcomes in adults with FASD and to identify novel molecular mechanisms and biomarkers for ethanol-induced congenital heart defects and subsequent cardiac dysfunction in adulthood. We propose to accomplish these goals through a retrospective study on adult patients with and without FASD and by evaluation of a zebrafish model of embryonic alcohol exposure. Our findings will enable early identification or intervention in at-risk patients with FASD and expand our mechanistic understanding of the lasting effects of prenatal alcohol exposure on the heart.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative By 2030, nearly 20% of the US population is expected to be 65 years of age or older, and by 2050, 88.5 million US citizens are projected to be over 64 years old. Given the rate at which the national population is aging, it is important to understand how cognitive and emotional processes change across the lifespan and identify processes associated with healthy aging. Such information can inform interventions to promote emotional well-being and subsequent mental and physical health in older adults, as well as people of all ages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS THE STATE UNIV OF NJ NEWARK
PHR: Project Narrative Perturbed lipid metabolism in aging, Alzheimer’s disease (AD), and AD-related neurodegenerative disorders impacts glial lipid storage and overall lipid profiles in brain cells. Elucidating the mechanisms underlying the crosstalk between different lipid metabolic pathways will inform potential therapeutic targets and strategies. This project aims to define the role of TTYH1 in coordinating lipid storage and lipid efflux in glial cells, and its impact on neuronal homeostasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer’s Disease [AD] is a progressive degenerative disorder of unclear etiology, though abnormal hypoperfusion, metabolic deficiency, and stroke may enhance AD progression. Our studies will examine the mechanisms leading to abnormal hypoperfusion and metabolism in AD, differentiating effects of aging versus degeneration, in a mouse model of AD. We will study hemodynamic supply of metabolic substrates to the brain and particularly pericytes and cerebrovascular mechanisms, which are signaled by neurons for enhanced blood flow. These studies may lead to treatments which may be able to improve brain metabolism based on identifying relevant mechanisms through manipulation of abnormal neurovascular coupling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application has the goal of continuing to provide education and training to nurses at the predoctoral and postdoctoral level in the field of omics research. Nurses are uniquely positioned to bridge the gap between omics research and clinical practice. They interact with patients at all stages of life, and in all clinical arenas. There continue to be few opportunities for long-term laboratory-based training in the conduct of cutting-edge omics research and such training opportunities are essential because nearly every condition studied by nurse scientists has an omics component. Our objective is to train talented Nurse Scientists, at the beginning stages of their careers, to develop research trajectories related to the application and evaluation of omics in improving patient outcomes.
PROJECT_TERMS: Academic Training;Genomics;Nurses;Research Training;Targeted Research
PROJECT_TITLE: Targeting Research and Academic Training of Nurses in Genomics

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE People attending federally qualified health centers (FQHCs) typically have limited access to acupuncture, an evidence-based symptom management intervention. This study will assess the feasibility of implementing acupuncture at an FQHC to alleviate multiple symptoms experienced by breast cancer survivors during endocrine therapy. Long-term, this study is the first step toward ensuring equal access to this evidence-based intervention. Results will provide the foundation for rigorous studies to test the effectiveness of integrating acupuncture into FQHC oncology clinic to support medically underserved breast cancer survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Plant natural products are the source of ~25% of FDA-approved drugs but drug discovery and development from plants is challenging due to rediscovery of known compounds and difficult scaled production and diversification of lead structures. To overcome these bottlenecks, the proposed research will develop a gene-guided approach to systematically discover new cyclic peptide natural products from plants by (a) mining plant genomes for new peptide biosynthetic genes, (b) biosynthesis of plant peptide lead structures via new plant peptide cyclases and (c) production of plant peptide libraries from diversified plant peptide precursor genes. Cyclic plant peptides are an attractive test case for gene-guided discovery of plant natural product drugs as they constitute lead structures for antiviral and anticancer therapy due to high oral bioavailability, stability and target specificity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to understand how a fungal meningitis pathogen, Cryptococcus neoformans, manipulates the innate immune system to enable infection. We have identified a protein secreted by this fungal pathogen that converts macrophages, key cells of the immune system, into an ineffective state. Deciphering how this is accomplished at the molecular level has the potential to transform our understanding of invasive fungal infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: HIV-1 is able to persist in the face of effective antiretroviral therapy (ART). Identification of cellular reservoirs that support viral persistence are needed to guide the design of viral cure strategies. While HIV-1 can infect T cells and myeloid cells such as microglia, there are few studies being explored to assess the role of myeloid cells in viral persistence. The proposed studies employ novel tools developed by us that allow interrogation of myeloid cell reservoirs in anatomic sites such as the CNS and that have the capacity to reveal the role played by myeloid cells in HIV-1 persistence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Although astrocytes, the most abundant glia cells in the brain, have been proposed to play important roles in the neural circuitry and behaviors, a mechanistic and comprehensive understanding of the active functional roles of astrocytes in neural circuitry and behaviors is largely lacking partially due to the difficulty in modeling the complex astrocyte activity data. We thus propose to apply advanced machine learning and data science theory to develop advanced computational methods and analytical tools. A deep understanding of bi-directional astrocyte-neuron signaling in health and disease could lead to novel therapies for brain disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Lipid accumulation is one of the major pathological features in the brain of patients with Alzheimer’s dementia (AD). This project will identify specific brain lipid species associated with cognitive decline and AD pathologies using postmortem brain tissue samples collected by two large population cohorts of aging and dementia. Such results will help us understand why lipid accumulation in the aging brain affects AD and are likely to lead to novel therapeutics for AD prevention and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although signaling and endocytic trafficking of the epidermal growth factor receptor have been studied in the context of mitogenic activation of cells and tumorigenesis, the molecular events that regulate EGFR levels and signaling, and their contribution to oral tumorigenesis are largely unknown. Studies proposed in this application will determine, for the first time, how an essential centriole biogenesis protein, CPAP regulates the ESCRT pathway to suppress EGFR signaling, and prevent EMT and tumorigenesis in oral cancer, independent of its function on the centrioles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inheritance of the apolipoprotein (APO) E4 gene is the strongest genetic risk factor identified to date for late onset Alzheimer's disease (AD), an age-related debilitating brain disorder that afflicts more than six million Americans and their families. Although the mechanisms by which APOE4 modifies the risk of AD are not fully understood, compelling evidence indicates that the pathogenic effects of APOE4 are mediated by lipid-related pathways involving the cell's powerhouse – mitochondria. The present study aims to assess the impact of mitochondrial lipidomic dynamics and its interaction with different APOE isoforms on brain aging and the progression of AD and identify novel molecular targets and/or pathways that can be harnessed as diagnostic biomarkers and/or for therapeutic development to block pathogenic brain aging and AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative For people living with HIV (PLWH), achieving, and maintaining viral suppression has critical benefits for their health and for reducing the risk of transmitting HIV to others. Viral suppression is thus a critical cornerstone of the US program to end HIV, but over a third of people in the US living with HIV do not have a suppressed viral load. We propose to use observational epidemiology methods to develop a nuanced understanding of the circumstances that surround gaining, sustaining, or losing viral suppression in men who have sex with men and transfeminine people.

PHR: We propose a new imaging technique for tumor detection based on a molecule that is present on the blood vessel walls of most tumors, both primary and metastatic. The method is expected to detect very small, incipient tumors, at the stage for which the chance of successful treatment is very high. This pilot project is aimed at evaluating the performance of the method using mice, in preparation for translation to clinical studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Tissue resident macrophages (TRMs) are sentinels of the environment that maintain organ homeostasis, yet they remain refractory to standard experimental approaches limiting our understanding of their underlying regulatory mechanisms. We developed a discovery pipeline combining functional genetics with a unique ex- vivo model of lung-specific TRMs, alveolar macrophages, that will enable fundamental discoveries of the TRM functions and maintenance. My research program will leverage these tools to identify new signaling pathways, transcriptional networks and functional mechanisms required for TRMs to maintain tissue homeostasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative:  Endovascular neurointerventions are critical for treating unruptured aneurysms; however, many such surgical procedures fail due to an inability to maneuver microcatheters safely through tortuous or complex cerebral anatomies. The goal of this research is to engineer and evaluate 3D-nanoprinted microfluidic circuitry- based soft robotic microcatheters that enable real-time multi-directional steering and navigation control by the neurointerventionalist. We expect to improve catheterization efficacy while reducing complication rates in the treatment of cerebral aneurysms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Co-occurring alcohol use disorder and posttraumatic stress disorder (AUD/PTSD) is prevalent among U.S. veterans, and existing AUD/PTSD treatments are associated with high patient dropout. We will conduct a pilot randomized controlled trial in a sample of veterans with AUD/PTSD to test the feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary effects of Behavioral Activation, an integrated and recovery-oriented treatment, on subjective (clinical) and objective (geospatial) outcomes. This project will improve the lives of the nearly two million U.S. veterans with AUD/PTSD by providing them with an effective and acceptable treatment option for their health and well-being.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT SUMMARY Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are essential medications for the treatment of chronic pain, but their threat of kidney toxicity limits their availability to many patients. Currently, there is no monitoring strategy for kidney safety other than using the serum creatinine, which is neither sensitive nor specific for detecting actual kidney injury from NSAIDs. Our goal in this proposal is to develop an NSAID Kidney Monitoring Panel that would allow the safe use of NSAIDs for patients in chronic pain who are also at high risk for kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE With a doubling in the number of older cancer survivors in just a few decades preventing falls, dysfunction and disability from systemic cancer treatment is an urgent public health issue. Our phased R21/R33 study will advance an infrastructure advancing the use of digital biomarkers and related technologies for research on functional aging and survivorship in cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will validate low-cost mobile sensors (smartphones, smartwatches, home-based environmental sen- sors) to capture sleep, physical activity, location, and environmental hazards in and around the homes of 1000 Latina women as proxy measures of metabolic syndrome (MetS) risk. The sensing data will be ground-truthed using clinical measures of MetS and models of MetS-related brain vulnerability networks among a subset of participants (n=225). Our transdisciplinary approach uses gold-standard clinical measures to validate integrated measuremnets of mobile sensing devices as a cluster proxy assessment of MetS risk and neuroimaged MetS- related brain vulnerability.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because the discovery of mechanisms by which intestinal microorganisms influence the central nervous system is expected to lead to increased understanding and new treatments for many neurological diseases and functional intestinal disorders. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Project Narrative The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has profoundly affected the HIV prevention and treatment efforts in the Deep South (including South Carolina), which disproportionally endures the dual epidemics of HIV and COVID-19. The HIV service interruptions during COVID-19 pandemic could have long-term negative impacts on people living with HIV and our efforts to end the HIV epidemic by 2030. The proposed research can lead to a better understanding of complicated HIV service interruptions at multiple socioecological levels in SC, the negative effects of such interruptions on key outcomes of the HIV treatment cascade, and the resilience resources that can mitigate these effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myocardial ischemia-reperfusion (IR) injury is a major clinical challenge in treating patients suffering from myocardial infarction (MI) as there is no effective therapy to date. In this work, we will employ new mouse models, cell culture, proteomics, molecular and cell biology techniques, and small molecule activators of LonP1 to study the mechanisms of LonP1 mediated cardioprotection in mitigating IR injury. Our proposed work will delineate how LonP1 remodels Complex-I, its integrity, and activity during early IR, thereby reducing excess mtROS and preventing oxidative damage-induced cardiomyocyte death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative There were 4.95 million deaths associated with antimicrobial resistance in 2019 worldwide, with antibiotic- resistant Staphylococcus aureus as the leading causative pathogen in the US. More effective antibiotics with unique mechanisms of action are needed to combat the global crisis of antimicrobial resistance, which has further worsened due to COVID-19 pandemic. AimMax Therapeutics seeks to develop a novel antibiotic to treat serious multidrug-resistant gram-positive infections including those with MRSA and VRE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative. The diagnosis and prognosis of early stage lung cancer, the leading cause of cancer deaths in the U.S., is challenging and there are no useful biomarkers leading to unnecessary invasive tests and poor outcome among those that have recurrence of disease. In this project, we will uncover microbial and host signatures to develop tests that can predict diagnosis and prognosis of early stage lung cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The co-occurrence of hazardous drinking exacts a significant burden on patients, providers, and health care systems. In line with NIAAA initiatives to increase greater understanding of individual differences factors that may underlie the etiology and maintenance of alcohol misuse and its comorbidities and NIH’s UNITE initiative’s aim to support “new research on health disparities, minority health, and health equity,” the proposed work will examine the influence of microaggressions (MAs) (accounting for non-discriminatory daily stress) on alcohol use motivation, drinking, and alcohol-related problems as well as pain experience among non-Latinx Black adults who are hazardous drinkers with chronic pain. Through this research, we also will explore mediational processes and moderators in the MA-hazardous drinking/pain relations that will inform future intervention and prevention efforts for this neglected health disparities group. 3

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: As more states have legalized cannabis, high-potency products such as concentrates have become more popular. However, very little is known about how the use of these products affects mental health or psychosocial functioning. Given the increasing prevalence of concentrate use, it is imperative to clearly understand how these increasingly popular, high-potency cannabis products affect mental health outcomes. This project will examine how concentrate use affects mental and psychosocial functioning by examining concentrate users over time, and also, by utilizing a co-twin control design, compare twins who use concentrates with their co-twin.

PHR: Project Narrative Cytokine-induced memory-like (ML) NK cells are a promising cellular therapy for treating hematological malignancies as demonstrated in early phase clinical trials. This proposal aims to understand the mechanisms underlying NK cell reprogramming. These findings will provide insights on how to improve ML NK cells in the clinic on treating malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Recent studies demonstrated that red blood cells (RBCs) play an active role in venous thromboembolism (VTE). RBC abnormalities observed in sickle cell disease (SCD) influence venous clot structure, resulting in an unusually high incidence of pulmonary embolism (PE) relative to deep vein thrombosis - a phenomenon which we have termed “the sickle cell paradox”. This paradox is also seen in subjects with sickle cell trait. This proposal aims to identify the best approach to attenuate this disease-specific form of VTE through a greater in- depth understanding of the mechanisms of thrombosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Our research is relevant to public health because it addresses the most relevant shortage of organs for transplantation. Optimizing the utilization and outcomes of older transplanted organs is expected to reduce mortality and morbidity rates of wait-listed patients with end-stage-organ-failure. Understanding the impact of aging on inflammation is highly relevant to public health as it addresses an area of increasing clinical significance and our proposal is of high translational relevance as it dissects mechanisms of inflamm-aging and offers novel treatments that improve organ quality and transplant outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Public health relevance/ project narrative. Since anemia affects ~30% of persons worldwide and is a major cause of morbidity, understanding red cell maturation is important. By investigating mouse models in vivo and cells from Diamond Blackfan anemia (DBA) patients in vitro, we will determine how and why red cell precursors die. These studies should provide insights into the molecular and cellular processes regulating normal red cell differentiation and should define new therapeutic strategies to ameliorate anemia in DBA and other disorders characterized by ineffective red cell differentiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WALTER AND ELIZA HALL INST MEDICAL RES
PHR: Project narrative There are several common barriers to malaria elimination that countries in the Asia-Pacific region are facing – increasingly heterogenous transmission driven by asymptomatic infections, environmental change affecting malaria ecology, emerging drug and insecticide resistance, the resilience of P. vivax malaria and resource constraints. We will address these barriers to elimination through a coordinated program of epidemiological and transmission studies that combines epidemiological, clinical and entomological investigations, innovative molecular and serological diagnostics with advanced mathematical transmission modelling across 5 field sites in Cambodia and Papua New Guinea that span the transmission gradient from very low to high. By developing better surveillance approaches that allow better targeting of intervention, improving P. vivax case management, monitoring the changing vector distribution and behavior and tracking the spread of drug and insecticide resistance, evidence from our research will inform program action to accelerate towards zero malaria in the region.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disruption of intestinal homeostasis is a major cause of sustained inflammation in people with HIV (PWH) despite antiretroviral therapy and this leads to increased morbidity and mortality due to inflammatory non-communicable diseases (NCDs) such as diabetes, cardiovascular disease, obesity, and end organ damage. Maintenance of intestinal homeostasis requires coordinated functions of tissue resident immune cells and several epithelial cell lineages; therefore, this proposal will characterize the mechanistic role of intestinal CD8+ T cell immunometabolic function and its contribution to maintaining epithelial homeostasis. Results from this work will provide new insights to develop novel strategies to target mucosal CD8+ T cells and improve health outcomes for PWH.

PHR: OVERALL NARRATIVE Despite significant reductions in cases, malaria remains a major public health problem in India, the world's most populous country, causing important morbidity and mortality. The Center for the Study of Complex Malaria in India is a collaborative scientific research institute comprising United Kingdom, United States, and India malaria experts and dedicated staff at four field sites, working towards the goal of enhancing malaria intervention and control programs in India.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Malaria parasite infections and disease continue to cause considerable morbidity and mortality in Malawi. This research will ascertain why some existing malaria control practices have become less effective in reducing contact with the mosquito vector and in decreasing the incidence of malaria disease. A new anti-malaria vaccine for children and bed nets with new compounds will be evaluated for their ability to reduce disease risk.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sexually transmitted diseases (STD) such as gonorrhea and chlamydia are common among men living with HIV and men taking pre-exposure prophylaxis. Innovative strategies for STD/HIV prevention are important for developing a comprehensive HIV response, especially in low and middle-income countries. The proposed midcareer award provides protected time to support mentorship of new investigators undertaking patient- oriented HIV prevention research, building capacity for further HIV prevention research in global settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Flux through oxidative phosphorylation is regulated by mechanisms that are not completely understood. The proposed research will address fundamental questions on how the lipid composition of mitochondrial membrane regulates bioenergetics. Findings from these studies have implications for health and disease across multiple organ systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE  Mutations in the mitochondrial genome play an important role in a number of devastating maternally inherited diseases, as well as a number of human relevant pathologies, including cancer, sarcopenia, and neurodegener- ation, but the cellular mechanisms that give rise to them or modify their presence are poorly understood. This project is designed to take advantage of cutting edge technologies to test fundamental hypotheses involving what cellular mechanisms modify their presence. The end result will be a better understanding of mitochondrial biology and the role of mitochondrial mutation in human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF SCIENCES, TECH & TECH OF BAMAKO
PHR: Project Narrative: Sub-Saharan Africa region continues to bear the brunt of the global malaria burden despite wide deployment of control interventions. This multidisciplinary program will contribute to improve our understanding of the changing malaria epidemiology and transmission in relation with control interventions. We will developpe, evaluate and optimize ongoing malaria control strategies to produce maximum impact on transmission interruption and elimination through implementation research. We will characterize critical barriers related to changing epidemiological patterns, drug and insecticide resistance to develop adaptive evidence-based interventions to meet the evolving needs of control programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The theme of this Southern and Central Africa International Center of Excellence for Malaria Research renewal application is to harness innovation to transform malaria surveillance into key interventions, derived from the World Health Organization’s Global Technical Strategy for Malaria 2016–2030. These innovative approaches will include the use of crowd-sourced data, volatilomics, machine learning forecasting models, data visualization tools at small spatial scales for local use, and periodic serological surveillance using residual blood specimens. By harnessing innovation and exploring novel data streams, malaria metrics, analytical methods, surveillance tools, and their applications to fill existing knowledge gaps and inform strategies, we hope to transform malaria surveillance into key interventions in collaboration with the Zambian National Malaria Elimination Programme, the President’s Malaria Initiative, and other partners to achieve national and regional malaria control and elimination goals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV can develop resistance to drugs, which leads to increased viral load that harms patients and increases HIV transmission. Identifying drug resistance requires identifying patients who have high viral load and testing virus for mutations known to cause drug resistance. We will develop a test that rapidly tests for viral load, and for patients failing therapy, tests their virus for drug resistance mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROGRAM NARRATIVE In recent years, the global incidence of malaria has been rising, primarily driven by a subset of high-burden countries in sub-Saharan Africa, including Cameroon. This program aims to address this urgent problem by conducting comprehensive research on humans, vectors, and parasites using innovative approaches and technologies in selected study sites representing all strata of malaria transmission. The proposed two interrelated projects will systematically investigate the fundamental mechanisms underlying persistent high-level malaria transmission to inform the national malaria control program to develop effective malaria control strategies in Cameroon.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As people living with HIV experience longer lifespans (even reaching normal life expectancy) due to highly active antiretroviral therapy, cardiovascular disease (CVD) has emerged as a leading cause of morbidity and mortality. The proposed research project aims to identify potential microbial features, biomarkers, and targets for individual CVD risk prediction and prevention. This holds promise for personalizing medication, such as therapeutic modulation of the microbiome and other interventions, to avert CVD among HIV-infected patients.

PHR: The objective of this project is to fill the knowledge gap of how an FDA-approved oral formula of small molecules, tRES+HESP, can enhance the new blood vessel formation in treating non- healing wounds in diabetic patients as a topical application. We will evaluate the therapeutic potential of tRES+HESP and its underlying molecular mechanisms in human vascular endothelial cells in Aim 1, and in a newly developed diabetic chronic wound animal model in Aim 2, using a combination of cell culture and animal studies (for causal mechanisms in vitro and in vivo) and cutting-edge proteomics studies (for global analysis of cell signaling & unbiased discovery). The outcome of the proposed research will determine the efficacy of topical application of this formula, tRES+HESP, in diabetic wound healing, and will unveil underlying molecular mechanisms for its beneficial effect.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In South Africa, the country with the highest HIV prevalence (19%), comorbid problems such as depression, post-traumatic stress, and food insecurity synergistically enhance one another (i.e., syndemic problems) and are associated with worse HIV outcomes such as poorer antiretroviral therapy (ART) adherence and worse viral load. This study proposes to: 1) explore the complex interrelationships between syndemic problems and explore attitudes to potential intervention components; 2) develop a multilevel intervention to address syndemic problems and improve adherence (CBT-SA); 3a) assess the feasibility and acceptability of CBT-SA in a pilot RCT; and 3b) identify barriers and facilitators of CBT-SA engagement. If the CBT-SA intervention is found to be feasible and acceptable, and findings suggest clinically meaningful improvement, the multilevel CBT-SA intervention could be further examined for effectiveness, which could advance the field toward the ending the HIV epidemic initiative.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Cancer immunotherapy stimulates a patient’s own immune system to fight off cancer, offering the promise of eradication and a durable cure, however, the majority of breast tumors fail to respond. This project will develop a new targeted nanotherapy strategy to deliver stimulatory compounds to specific immune cell types in breast tumors to convert the tumor to a state that is responsive toward immunotherapies. The project will focus on engineering new therapeutic nanomaterials to maximize safety and effectiveness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative South Africa has made progress towards their 95-95-95 goals, yet a substantial proportion of the population do not test regularly. To reach people who otherwise may avoid testing, we propose to build on our successful healer-initiated HIV counseling and testing pilot to conduct a cluster randomized controlled trial in 42 clinical catchment areas to evaluate an expanded Healer-Initiated HIV Testing and Linkage to Care intervention in rural South Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: RELEVANCE Organophosphate-based nerve agents such as sarin, soman, and venomous agent X are among the most toxic chemicals known for humankind, exposure to which can lead to high mortality and substantial morbidities in survivors. The current medical countermeasures are of doubtful utility for civilian populations as they must be administered within minutes of an attack to be effective. Proposed research aims to evaluate a novel, potent, drug-like inhibitor of an emerging therapeutic target in mice exposed to a prototypical organophosphate and may lead to a delayed treatment for nerve agents-triggered neurotoxicity and long-term neurological sequelae.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Cerebral small vessel disease (CSVD) affects small penetrating arteries, arterioles, capillaries, and venules, causing small subcortical infarcts, lacunae, white matter hyperintensity, enlarged perivascular spaces, cerebral microbleeds, and brain atrophy. CSVD pathology is a leading cause of cognitive impairment and dementia. This project aims to assess the role of monocytes DII4 in CSVD in the context of HIV infection. The study's results will provide essential data that will inform the design of appropriate clinical interventions to slow down the progression of CSVD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: GRADUATE SCHOOL OF PUBLIC HEALTH AND HEALTH POLICY
PHR: ICARE Project Narrative In many countries including low-and middle-income countries (LMIC), where 90% of adolescents live, adolescents can consent to sexual and reproductive healthcare but require parent/guardian permission to participate in research before age 18. This creates a barrier to adolescent research participation – leading to adolescent underrepresentation and systematic exclusion from biomedical and behavioral studies and subsequent disparities in developmentally tailored HIV prevention research. ICARE will advance research bioethics and biomedical HIV prevention research by evaluating whether early and middle adolescents in Uganda demonstrate adult-level cognitive capacity to consent to biomedical HIV prevention research.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Chlamydia trachomatis (CT), Neisseria gonorrhoeae (NG), and Trichomonas vaginalis (TV) infections in pregnancy are associated with fetal loss, preterm birth (PTB), and small-for-gestational age, among other adverse outcomes. To date, no RCTs in HIV high-burden settings evaluate perinatal outcomes using different models for antenatal CT/NG and TV testing and no evaluations assess implementation and cost outcomes within routine antenatal care. We propose a 3-arm hybrid effectiveness-implementation RCT among antenatal care attendees in Kisumu and Siaya, Kenya–a region with an HIV prevalence of 20% among women and 10% PTB rate–to compare effectiveness, implementation, and cost outcomes of delivering standard-of-care syndromic STI management vs. CT, NG, and TV testing using Xpert® assays universally vs. only among women without STI symptoms. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: OVERALL RESEARCH STRATEGY PROJECT NARRATIVE Increasing insecticide and drug resistance, limited sensitivity of field diagnostic tools and declining investments are urgent contributory factors to the decline in coverage and effectiveness of routine control interventions for malaria control and elimination. Moreover, the true contribution of non-falciparum malaria (NFM) – often presenting as asymptomatic infection – to the global disease burden remains underappreciated. The West- Central Africa Enhancing Malaria Epidemiology Research through Genomics & Translational Systems biology (Émergents [fr.]) ICEMR program is built on a proven research platform and consortium of World Bank, Wellcome Trust, African Academy of Sciences-, and NIH/CDC-funded centers of excellence in Cameroon and Nigeria, and will leverage this expertise to focus on (a) Genomic Epidemiological Mapping (GEM) of non-falciparum malaria (NFM) to quantify the parasite reservoir, measure transmissibility to mosquitoes and evaluate the insecticide resistance status of mosquitoes with NFM parasite infections; (b) Bionomics, Ecology, & Control of Anopheles stephensi (BECA) against the background of endemic primary and secondary anopheline vectors; and (c) Advancing Clinical and Entomological Surveillance (ACES) through emergent diagnostic and translational systems biology platforms to address emerging issues viz. asymptomatic malaria and non-falciparum malaria transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: CORE 2: ADMINSTRATIVE CORE PROJECT NARRATIVE The Émergents ICEMR is led by an experienced, multinational, interdisciplinary, and complementary leadership team and the implementation of a streamlined, decentralized organizational structure administrative structure. The overarching objectives of the Administrative Core is to provide the leadership, administrative support, and financial management to ensure the success of the Émergents ICEMR, through: (i) effective and efficient administration, coordination and management of all activities associated with the program to ensure that the program milestones are met; (ii) effective and efficient allocation of funds and maintenance of fiscal integrity; and (iii) effective coordination and communication between collaborating Co-Is from academic institutions and research institutes within the network. The Émergents ICEMR Administrative Core will be specifically responsible for leading Coordination of Malaria Surveillance and Core Activities; implementing an Émergents ICEMR Performance & Evaluation Program; and working closely with the NIAID-assembled Scientific Technical Advisory Group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: CORE 2: DATA MANAGEMENTAND STATISTICAL CORE PROJECT NARRATIVE Developing and maintaining rigorous data quality and management systems throughout the cycle of any research program is paramount to safeguard data privacy and confidential standards, as well as to ensure the completeness, consistency, and validity of results generated. The Émergents ICEMR Data Management & Statistical Epidemiology (DSME) Core will provide a central source of expertise related to data management, biostatistical analyses, and coordination of secure data exchange and archiving across all Core Components and Research Program Projects. Primary responsibilities of the Core will be to, (a) develop and support implementation of all standard operating procedures (SOPs) related to data collection, security, management, and analyses; (b) support quantitative study design and analytical results (c) coordinate efficient and consistent utilization of data and statistical resources across the projects by providing standard methodology and expert staff support that are readily accessible to all investigators; (d) establish a central, secure integrated data management and storage system; and (e) ensure that analytic methods used for data generated through the program are distributed in a commented, sustainable manner.

PROJECT NARRATIVE Malaria remains a global health crisis affecting over 241 million people and leading to 627,000 deaths, mostly in children. New tools are necessary to address emerging and drug-resistant strains, the complexity of mixed infections, invasive mosquito species, and the control of insecticide resistant mosquito vectors in support of the goal for malaria elimination. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROGRAM PROJECT 3 [PP3]: Advancing Clinical and Entomological Surveillance (ACES) through emergent diagnostic and translational systems biology platforms to address emerging issues viz. asymptomatic malaria and non-falciparum malaria transmission in the context of malaria elimination and eradication (MEE). PROJECT NARRATIVE Malaria remains a global health crisis affecting over 241 million people and leading to 627,000 deaths, mostly in children. New tools are necessary to address emerging and drug-resistant strains, the complexity of mixed infections, invasive mosquito species, and the control of insecticide resistant mosquito vectors in support of the goal for malaria elimination. Program Project 3 of the West-Central Africa Enhancing Malaria Epidemiology Research through Genomics & Translational Systems biology (Émergents) International Center of Excellence in Malaria Research (ICEMR) is focused on Advancing Clinical and Entomological Surveillance (ACES) through emergent diagnostic and translational systems biology platforms to address emerging issues viz. asymptomatic malaria and non-falciparum malaria transmission in the context of malaria elimination and eradication (MEE).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will establish an International Center of Malaria Research in Burkina Faso to study the spatiotemporal heterogeneity of malaria and malaria parasite transmission across the Sahelian, Sudano- Sahelian, Sudanian ecozones of Burkina Faso and within differing landscape environments (urban, rural, and migrant/artisanal gold-mining camps). Parasite (species and genetics) and host data (including age and clinical status) will be tightly linked to the complexity of vector species (primary and secondary), their locations near transient or permanent water sources, and translational studies of vector competence, transmission dynamics, and drug and insecticide resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Decades of collective effort in the HIV field have led to a consensus that germline-targeting vaccine approaches offer one of the best methods for effectively eliciting broadly neutralizing antibodies. However, prior efforts have been hampered by the relative rarity and improbable maturation path of targeted precursors. By studying the human germline antibody response to the recently discovered “silent face” gp120 epitope and designing immunogens targeting these germline antibodies, this work will help guide and augment rational vaccine design efforts against HIV-1.

IC_NAME: National Center for Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious Diseases
PHR: Project Narrative The EMERGEncy ID NET program is a sentinel research network of 12 geographically-diverse, university-affiliated US hospital emergency departments (EDs), which was established in 1995 to address the threat of emerging infectious diseases. Over the past 25 years, the network has worked closely with CDC partners to conduct translational research of emerging infectious diseases with a goal of improving patient care, health outcomes, and infection prevention strategies.

PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-CK-22-003, Emerging Infections Sentinel Networks (EISN) Research - 2022

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: Project Narrative The project has the potential to significantly reduce community rates of violence among youth age 10 to 24 across two high-burden Denver communities, Far Northeast Denver and Northeast Park Hill. In each community, we will implement and evaluate three innovative strategies for violence prevention that balance theoretical salience, empirical evidence, and practical viability. Together, these strategies, which were selected by our youth and community partners and are informed by the social development model, will help build an infrastructure for violence prevention with universal, selective, and primary interventions that can produce generalizable knowledge to inform violence prevention across the country.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: CE21-005 - Empowering Youth to Realize Equity and Prevent Violence: Youth Violence Prevention Center-Denver

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Intracortical microelectrodes enable recording of surrounding neural tissue in the brain to drive external devices for paralyzed Veterans. This proposal details the creation of innovative polymer coatings capable of enhancing neuroprotection following microelectrode implantation to increase the long-term recording potential of intracortical microelectrodes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: EDITH NOURSE  ROGERS MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSPITAL
PHR: The goal of this project is to develop a much-needed objective biomarker in PTSD that will allow more accurate treatment choices and faster evaluation of treatment response for individuals with PTSD. However, current clinical practice is based on subjective assessments and it lacks “objective” PTSD diagnostic and assessment methods based on underlying brain mechanisms of dysfunction. We propose to use quantitative EEG, a non-invasive, cost-effective, totally portable procedure, to precisely measure activity and connectivity between different parts of the brain during awake and sleep states in individuals with and without PTSD. If successful, these objective neuromarkers can be used not only for more accurate detection of the presence and severity of PTSD, but also for a faster and more accurate evaluation of response to current therapy, informing the potential need to switch interventions, and identifying those at high risk for relapse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study is designed to understand the mechanism of LVAD-associated bleeding complications using the state-of-art biophysical and mass spectrometry technologies, and conventional clinical tests. The study objectives are to 1) develop new model to predict for LVAD- induced bleeding 2) investigate the structural changes of the adhesive protein VWF induced by high shear stress found in the LVAD-derived blood flow, and 3) to study how cellular fragments and VWF promote the formation of immature blood vessels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC) is a type of cancer characterized by tumors whose growth relies on making new blood vessels, and therefore, ccRCC responds well to drugs that prevent new blood vessels from being made. ccRCC-associated mutations in a DNA-binding protein called PBRM1 improve patient response to these drugs that prevent tumor blood vessel formation, but mutations that do not inhibit PBRM1 activity are common, and the effects of these mutations on patient drug response are unknown. We will determine how mutations that do not disrupt PBRM1 activity affect how ccRCC tumors increase their blood supply so that patients who will not respond are not unnecessarily given drugs with toxic side effects.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Organelles are essential cellular compartments with a diverse set of functions. How parental gametes partition their organelles to their progeny and the significance parental organelles play in progeny development remain poorly understood. I take a multi-disciplinary approach using the model organism Drosophila melanogaster to identify maternally deposited organelle proteins that persist in their offspring and track how these long-lived proteins influence germline health of the next generation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The voluntary control of movement emerges from neuronal activity distributed across many motor controls structures – notably motor cortex, the basal ganglia, and spinal cord. We understand little of how these structures are coordinated, undermining our ability to treat associated movement disorders like Parkinson’s disease and dystonia. In this proposal I will test the idea that the logic of output of cortical projections to basal ganglia and spinal motor centers is coordinated through innervation of defined neuron types that provide cohesion in motor action.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The AKT pathway is often aberrantly activated in breast cancer and acts to promote both tumor growth and the maintenance of an immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment. The proposed studies will investigate the potential of pan-AKT inhibition to enhance the efficacy of immunotherapy strategies in mouse models of triple negative breast cancer and patient-derived organoid models. High throughput screening with a tumor-immune cell co-culture system will be used to identify additional targeted strategies, beyond AKT inhibition, that enhance T-cell mediated tumor cell killing and have the potential to synergize with immune checkpoint inhibition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genome instability is a hallmark of many cancers that both initiates and accelerates disease development. My preliminary data demonstrate that Chk2, an important DNA damage response kinase, protects against genome instability through a novel and mitosis-specific pathway that ensures proper chromosome segregation. Work proposed here will provide molecular insight into this mitotic Chk2-driven pathway, including its regulation, molecular substrates, and potential utility as a pharmacological target in pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Constructing the brain requires the coordination of several different cell types that permanently reside within the central nervous system. One of these cell types, microglia, is the resident immune cell of the CNS and must travel to and break into the brain before doing its job. We are studying how precursors of microglia colonize the developing brain and differentiate into microglia. This will help us understand the basic biological mechanisms behind how microglia get into the brain and persist, knowledge that is essential to fully understand microglia’s role in brain development and health.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Intracortical brain-computer interfaces have extraordinary potential to restore full upper extremity function to people with paralysis, but current solutions fall short of the capabilities of able-bodied people. Recent studies have shown drastic improvements predicting motor intention when using decoding algorithms that model neural population dynamics – the rules governing the evolution of neural activity over time – instead of directly decoding the recorded neural activity. This research proposal aims to use dynamics-based decoding to bridge the gaps in performance between intracortical brain-computer interface-controlled hands and able-bodied hands, creating a general-purpose upper extremity prosthesis to restore independence to people with paralysis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic kidney disease is a progressive, irreversible loss of kidney function affecting up to 37 million Americans and is a significant health burden with increased patient risks for cardiovascular disease, stroke, and early death. Despite the widespread use of therapies aimed at compensating kidney function, these treatments do not reverse chronic kidney disease and only delay the progression to its final stage, end stage kidney disease. The current proposal will elucidate the contributions of T cells to the inflammatory milieu of chronic kidney disease and investigate the mechanisms through which T cells localize to kidney tissue, providing preclinical evidence for potential therapies in the management of chronic kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The head direction (HD) system has proven a fruitful target for neuroscience research into navigation and has spurred significant theoretical advances in modeling the computations performed by neural populations. By incorporating the leading edge of neural recording technology into studies of the HD system in primates during both passive motion and and active locomotion, we will advance not just knowledge of the HD system specifically, but also our understanding of how multiple streams of sensory information are integrated into a coherent whole by populations of neurons distributed across many areas of the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tuberculosis (TB) is one of the leading causes of death from a single infectious agent, and though the most important risk factor for active disease is co-infection with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), the mechanisms by which HIV dysregulates the immune response during co-infection are not fully understood. The experiments described in this proposal will use a non-human primate model to examine how co-infection alters immune cell function to lead to greater TB disease in lesions (granulomas), specifically in immune cells that respond to intracellular pathogens (macrophages and CD8 T cells). The insights from these experiments will further our understanding of how HIV impairs the immune response to Mtb, which will inform both vaccine strategies and therapeutics development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE This project focuses on largely unexplored mechanisms that multicellular eukaryotes have evolved to grow and protect themselves from death and diseases caused by insufficiency and defects in secretory protein synthesis. To achieve our goals, we will harness the power of the genomic resources and molecular tools of the model plant species Arabidopsis thaliana, which allow genetic and advanced analyses that are impossible to perform in humans and whole-body mammalian models. By studying the signaling pathways of conserved sensors that monitor the homeostasis of secretory protein synthesis, this work will reveal new mechanisms that coordinate growth, stress responses and cell fate decisions and thus improve our understanding of human growth and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative. Insulin-degrading enzyme (IDE) is involved in cellular proteostasis and its dysregulation is implicated in several metabolic and neurodegenerative disorders. Our studies will characterize the structural and mechanistic basis of various proteolytic and nonproteolytic roles of IDE, thereby providing a molecular understanding of its multifunctionality, which will be beneficial for designing new therapeutic strategies to halt the progression of IDE- associated pathologies, including Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Behavioral performance in perceptual tasks involves a complex and dynamic interplay between external inputs and internal states such as alertness, motivation and attention, which are regulated by several neuromodulatory systems. The overarching goal of the current proposal is to develop and test an optical- genetic toolbox for monitoring and controlling multiple interacting brain regions in awake, behaving non- human primates, focusing on neuromodulatory circuits that exert a powerful, yet poorly understood, impact on the cortical circuits that mediate perceptual decision-making. This toolbox will open the door for advanced studies that would lead to a deeper understanding of the neuromodulatory circuits which play an important role in many complex behaviors and are implicated in many human neuropathologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol-associated liver disease is a major health problem accounts for approximately 40,000 deaths per year in the US. This project will examine the role that liver cells called Kupffer cells play in supporting and maintaining liver function during alcohol exposure. Understanding how alcohol specific Kupffer cells are able to protect the liver will allow development of therapies to reverse liver failure and accelerate recovery in patients who cease alcohol consumption.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disrupted primary cilia signaling and the resultant changes in neuronal circuit formation and function lead to brain malformations and neurodevelopmental disorders, including autism, schizophrenia, and epilepsy. We plan to precisely and comprehensively delineate primary cilia driven signaling mechanisms animating neuronal function and malfunction in the cerebral cortex. Understanding the molecular logic of primary cilia's role in neuronal functional dynamics and the relevance of this paradigm for neural circuit malfunction will enable us to use primary cilia signaling as a tool to mend neural circuit disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Blood-forming stem cells in the bone marrow regenerate blood and immune cells throughout life. Defects in stem cell maintenance that occur during aging lead to anemia, impaired immunity and leukemia, but the underlying cause of these defects is largely unknown. This proposal will examine if blood-forming stem cell maintenance and fitness is disrupted by the accumulation of aggregated protein, and will identify unique pathways used by stem cells to limit protein aggregation and enhance longevity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The University of California, San Francisco Training in Reproducible Research on Aging for Social Science and Epidemiology (UCSF-TRASE) program will develop, launch, evaluate, refine, and disseminate, intensive short courses on reproducible research perspectives and skills. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TOLEDO HEALTH SCI CAMPUS
PHR: Insulin, a hormone that rises in response to food intake and accumulating body fat stores, is known to promote early puberty and fertility by acting in the brain, but extensive research has not determined the neurons involved. New, exciting data from our lab indicates that non-neuronal cells called astrocytes sense insulin to permit normal reproductive hormone release. These studies will determine the underlying mechanisms so that novel therapies can be developed to treat infertility related to diabetes mellitus, obesity, and other metabolic disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Ultrasonic neuromodulation is a promising new technology that has the potential to provide revolutionary new therapies for neurological disorders including Parkinson's disease, dystonia, epilepsy, Alzheimer's, anxiety, schizophrenia, and stroke. However, use of this technology is impeded by the limited understanding of the mechanism by which ultrasound stimulates brain activity. The proposed research will provide a mechanistic understanding necessary to catalyze development of ultrasonic neuromodulation therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: RELEVANCE STATEMENT The way different kinds of cells express various genes at various times and in various amounts is determined largely during early organism development and often relies on proteins known as transcription factors. However, this control of gene expression can also be driven by dynamic interactions between the structures of the nucleus and the structures around the genes – particularly chromatin. Here we will study how nuclear proteins called nucleoporins purposefully link chromatin organization and remodeling to control of gene expression in certain cell types so that we can understand how they function in both health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately 10% of U.S. adults aged 65+ has Alzheimer's disease and related dementias. This project seeks to identify taxonomic and function features of the gut microbiome and fecal metabolites of microbial origin that explain inter-individual differences in the associations of healthy dietary patterns with cognitive function and risk of Alzheimer’s dementia in three studies of ~1,5000 participants. Based on the unique resources, the proposed research will provide foundational knowledge for maximizing the benefits of dietary approaches, discovering novel biomarkers, and ultimately contributing to precision dietary prevention of Alzheimer's dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT ALBANY
PHR: Narrative We propose to develop a class of potent, selective and chemically modified RNA aptamers that inhibit AMPA receptors, and test their efficacy and safety in the AR2 mouse that models sporadic ALS, where motor neurons undergo selective neurodegeneration triggered by excessive activity of AMPA receptors. If successful, our research will produce a novel RNA-based drug candidate for a potential ALS therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative My academic research career in the field of neurodegenerative disease spans 30 years, beginning with my discovery of the first CAG – polyglutamine repeat expansion as the cause of an inherited neurological disorder, extending to 22 years as an independent investigator who has worked primarily on three polyglutamine repeat diseases (X-linked spinal & bulbar muscular atrophy [SBMA]; spinocerebellar ataxia type 7 [SCA7]; and Huntington’s disease [HD]), and including 20 years of continuous R01 funding from NINDS, with two currently active R01 grants. I have recently published a number of significant papers that advanced our understanding of these disorders, demonstrating skeletal muscle expression of mutant androgen receptor as a primary driver of SBMA motor neuron disease in a series of independent studies, documenting PPARd dysfunction in HD pathogenesis, confirming a role for PPARd in normal CNS function, and establishing PPARd agonist therapy as a potential HD treatment. I now request funding through the Outstanding Investigator Award mechanism to continue my dynamic and wide-ranging investigations into the cellular and molecular basis of polyglutamine neurodegeneration, as I seek to define the molecular basis of SBMA skeletal muscle-driven motor neuron degeneration, delineate how PPARd activation achieves neuroprotection, determine if processes of NMJ dysfunction or overexuberant activity-dependent gene expression may be relevant to more common neurodegenerative diseases, including ALS and AD, and seek to develop novel therapies that will restore homeostasis pathways that decline in function with aging and are markedly diminished in neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research examines how multi-level factors contribute to disparities in health-related quality of life and survivorship care in diverse populations of young adult cancer survivors. During my dissertation research (F99 phase), I focus on the collaborative management of cancer among ethnically diverse survivor-caregivers. During the K00 phase, I will extend this research and training by developing expertise in understanding healthcare system and policy-level factors that contribute to disparities in cancer survivorship.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The COVID-19 pandemic has disrupted multiple aspects of youth's life and poses major risk for their mental health. Data is needed on factors that contribute to risk and resilience mental health trajectories during and following the pandemic. We will investigate a large US youth cohort followed before and during the pandemic to better understand what drives variability of mental health trajectories in US adolescents living through the COVID-19 pandemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Coronary artery disease is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality often treated by coronary artery bypass grafting surgery (CABG). CABG surgery is commonly performed via either single arterial graft or multiple arterial grafting strategies - while arterial grafts have better long-term patency than venous grafts, patients receiving multiple arterial grafts may experience higher perioperative risk. This re-submission K23 proposal aims to understand the effect of the two different revascularization strategies (single arterial grafting vs. multiple arterial grafting) on cardiac function immediately after CABG and subsequent clinical outcomes, with the goal of physiologically guided perioperative decision-making and improved clinical outcomes for patients undergoing CABG.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: This proposal is relevant to public health as it addresses nutritional gaps in one of our most vulnerable populations, preterm infants. The proposal is aligned with the recently released NIH strategic plan to accelerate nutrition research over the next decade and responds to the Notice of Special Interest: Nutrigenetics and Nutrigenomics Approaches for Nutrition Research. Specifically, our research team will conduct a randomized clinical trial of a nutritional fatty acid supplement to inform mechanisms of action and strategies to adequately provide these bioactive nutrients that are critical for fetal and neonatal development..

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The education and training of young MD and PhD researchers is the lifeblood of continued progress in medical care. This training grant fills a critical need by preparing these individuals to work at the cutting edge of translational biomedical research in gastrointestinal and liver diseases. The training program focuses on mentoring, career development and advanced degrees in the methods of epidemiology and health services research applied to digestive disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will provide important insights into broader population trends in ADRD prevalence and racial disparities in ADRD by considering how education operates differently to reduce risk for cognitive impairment and dementia under more (or less) advantaged educational contexts. The proposed research is relevant to several NIA priorities in the area of Alzheimer’s Disease and related dementias (ADRD), including identifying early life risk and protective factors for ADRD and the linkage of administrative data to existing longitudinal cohort studies.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE These studies will lead to fundamental new insights into the mechanism by which AIF regulates OXPHOS assembly in muscles. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Innate Lymphoid Cells (ILC) are recently described immune effector cells that play key roles in protective immune responses against nearly all classes of pathogens and in tissue homeostasis; but at the same time, their dysregulation contributes to the development of prevalent pathologies such as cancer, asthma, colitis, and obesity. While the transcription factor networks that control ILC development and functions have been extensively studied, how the epigenetic landscape and the 3-dimensional (3D) genome architecture regulate these processes remains largely unknown. In this proposal, we aim to establish how the 3D genomic and epigenetic architecture regulate the development and functions of ILC2 and ILC3 and how specific features of the 3D and epigenetic landscape in ILC2 contribute to allergic airway inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The microtubule cytoskeleton comprises the tracks for long-range transport in neurons and is essential for long-term health of these cells. Recent in vivo imaging experiments have generated understanding of the biophysical mechanisms that drive microtubule network development, but as of yet, there is no comprehensive theory that can explain microtubule reorganization that occurs in response to injury. This proposal combines novel mathematical modeling with theory-driven experiments in order to synthesize a deeper understanding of neuronal microtubule organization in healthy and injured cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study seeks to examine upstream indicators of structural racism as contributors to inequities in receipt of guideline-concordant cervical cancer treatment and survival in a diverse population-based study. Guided by the NIMHD research framework and socio-structural models, this mixed-methods study will leverage two NCI population-based Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results Program registries (New Jersey State Cancer Registry and Los Angeles Cancer Surveillance Program), to prospectively examine the impact of micro- mezzo-, and macro-level factors, with an emphasis on health system-level factors, on receipt of guideline concordant treatment for and survival from cervical cancer. Successful accomplishment of the proposed aims will result in high impact findings on the multilevel causes of suboptimal cervical cancer treatment and poorer survival outcomes among marginalized groups to develop actionable system-level practice and policy change to address the persistent cervical cancer inequities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The underlying mechanisms of tyrosine kinase inhibitor-induced vascular toxicity (TKI-VT), an increasingly reported adverse cardiovascular outcome in cancer survivors, are elusive, and preventative or protective treatments are not currently available. Combining patient-specific pluripotent stem cell technology, CRISPR- based high throughput drug screens, physiologically-relevant engineered vascular tissues, and animal models, this proposal seeks to investigate the underlying mechanisms of TKI-VT, which will set the foundation for a more precise search for novel personalized therapeutics for patients manifesting TKI-VT. This proposal will also advance basic and translational research in cardio-oncology by providing a humanized disease modeling and drug discovery platform to study cancer therapy-induced vascular dysfunction in general.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE

PHR: The work described in this proposal seeks to identify molecular mechanisms in the vertebrate retina that the govern the inflammatory response to the injury and death of photoreceptors. This work utilizes zebrafish as an animal model. This project is relevant to the NEI’s mission, because it will create fundamental knowledge regarding mechanisms that govern the regeneration of photoreceptors from cells that are intrinsic to the retina.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Neuropeptides and, importantly, the enzymes that modify their actions, are involved in an impressively large number of brain functions from healing following stroke, to the perception of pain, learning and memory, and mood. The proposed microfluidic device and its method of use will provide quantitative understanding of neuropeptide action in chosen brain regions. The fundamental and quantitative knowledge gained in the proposed research will aid in approaches, such as drug design, to lessen the harm and promote the good that specific peptides in particular brain regions do.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Through this multi-center AIP project, we will develop a robust deep learning-based software solution and integrate into the clinical PACS system to convert any clinical PET image into a high-quality counterpart with much lower image noise levels that can only be obtained with >90min long scan or extremely long field-of-view scanners. The translation into PACS servers with “one-button” convenient workflow will lead to fast clinical adoption and substantially benefit clinical practice to improve diagnostic accuracy and increase decision confidence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Despite steady increases in obesity prevalence, the more than 12 million obese U.S. adults with type 2 diabetes (T2DM) and severe obesity encounter a number of barriers to adopting effective surgical and pharmaceutical treatments, including: (a) both patients and primary care clinicians frequently underestimate the effectiveness and potential benefits of obesity treatments; and (b) both patients and clinicians typically lack access to evidence-based estimates of the patient-specific potential benefits and risks of appropriate obesity treatment options. This project addresses these important obstacles to evidence-based obesity care by providing accurate, patient-specific estimates of benefits and risks of various obesity treatment options to inform shared decision making about obesity treatment. In this project we implement a scalable, web-based point-of-care decision-support intervention in primary care that provides patient-specific estimates of obesity treatment benefits and risks in a randomized trial in 40 primary care clinics with 15,814 eligible patients, and assess intervention impact on (i) appropriate active management of obesity in eligible patients, (ii) weight trajectories, and (iii) patient and clinician satisfaction with the decision support intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative: Substance use disorders (SUDs) remain a significant public health problem that requires more effective treatment interventions. A cadre of clinical researchers is needed to develop novel treatment interventions for SUDs, often through translational research, to better understand who best responds to these interventions, and ways to best promote the implementation of these interventions. Our long- standing program has been at the forefront of training early career investigators and through continued support, our program hopes to continue to train the next generation of clinical investigators who will eventually become leaders in the substance use disorder field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity and asthma are common health conditions in the United States, and obesity-associated asthma tends to be more severe and difficult to control compared to other phenotypes of asthma. Understanding why this may be is important in reducing symptoms and disability associated with this common phenotype of asthma. This proposal examines if insulin resistance, pre-diabetes, and diabetes are associated with asthma outcomes, and if this association is stronger in obesity, in the hopes of identifying a new treatment target for obesity- associated asthma.
