IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Humans have developed mechanisms to restrict bacterial access to metals during infection, and thus, pathogens in turn have evolved high-affinity metal acquisition systems to overcome this restriction. This project will identify the mechanisms used by Yersinia pestis to acquire zinc in order to cause the human disease plague. As metal acquisition is essential for virulence, defining these mechanisms will reveal novel targets for the development of new anti-plague therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: The prevalence of opioid use disorder (OUD) during pregnancy has quadrupled over the past decade, as have adverse maternal and neonatal health outcomes related to substance use. This research will test the effectiveness of a prenatal provider education and training program designed to facilitate provider adoption of evidence-based practices for the treatment of OUD during pregnancy. Findings from this research will provide high-quality evidence about how to increase evidence-based treatment for pregnant women with OUD and subsequent maternal and child health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Severe inequities in HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) access and use in communities hardest hit by the HIV epidemic persist, further exacerbating ongoing racial/ethnic and socioeconomic disparities in HIV incidence. In these same communities, many patients at risk for HIV seek care for sexually transmitted infections (STIs) in Emergency Departments (EDs), but the structure of traditional ED care is poorly suited to address HIV prevention or provide PrEP. To advance the Prevent objective of the Ending the HIV Epidemic (EHE) initiative, ED2PrEP will leverage an implementation science approach to rigorously test two innovative strategies for increasing PrEP uptake among patients seeking STI care in EDs in one of the 48 EHE-identified geographic hotspots.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Recent evidence shows that there is a bidirectional relationship between epilepsy and Alzheimer’s Disease (AD), with an increased incidence of epilepsy in AD and higher dementia risk in people with epilepsy. Seizures and network hyperexcitability may be a treatable component of AD, as our recent preclinical results show that seizures can accelerate AD pathology. We will use novel AD mouse models and human tissue studies to identify neurodegenerative mechanisms triggered by seizure activity, as well as test efficacy of targeted therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative In the human body, for 100 human cells that are present, there are 130 microbial cells. Those microbes often define the balance of human health and disease, yet the molecules by which they promote this balance are unknown. We have designed a reverse metabolomics and big data mining strategy to discover microbial metabolites with emphasis on microbial metabolites associated with inflammatory bowel disease and other gut associated metabolic disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV-associated neurocognitive disorder (HAND) is a major health problem affecting the quality of life for millions of HIV+ patients. Our proposed research will use innovative human stem cell technologies to investigate the mechanisms of how HIV infection leads to HAND by altering the function of microglia, the primary immune cells within the brain. Through these studies, we will gain a deeper understanding of the root causes of HAND and potentially identify new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vaccines are one of the most important medical interventions in history, yet every year nearly 15 million people die worldwide from infectious diseases. The majority of infections are caused by bacterial or viral pathogens that enter and colonize the mucosa, such as the lung or gastrointestinal and reproductive tracts. The goal of the proposed research is to understand how adjuvant combinations can be used to direct immunity to the mucosal tissues and how these responses can be enhanced or “tuned” to target particular pathogens. As such, the pro- posed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge to reduce the burdens of human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Traumatic brain injuries (TBIs) affect 2.8 million individuals each year in the United States and often cause long-lasting cognitive and mood alterations, with the greatest external cause for TBI being falls, especially in older adults over 65 years of age. Given that behavioral tests performed to date after experimental brain trauma have primarily focused on motor and spatial learning deficits and not on commonly-reported complex attention impairments, this R01 application aims to characterize alterations in sustained attention, behavioral flexibility, and anxiety-like responses after experimental TBI in both young adult and aged rats, as well as to address mechanistic questions regarding altered cholinergic neurotransmission responsible for such behavioral impairments by restoring behavioral performance and acetylcholine brain marker levels with NS 1738 - a positive allosteric modulator of alpha-7-nicotinic acetylcholine receptors – alone or in a combination with enriched environment housing as a preclinical model of neurorehabilitation. Integrating animal models of higher-order cognitive processing in the behavioral battery after TBI is paramount to finding clinically-relevant therapeutic targets, and therefore the proposed studies will be carried out in males and females, an approach which may prove valuable for translation from bench to bedside and advanced rehabilitation research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because understanding how interactions between dietary protein and the intestinal microbiota impact human health will allow rational design of customized therapeutic interventions that consider detrimental and beneficial impacts of different dietary protein sources. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH's mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that will reduce the burdens of human illness. The research is also relevant to the mission of the NIGMS as it will provide new, broadly applicable methods to increase the understanding of functional interactions between humans and their microbiota, which lays the foundation for advances in disease diagnosis, treatment and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Individuals who develop cardiometabolic diseases may not have elevations in risk factors suggesting that there are other risk mediators underlying diseases that are not yet identified. This project will use cutting-edge and innovative multi-omics approaches which examine many factors measured in blood to identify groups of individuals who are biologically similar and will determine whether the groups have different functional and/or pathophysiological risk mechanisms for disease or different response to treatments. These groups can be further studied to determine their risk mechanisms, and this will ultimately lead to new personalized ways of managing and preventing cardiometabolic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The specific cell types that make up neural circuits, the ensembles of cells in our brain that coordinate behavior in health, are poorly understood. Our basic research project focuses on characterizing a specific cell type located in a brain center critical for social interactions. Our study will shed light on how this cell type normally regulates social behaviors and may have implications for how disease states alter such neural circuits and disrupt emotional well-being and social interactions in neurological and psychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Many adults in the United States have knee osteoarthritis, which is a disabling disorder with no treatments to slow, stop, or reverse joint damage. A challenge to testing new treatments is the lack of a clear definition of disease progression and not knowing how much change in a structural measure would reflect a meaningful improvement or worsening to patients. Our goal is to determine how much change in two novel measures of disease progression translates to clinically meaningful improvement or worsening and receiving a knee replacement.

PHR: OVERALL NARRATIVE – MATERNAL DETERMINANTS OF INFANT IMMUNITY (MADI) Building on the premise that the maternal and infant immune states, from gestation and through the first months of life, are interconnected entities, we propose a research program aimed at transforming our understanding of the determinants of immunity against infectious agents early in life. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Malfunction of the midbrain dopamine system is associated with a variety of pathological conditions including depression, anhedonia, apathy, schizophrenia, addiction, eating disorders and Parkinson’s disease. In particular, aberrant dopamine responses to salient events have been implicated in addiction, schizophrenia and other mental disorders. Understanding dopamine signaling in the healthy brain is essential to understanding states of aberrant dopamine signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: In this proposal, we use a novel comparative approach to define how variation in Drosophila brain circuits gives rise to species-specific behavioral variation. As the etiology of many brain disorders is aberrant neural circuit wiring, a deeper understanding of the link between genes, neural circuits, and behavior could have profound consequences for neurological health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute kidney injury in children with chronic kidney disease is associated with an increased risk of death and is thought to be a risk factor for an accelerated loss of kidney function. We will conduct research on children with chronic kidney disease to determine risk factors for acute kidney injury, assess glomerular and tubular health after acute kidney injury, and identify children at high risk of rapid kidney function decline after acute kidney injury. These studies may allow for the early detection and prompt treatment of rapid kidney function decline, inform clinical trial enrollment, and provide the foundation for interventional studies to improve long-term health in children with chronic kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE: Abnormal potassium and sodium transport occur commonly in the setting of chronic kidney disease and heart failure. We have now identified a novel mechanism by which the kidney can sense the change in dietary K+ and Na+ content and regulate K+ and Na+ excretion or absorption. The new concept will expend the current knowledge regarding renal K+ and Na+ transport and may lead to development of new approach for treatment of hypertension and dyskalamia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Recent animal studies have provided new evidence that the cerebellum may have a stronger link to the reward system of the brain than was previously recognized, raising the possibility that cerebellar dysfunction could contribute substantially to addiction via a cerebellar influence over reward centers. We will investigate the nature of the cerebellar contribution to reward processing, how this contribution is altered by alcohol use disorder, and the extent to which cerebellar/brainstem dysfunction is related to over-activation of reward centers in individuals with alcohol use disorder. We will further investigate if reducing cerebellar activation to alcohol-related stimuli with cerebellar stimulation will reduce activation in reward centers, and reduce craving for alcohol.

PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH SIGNIFICANCE This study will contribute to public health knowledge of the effects of Medicaid MCO coverage and utilization management design on access to alcohol use disorder treatment, and the effects of Medicaid enrollees’ alcohol use disorder treatment receipt within MCOs on adverse outcomes, namely alcohol-related emergency department visits, hospitalizations, and mortality. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is an important cause of human lymphomas, including Hodgkin lymphomas (HLs) and Burkitt lymphomas (BLs), especially in immunosuppressed hosts such as AIDS patients. EBV-infected HLs and BLs have stringent forms of viral latency (types I and II) that cannot transform B cells in vitro, and there are no in vivo models available to study how stringent EBV infection cooperates with activation of oncogenes, or inhibition of tumor suppressor genes (TSGs) to induce BLs and HLs in humans. In this proposal, we will use cord blood-humanized (and non-humanized) mouse models and a novel cell culture system to define mechanisms by which stringent latent EBV infection collaborates with activated oncogenes, inhibited tumor suppressors, and growth signals derived from the tumor microenvironment to drive BL and HL lymphomas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because protein degradation by the proteasome is an essential cellular process and it must function sufficiently for neurons to carry out their biological roles. Alzheimer’s disease is characterized by metastable proteins that are normally degraded by the proteasome, but in disease they missfold and accumulate instead. Determining the molecular mechanisms of why proteins are not properly degraded in Alzheimer’s disease is a critical step that is necessary to understand disease pathogenesis–making this proposal relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to increasing our understanding of life processes that lays the foundation for advances in disease treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Project Narrative. The breakdown of the conceptual system in the brain in many common neurological and psychiatric disorders, including stroke, dementia, temporal lobe epilepsy, and schizophrenia, has a devastating impact on quality of life. Understanding how this information is organized, represented in the brain, and affected by neuropathology is a major focus of research. The proposed project will study brain regions believed to be crucial for this system, both in healthy subjects and in patients with aphasia due to stroke, leading to insights into the functioning of this system, a critical step in developing effective rehabilitation therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The zoonotic potential of chronic wasting disease (CWD) is unclear to date. We provide the first evidence by transmission experiments to different transgenic mouse models and bank voles that Cynomolgus macaques inoculated via different routes with CWD-positive cervid tissues harbor infectious prions that elicit clinical disease in rodents. Our proposed studies will unravel the properties of these prions, how they will adapt to humans and which pathways are activated in brain cells and associated with clinical disease. Results from these studies uncover the potential manifestation of CWD in humans, which is highly relevant for human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: The goal of the University of Michigan (U-M) Pharmacological Sciences Training Program (PSTP) is to develop a diverse pool of well-trained biomedical scientists who have the technical, operational and professional skills required to conduct pharmacological research in an ethically responsible and rigorous manner, and to enter diverse careers in the biomedical research workforce. The competency-based PSTP curriculum is designed to provide trainees with a strong foundational understanding of the pharmacological sciences, to provide training in the performance of rigorous and reproducible research, and to provide career development, teamwork, and leadership training, all under the direction of well-trained and dedicated faculty mentors. Although U-M has individual graduate programs in the Departments associated with this training program, the PSTP is the only program at U-M that draws upon the expertise of faculty, alumni, the Michigan Drug Discovery Institute, and the enthusiasm of students across these units to fertilize interdisciplinary education, collaborative research, career development, and team-based approaches to innovation and translation in target discovery and development of experimental therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite successes seen in treating patients with ER+ breast tumors with endocrine therapies, approximately 33% of these treated patients develop recurrent metastatic tumors that primarily metastasize to bone and do not respond to current treatment options. In the proposed study, we will investigate the Cxcl5/Cxcr2 axis as a primary regulator and potential therapeutic target of metastatic bone colonization. We will evaluate both the mechanism of action of these factors and will determine the efficacy of Cxcr2 inhibitors against metastatic colonization of bone in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) is a heterogenous syndrome of cognitive and neuropsychiatric symptoms, with as much as 40% of patients being diagnosed with comorbid depression. The goal of this project is to establish the dose-response curves of a safe and clinically feasible non-invasive brain stimulation technique (intermittent theta-burst repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation [iTBS-rTMS]) to improve both depression and cognitive function in MCI patients with comorbid depression. These results will inform future clinical trials of iTBS-rTMS for MCI such that the optimal dose can be used when targeting dysfunction in shared brain circuitry underlying both cognitive and neuropsychiatric symptoms, with the long-term goal of developing an efficacious treatment to prevent dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Much of our knowledge of islet physiology stems from rodent studies, however, we now know that marked differences exist between rodent and human islets in regard to architecture, hormone secretion, and islet cell enriched transcription factor expression, demonstrating potential limitations in assuming that rodent models entirely mimic human islet physiology and disease. An example of such a discrepancy lies in the islet cell enriched MAFA transcription factor, a fundamentally important protein in rodent islet β cells that is not even produced in human islet β cells until ~9 years of age. We hypothesize that this TF plays an essential role in regulating human insulin secretion in adults, and will test this in two distinct experimental contexts, human embryonic stem cell-derived β cells and adult human islets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: Dopamine D2 receptors are the targets of all antipsychotic drugs currently available, but we lack fundamental knowledge as to which specific receptors in the brain must be blocked to achieve antipsychotic effects and which contribute to side effects. Emerging evidence suggests that D2 receptors can interact with other receptors in the brain to modulate their functional properties, creating potential new approaches to more targeted therapeutics. The molecular studies proposed in cells, brain slices, and ultimately in behaving mice will lead to improved understanding of how the function of these receptors is modulated by receptor interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of this R01 proposal is to use our stabilized Amyloid beta forms to uncover novel uptake-toxicity relationships to better understand Alzheimer’s Disease. Peptide synthesis, biophysical and cell culture experiments performed in the Raskatov lab will be combined with collaborative efforts with the Tycko lab (NIH) and the Eisenberg lab (UCLA), which may allow us to obtain experimental structures of Amyloid beta trapped in both toxic and non-toxic states. Research proposed may lead to future development of Alzheimer’s therapeutics that act as structural modifiers that convert Amyloid beta into a non-toxic state.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myoblast fusion is essential for skeletal muscle development and regeneration. Understanding the mechanisms of myoblast fusion will lead to significant insights into human muscle biology in health and disease, and ultimately provide a basis for optimizing muscle stem cell-mediated therapeutics against life debilitating muscle degenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This cooperative agreement funds a coordinating center that provides investigators across the United States with the tools, expertise, and support to conduct effective clinical research studies in allergic diseases and asthma. By ensuring consistency and quality of asthma and allergy research across multiple research sites, we can help provide new insights into management of these conditions and into biologic mechanisms of allergic disease development. These insights can lead to new treatment or prevention strategies that will improve the lives of people living with these conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative We propose constructing a two-organ microphysiological system composed of human cells for both sensory and motor segments of the reflex arc to study the effects of Alzheimer’s disease on the peripheral nervous system. We will establish clinically relevent functional models for AD by treating healthy systems with Aβ42 and tau oligomers in addition to motor and sensory systems composed of AD mutant iPSC MN-based NMJ systems to better understand the effects beyond the well studied systems in the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This work involves a collaboration between the Chamberlain/Hauschka labs at the University of Washington and the Spencer/Kramerova labs at UCLA to develop a gene therapy for the disease limb girdle muscular dystrophy type 2A (LGMD2A). The disease involves progressively increasing muscle weakness, due to mutations in a gene that codes for calpain 3. This therapy will use a viral vector to deliver the gene throughout the body to all affected muscles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This is a collaborative proposal to understand the molecular and cellular bases of memory changes in the context of aging and Alzheimer's disease. We have demonstrated that NPTX2, a marker of the information storage process, correlates with cognitive performance in humans during normative aging and in the context of Alzheimer's disease. Studies will examine the impact of NPTX2 reduction in human brain specimens and in neuronal circuits modeled in vitro using RNA and protein profiling, and the functional consequence of NPTX2 reduction on cognitive and behavior-linked circuit function using innovative rat models, and will provide fundamental new insights into memory, cognitive resilience, aging, and Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Addressing unmet clinical needs will require Ph.D.-trained scientists who understand the molecular basis of human health and disease, the mechanisms of drug action, and the drug discovery process. To achieve this goal, the Stanford Molecular Pharmacology Training Program (MPTP) integrates rigorous basic science research with specialized coursework and hands-on experiences related to therapeutic development. Through its innovative curriculum, the MPTP will empower its graduates to translate fundamental discoveries into clinical advances.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emerging evidence suggests that co-use of marijuana and tobacco have greater deleterious effects on health than use of marijuana by itself. The proposed project will build on the limited research done in humans that examined the pharmacological interaction between marijuana and tobacco by manipulating both THC and nicotine dose administered to participants and characterizing THC and nicotine exposure and effects. The expected findings will help us understand the risk of co-use of marijuana and tobacco, a pattern of substance use done by a large majority of marijuana users.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Latinos have the highest risk of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) in the United States, and inferior outcomes compared with non-Latino whites. In this study, we will leverage the unique evolutionary history of Native Americans to carry out a comprehensive study of the role of germline genetic variation in the increased risk of childhood ALL in Latinos. Our results will help to elucidate the causes of this significant ethnic disparity and to identify children most at risk of developing ALL.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: We have an on-going clinical trial, which is based on our research, evaluating the two pediatric doses of the anti- HIV drug efavirenz in patients with Alzheimer’s disease. Yet, we need to have a better understanding of how efavirenz acts in the brain when used at smaller doses and whether this drug could be further improved as a potential anti-Alzheimer’s disease medication. These gaps in our knowledge will be filled by the proposed research, which may ultimately lead to a new, disease-modifying treatment for Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will test several novel hypotheses regarding the mechanisms of auditory cortex plasticity after cochlear damage and peripheral hearing loss. Because these mechanisms are involved in many disorders associated with sensory deficits, such as hearing loss, schizophrenia, tinnitus, hyperacusis, and neuropathic pain, this research is relevant to those aspects of the NIH mission aimed at improving health through understanding pathophysiological mechanisms in disorders causing disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Sexual minority youth of color are at increased risk for alcohol and other substance use and misuse than their same-race heterosexual peers. These health disparities are a major public health concern, especially among adolescents, given the economic, societal, mortality, and morbidity burdens. The project will test the effects of sexual minority adolescents of color's long-term and daily experiences with stigma-related stressors related to their minority and stigmatized identities and structural oppression of states they reside on their alcohol and other substance use in their natural environment and over 2.5 years of adolescence, in order to inform and develop interventions and improve the well-being of sexual minority adolescents of color.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Dysphagia, or difficulty swallowing, is a common symptom of many neurological diseases but remains poorly understood. In this project, we optimize a multimodal imaging tool using magnetic resonance imaging to provide the unprecedented measurement of both the dynamic motions associated with swallowing, along with the associated neural activity to enhance understanding of swallowing control. This tool will be validated in healthy adults and a sample of patients with neurogenic dysphagia in an effort to improve neurogenic dysphagia characterization and help improve diagnosis and management of this debilitating health condition in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Depression is among the most prevalent and impairing forms of psychopathology, with incidence rates sharply increasing in adolescence and earlier age of onset predicting a more debilitating course of depression across the life span. The proposed innovative study examines the neurophysiological markers associated with alterations in emotion regulation that optimize the accurate and generalizable prediction of adolescents’ concurrent depression diagnosis and longitudinal prognosis. The rigorous approach to systematically disentangling neurophysiological markers relevant to emotion regulation and the classification of adolescent depression will further translational clinical research, enhance replicability, and identify novel targets for early intervention and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE With growing concerns regarding the environment and sustainability in the pharmaceutical industry, synthesis of drugs using electricity is emerging as a green and advantageous alternative to traditional synthetic methods because it can cut down on the usage of chemicals, reduce waste, and offer improvements in cost, safety, and sustainability in pharmaceutical production. The first step towards the long-term vision of electrically-driven green synthesis of drugs is to build up an electrosynthetic reaction library. The goal of this proposal is to establish alternating current electrolysis, which uses alternating current to drive chemical reactions, for new reactivities in organic synthesis.
